column1: "Donetsk People's Republic" leadership declares independence, seeks accession to Russia (Part 2) MOSCOW. May 12 (Interfax) - Leadership of the "Donetsk People's Republic" has declared independence of the region and has sough accession to Russia. "Upon the results of the referendum held on May 11, 2014 and based on the sovereignty declaration of the Donetsk People's Republic, we, people of the Donetsk People's Republic, declare that from now on the Donetsk People's Republic is a sovereign state," co-chairman of the "Donetsk People's Republic" government Denis Pushilin said at a news conference on Monday. "We ask to consider the issue of accession of the Donetsk People's Republic to Russia," Pushilin said. According to Pushilin, the supreme council formed by the "Donetsk People's Republic" government and security council will become the higher state body of the "Donetsk People's Republic." "The Donetsk region has always been part of the Russian world regardless of ethnic affiliation," Pushilin said. "For us Russia's history is our history. Russian and Soviet victories, including in the Great patriotic Warm are our common victories," he said. "The Donetsk region was part of the Russian empire initially," Pushilin said. "Only after the bloody catastrophe of 1917 it turned out to be separated by conventional administrative borders from big Russia," he said. "We lived most part of the 20th century as part of Ukraine but this was possible only due to the fact that Ukraine itself was territorial formation of the single state," Pushilin said. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, "our people still hoped that Ukraine, Russia and Belarus will restore their historical unity," Pushilin said. "This hope crashed completely in March 2014, when the Kyiv junta professing neo-Nazi fascist ideology seized power in Ukraine during the revolt," he said. ez

"Project Novorossiya is closed!" -- this news caused despondency in the "patriots" camp and glee in the Ukrainian media. "They dumped Novorossiya, they betrayed the Russians, all the sacrifices were in vain!" -- so said those who like to talk about the "dump party" in the Kremlin. But what really happened? We talked about this with a person who was directly involved in the events that led to the formation of the present Donets'ka and Luhans'ka People's Republics in the territory of Ukraine -- political scientist Aleksandr Boroday, former prime minister of the DNR [Donets'ka People's Republic]. [Perevozkina] Oleh Tsaryov, ex-deputy from the Party of Regions and head of the parliament of Novorossiya, recently stated that Project "Novorossiya" is closed. Various versions of this news were widely disseminated in the media. Is it really true? Is Project "Novorossiya" closed? [Boroday] It depends on what you mean by the word "project." Novorossiya is not so much a project as an idea. If you like, the people's idea, and a rather self-evident one. Because Novorossiya is, in reality, a certain region of Russia that was at one time, through the efforts of people like Potemkin and Suvorov at the time of the rule of Catherine II, incorporated into Russia. These were lands that had been under Turkish protection and dominion in one way or another but which, after a series of Russian-Turkish wars resulting in Russian success, went to Russia. That was how Novorossiya was formed. [Perevozkina] As I understand it, back at the time when an independent republic was being formed in Transnistria, certain people who took part in this also professed the idea of a greater Novorossiya incorporating Transnistria. [Boroday] The founder of Tiraspol was Aleksandr Vasilyevich Suvorov. It is only natural that this idea arose at that time, because there is such thing as historical memory. And it begins to operate at critical moments in Russian history. This historical memory has also operated now. At present as a result of the events that have taken place we must acknowledge with regret that Novorossiya as such, as some kind of statehood, does not, de facto, exist. It is a dream that has not yet come true. But that does not mean that it will not come true in the future. It is another matter that various Russian patriots have interpreted this dream in different ways. Some consider Novorossiya to be a region that should actually be part of Russia. I myself am among that number and I hope that this will happen sooner or later. There are also those who were hoping to build a state of Novorossiya that would be a satellite of Russia but still separate from it, a state that would become a kind of "ideal Rus." This idea did not become reality and I do not consider it viable. In practice there are two republics in the Donbas [Donets Basin] that exist separately but which support each other in the struggle against the Kyiv regime. [Perevozkina] Were documents on the formation of Novorossiya ever signed? [Boroday] Yes, a kind of declaration was signed. I was involved in this, my signature is on it too. This was in May of last year. At that time we were still proceeding on the basis of the possibility of the implementation of a Crimea scenario. Since the Crimea scenario did not happen, the idea of Novorossiya was also not really needed. Resistance to the Ukrainian junta in territories other than the Donbas proved insufficiently strong -- and was cruelly suppressed. Active people who were prepared to uphold the ideals of the "Russian World" and historical justice were either arrested and subjected to repressions, or emigrated to Russia, or else moved to the territory of the Donets'ka and Luhans'ka Republics, joined the ranks of the militia, and are bearing arms and fighting there. [Perevozkina] The uprisings in the spring of last year took place practically simultaneously in several cities in historical Novorossiya. This prompts the idea of some kind of synchronization of these actions. So, after all, did Project "Novorossiya" as some kind of plan formulated by someone exist in the first place? Set forth on paper, with the authors' signatures, then approved and ratified by someone as guidance for action? [Boroday] As far as I know, no plan existed in that form. [Perevozkina] So in what form did it exist? [Boroday] In the form of an idea, of course. This idea was taken up by the masses of the people. [Perevozkina] And whose idea was it? [Boroday] I do not know of any originator, it arose naturally. [Perevozkina] Which republics were supposed to form part of this greater Novorossiya? [Boroday] It is fairly obvious that it was supposed to include Kharkivs'ka, Donets'ka, Luhans'ka, Khersons'ka, Odes'ka, Zaporiz'ka, Dnipropetrovs'ka, and Mykolayivs'ka Oblasts. Eight oblasts in total. Those are the natural borders of Novorossiya. [Perevozkina] What does Tsaryov mean when he talks about the closure of Project Novorossiya? [Boroday] His organization specifically is closed. That is, the Parliament of Novorossiya. Because there is nothing for it to do. There are no territories of Novorossiya, there are only the Donets'ka and Luhans'ka Republics. There is no government of Novorossiya, there are the governments of these two republics. [Perevozkina] So who was behind this specific project that Tsaryov led? Who was lobbying for it? Who was supporting it in the Presidential Staff? [Boroday] Ask Tsaryov. [Perevozkina] He had an office in Moscow and some kind of funding. Where did he get that from? [Boroday] Oleh Tsaryov, to the best of my knowledge, is quite a well-off businessman. [Perevozkina] They took everything away from him in Ukraine. [Boroday] Everything or not everything, I do not know. I have not looked in Tsaryov's pocket. I do not think it was everything. To the best of my knowledge he was investing his own money in this project. [Perevozkina] Back at the very beginning, in April 2014, I had a feeling that Tsaryov was somehow not very well received in Donets'k. [Boroday] There was a kind of anarchy there at that time. All kinds of plans and possibilities were being discussed. As far as Oleh Tsaryov personally is concerned, yes, he did indeed have some problems with acceptability in Donets'k and Luhans'k because he himself is from Dnipropetrovs'k. And one region is distinguished from another there and it is understood that the "Donets folk" keep themselves somewhat apart. [Perevozkina] So what is the result: To all appearances, Russia was satisfied with the creation of the LNR [Luhans'ka People's Republic] and the DNR [Donets'ka People's Republic] and is refusing to fight for other components of historical Novorossiya? [Boroday] I cannot and will not answer for the Russian Federation. And what does "fight" mean? You know the actual line of the Russian Federation Government. It is that Russia does not interfere in Ukraine's sovereign affairs. That is the official view, it was articulated not by me but by many Russian Federation state figures, including the president. [Perevozkina] But what is your personal attitude to this? [Boroday] Personally, at the beginning of the events, in May-June, I really sincerely expected the Russian Federation to intervene directly and openly. To send in the troops and help the people of the Donbas and other oblasts of Ukraine to exercise their will, which was to become part of Russia. Not to form some kind of new state but simply to become part of the Russian Federation. [Perevozkina] To restore historical justice? [Boroday] At least part of historical justice. Because in my view Malorossiya [Little Russia] became detached from Russia as a result of the event that became known as the "breakup of the Soviet Union." There was a referendum in which the overwhelming majority of citizens of the USSR (around 90 percent, if I am not mistaken), including those living in Ukraine, voted against the breakup of the Soviet Union. Nonetheless disintegration took place, and borders that were purely administrative, not affecting anything, suddenly became real borders between states. Of course historical justice consists in the disappearance of these borders. Because people live on both sides of these borders who have the identical mentality, the identical education, the identical historical memory, who are linked by a single historical destiny and blood relationship ties. [Perevozkina] If it goes on like this, after a generation no common historical memory and no ties will remain. [Boroday] Yes, it is a tragic situation. After all, Ukraine's name is no accident. It is the "kray" [province], the "okraina" [outlying district], and there is nothing offensive about that. Vladivostok is also an outlying district of Russia, but its residents do not feel like second-class citizens. There is only one question: Is Ukraine the western outpost of the Russian world or the eastern outpost of the Western world? Not for the first time in its long history, the Slav world is being divided. A Slav Polish-Lithuanian state also sprang up at one time -- the Rzeczpospolita. And after a while the Catholic Rzeczpospolita, ideologically trampled by the West, became the worst enemy of the Russian world and of Russia. Now there is an attempt, inspired to a significant degree by the West, to turn Ukraine into something like Poland in relation to Russia. [Perevozkina] So this attempt must be resisted? [Boroday] Yes, it must be resisted as much as possible. But I do not make the decisions on the forms that this resistance should take. [Perevozkina] Can you tell us how you got involved in this story at all? How you ended up in Crimea? [Boroday] I went there. [Perevozkina] With the help of your friend Strelkov? [Boroday] Without help. I went to support the Crimeans, and specifically Serhiy Aksyonov. Just like Strelkov also went. In fact I turned up in Crimea a day or two later than Igor Strelkov, but without me he might not have gone to Crimea. Whereas I would have gone even without Igor Strelkov. [Perevozkina] That sounds intriguing. Why so? [Boroday] That was how the situation developed. No further comment. [Perevozkina] Because you introduced him to [Konstantin] Malofeyev [Russian businessman alleged to have funded rebel militias in eastern Ukraine]. [Boroday] Not only because of that. [Perevozkina] After Crimea, you left for the Donbas. You say you were expecting intervention by Russia in the events in the Donbas. [Boroday] If it proved necessary. When we left for the Donbas we still did not really understand how events would actually develop. [Perevozkina] So you went there without having any guarantees that Russia, if necessary, would protect the local population? [Boroday] Right. [Perevozkina] And nobody said to you: Guys, you start, and we will support you? [Boroday] No. [Perevozkina] So it turns out that you were simply playing the role of… [Boroday] Volunteers. [Perevozkina] ...No offense -- provocateurs trying to provoke the response they wanted from Russia? You were presenting the Russian Federation leadership with a fait accompli: The war has begun, people are dying, please help? [Boroday] We were not trying to blackmail anyone. We went there as volunteers. To help. A great many people approached us back in Crimea to ask for just one thing: "Please help." And when the question of how to help was raised, the answer was simple: "As commanders, as leaders, be the leaders." [Perevozkina] Was it the locals who were telling you they needed a leader? [Boroday] Yes. The people of Donets'k, Luhans'k, Kharkiv. Whoever you like. [Perevozkina] Strelkov actually said that this was what he was counting on. That he started the uprising in Slovyans'k in the expectation that Russia would intervene. [Boroday] He said a lot of things. He did not start the uprising. It started without him. He only went to Slovyans'k. At that time precisely the same kind of events were also happening in Donets'k and in other cities in the Donbas. And Strelkov was not there. I called on him in Slovyans'k in April. Then I went to Donets'k. Initially I went there as a political scientist for research purposes. [Perevozkina] And then they invited you to become prime minister. [Boroday] It turned out that there was no alternative. And since I am a Russian patriot and ideologically support the movement that was beginning in the Donbas back then, naturally I could not remain aloof. [Perevozkina] So the reaction from Russia was not what you expected? [Boroday] The reaction from Russia was not what we were hoping for, but at the same time none of us, at least not me, is making any accusations against the Russian Federation. Because we understand that the Russian Federation's reaction is determined by a great many factors of every kind, in particular foreign policy factors. And that the most important objective for the leadership of the Russian Federation is the prosperity of Russia itself and its citizens. On this basis the Russian leadership could have made this or that decision. And it had the right to make those decisions. None of us has the right to condemn the leadership of the Russian Federation because of these decisions. Maybe if Russian troops had been sent into the territory of Novorossiya back then, in the spring of 2014, the kind of bloodshed that happened and which is still continuing would not have ensued. But it could also have been very different. The leadership of the Russian Federation had a great many considerations on the basis of which it made a different decision. [Perevozkina] You say yourself that the people who live in Novorossiya are not very different from Russian citizens. [Boroday] That is true. And the Russian leadership provided political, moral, and humanitarian support to the people of the Donbas. The political support led, in particular, to the conclusion of the Minsk Accords and forced people in Kyiv to sit at the negotiating table and to recognize Donets'k and Luhans'k as parties to the conflict. Moral support -- the Russian media demonstrate that extremely well. The humanitarian support is also quite obvious. Probably more than 100 humanitarian convoys have already entered the territory of the LNR and the DNR. [Perevozkina] People living there claim that all this humanitarian aid is being stolen and sold on the markets. [Boroday] I think there are instances of corruption, but not so universal. [Perevozkina] The tone in the state media has also changed recently. It appears that they are gradually preparing people for the idea that the DNR and the LNR will remain part of Ukraine, even without the rights of federation components. [Boroday] I would not draw such far-reaching conclusions. Despite the endless wailing about how poor Novorossiya, Donets'k, and Luhans'k were "dumped on" by the Russian Federation leaders, the Donets'ka and Luhans'ka Republics still exist today. Despite all the circumstances. Despite the fact that Ukraine is still, in effect, waging a war against them and the Minsk Accords are not being particularly observed. They have been in existence for more than a year now. During that time their statehood has strengthened substantially. [Perevozkina] The question is whether they will exist much longer. [Boroday] I am not about to make predictions. The situation is changing very rapidly. Furthermore I believe the existence of the DNR and the LNR is in principle a temporary thing. Because the Donbas should not and will not be independent. In my view these regions should be incorporated in one way or another into the Russian Federation. But that is my personal view. [Perevozkina] What about the other regions? [Boroday] I think Ukraine is doomed to disintegrate. [Perevozkina] You were saying that a year ago. But still it goes on and on not disintegrating… [Boroday] Ukraine has not disintegrated yet only because of the effect of the very strong organizational and financial resources of the West, which is not permitting it to break up into its components. This is an unnatural statehood. It is not actually a statehood in principle, in my view. Throughout its 23 years Ukraine has essentially been a kind of oligarchate only outwardly presented as a statehood. The fact that it is now disintegrating is a fait accompli. As of today three of the most important regions have already dropped away from Ukraine. The DNR, the LNR, and Crimea. When I said that Ukraine would finally disintegrate within the year I was not taking into account the powerful resources of the West, which mobilized the whole of the rest of Ukraine for the war against the Donbas. It is only the mobilization for the war against the "Russian world," of which the LNR and the DNR are the vanguard, that is preventing Ukraine from disintegrating for the time being. If this war should come to an end, a great many questions would arise within Ukraine for its leadership. And if you take into account the extremely threadbare state of the Ukrainian economy, I think Ukraine will collapse practically immediately after the end of the war. Therefore what is called the Ukrainian statehood and the present Kyiv "elite," so-called, are in a rather difficult, stalemate situation. They have practically no resources to continue the war. They understand that if they run into yet another serious military defeat it will be a huge problem for the stability of present-day Ukraine as a state, but they also cannot not continue the war. Because then legitimate questions would arise about their effectiveness and the need for all this mobilization and the casualties that have already occurred. And also questions about the state of the Ukrainian economy. At the moment it is being maintained exclusively by the West's financial resources. [Perevozkina] And also those of Russia, which is continuing to supply Ukraine with gas, coal, and electricity at concessionary rates. Even Poroshenko's enterprises are continuing to work in Russia as if nothing had happened. [Boroday] Which only goes to show that the Russian leadership is demonstrating that it has no interest in the disintegration of Ukraine. But specifically as a political scientist I believe that this disintegration is predetermined. Because at a certain point the external factors will cease to operate. The West absolutely does not want to go on feeding and supplying Ukraine indefinitely, and this is not to its advantage. Furthermore Ukraine in itself is of no interest to the West, and particularly the United States. For them, this is some kind of godforsaken spot on the map of the world. Therefore as soon as the situation is exhausted Ukraine will disintegrate of its own accord under the weight of internal contradictions. [Perevozkina] I wonder which will happen first: whether Ukraine will disintegrate or whether it, in conjunction with Moldova, will suppress independent Transnistria. This, in my view, is the next item on the agenda for our "Western partners." [Boroday] For all the delicacy of Russia's position it is still capable of rebuffing the West's aggressive aspirations. As for the person who leads Russia -- I think Vladimir Putin is a very smart, subtle, and experienced politician. True, he is not inclined to publish all his plans or issue program statements. [Perevozkina] Do you think he has plans? [Boroday] I am not personally acquainted with Vladimir Putin but I am confident he knows what he is doing. Our leader is not short of experience, intelligence, and will. [Perevozkina] Does [Vladislav] Surkov [Putin's adviser on Ukraine] also know what he is doing? [Boroday] Why this question? Surkov is a state official. He does not operate autonomously. He operates in accordance with the line determined, first and foremost, by the president of the Russian Federation. Surkov, in this sense, is not an autonomous player. True, he is a brilliant person and his personality gives rise to a great deal of talk and gossip. Empty, as a rule. [Perevozkina] As I understand it, his line is to conduct a policy with the support of the local oligarchs and on the basis of agreements among the oligarchs. The report that Mariupol' was not taken for the reason that this would have damaged the business of the Donets'k oligarch Akhmetov came as a real shock to me personally. The recently killed brigade commander Mozhovyy held different views: He understood the uprising in the Donbas specifically as a people's anti-oligarchic revolution. Is that why he was killed? [Boroday] I have no special theories about who killed Mozhovyy or why. I did not know him well. We had a real conversation only once: when I left Slovyans'k in April 2014 and met him at the border. Later I saw him once or twice in Donets'k. I am not prepared to comment either on him as an individual or on the circumstances of his death. [Perevozkina] He thought the struggle against the oligarchs was the subject on which people living in both eastern and western oblasts of Ukraine could come together, and then the revolution would happen on a countrywide scale. [Boroday] What kind of revolution? Socialist? Personally I am an opponent of socialism in any of its manifestations. [Perevozkina] Anti-oligarchic. [Boroday] I became sick and tired of anti-oligarchic fervor long ago. Experience shows that it is usually a cover for commonplace looting. "Let us 'nationalize' something, then quickly split it up or cut it up for scrap metal and then sell it… To Ukraine, naturally." So, say you are honest "anti-oligarchs." You take some oligarch or other and hang him from a lamp-post. The people's wrath is satisfied. And what next? What do you do with his property? Who among the people's masses knows how to manage it? You have acquired export products, where will you sell them? You nationalize an enterprise and go to the international market with this output. You knock on the doors. And they turn you around and hand you over to the police. Because from the viewpoint of international legislation you are thieves. And nobody will buy anything from you. And all the plants you nationalized grind to a halt. And the workers who used to work at them start to go hungry. And nothing else will come of all that social revolution and anti-oligarchic fervor. Although I also understand those who, having lived their lives in Ukraine, hate the omnipotence of the oligarchs. But the cure for oligarchic tyranny is not nationalization but merely the existence of a state that restricts that power. The existence of the normal institutions of statehood, which have never before existed in "independent Ukraine." [Perevozkina] It is strange to hear such things from a former correspondent for the Red newspaper Zavtra. [Boroday] What do you mean, the Red newspaper Zavtra ? Zavtra is a patriotic publication in whose pages both "Red" and "White" views coexisted and were respected, notional as those distinctions may be.

(adds details, context) VIENNA, May 27 (Itar-Tass) - The special observer mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) in Ukraine said Tuesday it has lost contact with its team working in the Donetsk Region in eastern Ukraine. According to an OSCE news release, the organization was last in touch with the group of four monitors at 18.00 local time on Monday, when the group was involved in planned patrols of Donetsk"s eastern part. The OSCE said it is continuing efforts to establish contact with the group, adding that the Ukrainian government and regional authorities have been informed. Instability embraced Ukraine after the country saw a coup in February. New people were brought to power amid riots as security concerns caused President Viktor Yanukovich to leave the country the same month. Massive protests against the new Ukrainian authorities erupted in Ukraine’s Russian-speaking southeastern territories after the secession of the Crimean Peninsula, which declared independence on March 11 and joined Russia on March 18 following a referendum. Demonstrators in southeastern regions, who have been demanding the country’s federalization, seized some government buildings. Kiev has been conducting what it has dubbed "an antiterrorism operation" against pro-federalization activists. Russia, which does not recognize the new Kiev authorities, has said the operation is punitive. The eastern Ukrainian Donetsk and Lugansk regions held referendums on May 11, in which most voters supported independence from Ukraine. Denis Pushilin, the chairman of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic (DPR) Supreme Council presidium, told Itar-Tass that more than 50 militiamen and 20-50 civilians have died since Ukrainian law enforcers launched the active phase of their military operation in Donetsk on Monday. Donetsk Mayor Alexander Lukyanchenko confirmed the death of at least 40 people in clashes near the city airport. Ukrainian parliament-appointed interior minister Arsen Avakov confirmed that "dozens" died as a result of Kiev’s operation in Donetsk. Clashes near the Sergey Prokofyev International Airport in Donetsk started on Monday morning. Ukraine’s law enforcers used attack aircraft, including fighters and combat helicopters. Fighting in the area was ongoing all day and throughout the night. Now the situation in the city is calm, the DPR says.

(adds) MOSCOW, June 18 (Itar-Tass) - Prospects for contacts between the Russian leadership and Ukraine’s leaders will depend on how long the punitive operation of the Ukrainian Armed Forces continues in the east of the much-troubled country, Dr. Alexei Pushkov, the chairman of the State Duma foreign policy committee told a news conference Wednesday. "In my assessment, it would be essential for (Ukrainian President Petro) Poroshenko to issue an order on a ceasefire so as to make a contact with the Russian President possible, because any such contacts are rather problematic in amid combat actions," he said. "The stance of the Russian government towards Kiev depends in many ways on whether or not the punitive operation continues," Dr. Pushkov said. He also hailed President Poroshenko’s decision to replace the Ukrainian Foreign Minister and to appoint diplomat Pavel Klimkin to the post. "I think it’s a correct decision," Dr. Pushkov said, adding that the former acting minister, Andrei Deshchytsya, was "lost for the diplomatic sphere" after last Saturday’s violent incident in Kiev, in which he addressed an obscene insult to Vladimir Putin. "His verbal escapade crossed him out of the diplomats’ ranks," he said. "Deshchytsya displayed professional inaptitude and I don’t think the foreign ministers of other countries would continue treating him seriously after a declaration of this kind." Saturday, June 14, a mob of radicals in Kiev assaulted the Russian embassy, overturning the diplomats’ cars and hurling Molotov cocktails at the building. Andrei Deshchytsya who arrived at the spot of the incident took the liberty of making an obscene remark against the Russian leadership. Wednesday, Pyotr Poroshenko filed a request with the Verkhovna Rada, the national parliament, to relieve Deshchytsya of ministerial duties and to appoint the former ambassador to Germany, Pavel Klimkin , to the post.

(Updated with new figures for those injured and detained.) MOSCOW/WASHINGTON, January 20 (RIA Novosti) – The United States has slammed Ukrainian authorities over violent clashes between police and demonstrators in the capital Sunday and threatened to impose sanctions if force is used against protesters. Dozens were injured in Kiev as police deployed water cannons, stun grenades and tear gas against protesters throwing Molotov cocktails, fireworks and other projectiles at police, international news agencies reported. National Security Council spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden said the US is deeply concerned about the latest clashes. Hayden said the Ukrainian government "has moved to weaken the foundations of Ukraine's democracy by criminalizing peaceful protest and stripping civil society and political opponents of key democratic protections under the law," Associated Press reported. She called on Ukraine to open a dialogue with the opposition. The White House says the US is considering measures including sanctions if the Ukrainian government uses violence, echoing a warning from the US State Department last month. A crowd of tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in downtown Kiev on Sunday to protest new legislation that lawmakers hurriedly passed last week to limit protests. Tensions ran high well into the night as police reportedly used water cannons and tear gas against demonstrators near the parliament building, while protesters hurled various objects and smoke bombs at police. The violence continued despite appeals from opposition leaders, including Vitaly Klitschko, at the scene. The Interior Ministry said Monday that a hundred police officers had been injured, of whom at least 61 were hospitalized. Six police cars were burned, it said. Ukraine’s Unian news agency cited authorities as saying 103 protesters had sought medical assistance as of early Monday morning, with 42 of them hospitalized. More than 20 people have been detained and an investigation has been opened into mass rioting, police said. Media reports said a film crew from the US-funded Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty had been held by the police, but officials had not issued any confirmation as of Monday afternoon. Two men who identified themselves as construction workers said they had been hiding from the clashes when a group of riot policemen ordered them to strip before beating them and pouring water over them, Ukraine’s Channel 5 reported. Temperatures are well below zero degrees Celsius in Kiev. City police said they were looking into the claims. President Viktor Yanukovych said late Sunday on his official website that he had instructed National Security and Defense Council head Andriy Klyuyev to form a working group of ministers, and presidential administration officials to work on the settlement of the political crisis. Vadim Kolesnichenko, a lawmaker with Yanukovych’s Party of Regions, said “foreign special services” were behind the anti-government protests, Korrespondent.net website reported Monday. He defended the new law on protests as similar to those existing in Europe and the US. Sunday’s rally, one of the biggest this year, was the latest in a series of large-scale street protests that kicked off around Ukraine in November after the government announced it would postpone the signing of association and trade deals with the European Union, opting instead to strengthen ties with Moscow.

(Updates with paras 3-5) MOSCOW, June 19 (Sputnik) - The "artificial restriction" in the form of Western sanctions against Russia will not last long, First Deputy Prime Minister Igor Shuvalov said Friday. "The Europeans want to work with the Russians, the Russians can invest in Europe. And so these artificial restrictions in the form of sanctions cannot last long," Shuvalov said at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum. His remark comes ahead of the June 25-26 EU summit in Brussels, where the European leaders are expected to discuss the prolongation of anti-Russia sanctions that expire in July. Moscow has said it will not leave any new possible sanctions by the West without response. The European Union and other Western countries have introduced several rounds of sanctions against Russia since 2014, accusing Moscow of involvement in the armed conflict in Ukraine. Moscow has repeatedly denied the accusations, calling the sanctions counterproductive, and retaliated with a one-year food embargo on imports from the European Union.

(Updates with paras 7-11) MOSCOW, April 27 (Sputnik) - Russia will not change its stance and will not quit supporting the compatriots as a result of the Ukrainian crisis, Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Monday. "I do not feel that this Ukrainian drama will result in a surrender of our positions and a refusal to support our compatriots," Lavrov said in an interview to Russia 24 television. He pointed out that President Vladimir Putin has repeatedly stressed that nobody can force a wedge between Russia and the Ukrainian people. "The fact that there [in Ukraine] has occurred an unconstitutional coup and ultra-radical forces have taken power, which are still to some extent running the show and have been branded a "war party," it does not negate the above said," Russian top diplomat added. Lavrov stressed that Russia has become a target of an unprecedented campaign of confrontation aimed at isolating the country on the international arena. "The goal has been proclaimed clearly - to isolate Russia. It has failed ... Those, who have unleashed this campaign, begin to realize its futility," Lavrov pointed out. Speaking on the subject of the Minsk deal, the implementation of which European Council President Donald Tusk said earlier remains the "best chance" of settling the year-long conflict in Ukraine, Lavrov pointed to Kiev's evasion of its responsibilities. "The February 12 Minsk agreements are very difficult to misconstrue, they are highly specific... The fact that Kiev's leadership violates and interprets them as they see fit is becoming increasingly evident," the Russian diplomat said. The ceasefire deal reached in the Belarusian capital envisioned an immediate ceasefire in the region, a pullout of heavy artillery, prisoner exchanges, as well as a series of constitutional reforms. As part of the deal coordinated by France, Germany, Russia and Ukraine, Kiev undertook to decentralize powers, hold special elections and grant southeast Ukraine's Donetsk and Luhansk regions special status by the year's end. The Ukrainian conflict began last April two months after the ouster of President Viktor Yanukovych, who opted out of signing an association agreement with the European Union. The country's southeastern population refused to accept the February coup and proclaimed independence, triggering an armed response from government forces and leading to the loss of over 6,000 lives, according to UN estimates.

[Computer selected and disseminated without OSE editorial intervention] Baltic states favor greater presence of NATO allies in region to restrain Russia - Latvian Foreign Minister BRUSSELS. Dec 3 (Interfax/BNS) - Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia favor developing a mechanism of long-term, expanded and significant presence of NATO allies sufficient "to restrain any type of aggressive actions" on the part of Russia by the summit of the alliance in July. After a conference of foreign ministers of NATO member-states Latvian Foreign Minister Edgards Rinkevics said that the talks focus not on the establishment of permanent NATO bases in the Baltic region but on preparing a solution for the Warsaw summit of NATO that would guarantee a sufficient mechanism of restraint. Other countries of the Eastern flank of NATO, such as Poland and Romania, also favor that. "This means more expanded, even greater presence of NATO allies without any definitely set terms. Not the stylistic discussion of some one or other phrase, not the way to call all this but the real presence of allies is in our interests now. Work continues on concrete issues but I have seen that our colleagues on both the Eastern and Southern flanks are determined to do their utmost for this long-term NATO presence in the Baltic, Poland or the so-called Eastern flank to happen and that it would be sufficient," Rinkevics said. Ambassadors of NATO countries, and defense ministers and military experts plan to discuss the issues. The Latvian foreign minister also drew attention to the fact that the allies supported Latvia's determination to increase its defense budget to 2% of the GDP. "This removes certain tensions," he said. Asked whether the 1997 Founding Act on relations, cooperation and security between Russia and NATO binding the sides not to conduct noticeable movements of forces could obstruct the strengthening of allied presence Rinkevics pointed out to the resolutions of the NATO summit in Wales on increasing NATO presence in the Baltic states, Poland and Romania which followed the unification of Crimea with Russia. "We are speaking of such actions that are related to the strengthening of defense. We are not speaking of things that are inscribed in the 1997 NATO-Russia document. Neither are we speaking of any termination of the 2002 Rome Declaration. Therefore we don't see absolutely any contradictions here. In any case the 1949 NATO Treaty stands above all other documents," he said. At the conference the foreign ministers of NATO countries also discussed questions of improving information exchanges with Russia realizing the need for communication channels to avoid various incidents to the utmost, the developments in Ukraine and relations with Russia, the NATO strategy in conditions of a hybird war. As reported earlier Rinkevics took part in the conference of NATO foreign ministers in Brussels on December 1-2.

[Computer selected and disseminated without OSE editorial intervention] Maidan shootings case has no direct evidence of Russia's involvement - Ukrainian prosecutor KYIV. Oct 30 (Interfax) - No materials related to the criminal investigation into the Maidan shootings of winter 2014 contain any direct evidence of the Russian security agencies' involvement in the events and the statements made by former chief of the Ukrainian Security Service Valentin Nalyvaichenko are no more than his own vision, head of the special investigations department of the Ukrainian Prosecutor General's Office, Serhiy Gorbatyuk, said. "We have no direct evidence of the involvement [of the Russian security agencies] in the shootings. In other words, having confirmed the list of papers earlier submitted to the investigators, including those bearing his [Nalyvaichenko's] signature, witness Nalyvaichenko confirmed that these are the same documents that allow him to forward a version saying that these people could be involved," Gorbatyuk told reporters in Kyiv on Thursday. The involvement of the Berkut special forces police regiment in the killings of protesters has been established, Gorbatyuk said, adding that now it is necessary to find out who exactly, driven by what kind of motives and acting under whose instructions gave the order to shoot. Within the scope of the probe, investigators are making efforts to establish how certain forces could contribute to such instructions being given to senior Ukrainian officials, Gorbatyuk added. According to reports, Nalyvaichenko claimed on Thursday that the Maidan shootings cases investigated by the PGO contained some data indicating the alleged involvement of the Russian security agencies and Russian senior officials in the events. He also said that "the investigators will study this version" and that "the evidence is present in the case," but admitted that he cannot talk about any details, citing the secrecy of the investigation. Nalyvaichenko also revealed that he had confirmed the information voiced by him earlier that three Russian army generals visited Ukraine in December 2013 and in January-February 2014. "All these official documents are present in the case and available to the Prosecutor General's Office," Nalyvaichenko said. st kh iz

[Computer selected and disseminated without OSE editorial intervention] PAGE: http://charter97.org/en/news/2015/10/28/175708/ ) TITLE: Freedom Closer Than Seems: Lawyer on Savchenko's Prospects to Return SECTION: News AUTHOR: PUBDATE: 28.10.2015 (Charter97) - Ukrainian pilot and Member of Parliament, held in Russian prison, Nadia Savchenko, will return to Ukraine in 2016, according to her lawyer, Mark Feygin. "I'm out of the prison in Novocherkassk. Nadia sends greetings to everyone. Freedom is closer than it seems. In the new year, Savchenko will leave for home," he wrote on Twitter. However, Feygin did not disclose any further details on this issue. As UNIAN reported earlier, in the summer of 2014, Savchenko was abducted by terrorists in Donbas and illegally moved to Russia. In Russia, she was accused of complicity in the deaths of Russian journalists. However, according to Savchenko's defense, she could not be involved in the deaths of reporters, as she had ben captured before they were killed. The indictment in the criminal case against Savchenko comes to charges of attempted murder, murder, as well as illegal border crossing. [Computer selected and disseminated without OSE editorial intervention] PAGE: http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=28700 ) TITLE: President Meets Parliament Speaker SECTION: politics AUTHOR: "Civil Georgia" PUBDATE: 27 Oct.'15 (civil.georgia /politics) - President Giorgi Margvelashvili met Parliament Speaker Davit Usupashvili at the presidential palace on Monday evening. Margvelashvili and Usupashvili “discussed existing situation in the country and spoke about the importance of dialogue,” president’s office said in a brief statement. After the October 22 statement  in which he spoke of “prerequisites of civil confrontation and violation of constitutional order” and criticized PM Irakli Garibashviliâ€™s remarks  for adding tension to already difficult situation, President Margvelashvili held series of meeting with political parties, civil society and media representatives, and foreign diplomats. After his call for consultations was snubbed by the Georgian Dream ruling coalition, the President asked on October 23 for a meeting with the PM and the Parliament Speaker. Parliament Speaker Usupashvili also met on October 26 lawmakers from the opposition Free Democrats party. “Politicians should unequivocally and unconditionally denounce all forms of violence and contribute to civil accord,” Usupashvili said. Also on October 26, at a session of parliamentary bureau, lawmakers from the opposition UNM party raised before the Parliament Speaker the issue of the investigation, which was opened on October 24 by the State Security Service, into alleged coup plot. The State Security Service said that it launched investigation into “conspiracy to overthrow the government” based on unspecified “operative-investigative activities carried out by the counter-intelligence department and information reported in the media outlets.” The information in question is a reference to unsubstantiated text published by an obscure website, which claimed that ex-President Mikheil Saakashvili, who is now governor of Odessa region in Ukraine, was plotting with one of the leaders of UNM party, Giga Bokeria, attacks on Rustavi 2 TV personnel with a purpose to then trigger mass protests. Bokeria, who dismissed the report as “delirium”, was questioned by the State Security Service on October 24. UNM lawmakers told Usupashvili to intervene and find out details of this matter. The Parliament Speaker responded that it was beyond his competence to look into specifics of ongoing investigation, but also suggested that it will damage the State Security Service itself if it opened its investigation only based on dubious information in question. “I am convinced that it will become clear very soon if the investigation is based only on [the information] you have mentioned; if so then it will be, to say the least, extremely damaging for those people who have launched this probe based on that document,” Usupashvili said. “But it will also become known very soon if there is also some other basis for launching such investigation.”

Dec 17 (Interfax) - Ukraine will not be able to redeem the $3 billion in "Russian" Eurobonds, which mature on December 20, 2015, on initial terms, the Ukrainian Finance Ministry said. "Regardless of their characterization, and reserving Ukraine's position as to the obligations themselves, the December 2015 Eurobonds constitute debt obligations which Ukraine cannot pay in accordance with their initial terms without (i) violating the financing targets established under the Extended Fund Facility and (ii) breaching its contractual obligations under the 'most favored creditor clause' included in the new sovereign debt securities issued in November 2015 as part of the recently completed debt operation," the ministry said in a statement, posted on its website. [Computer selected and disseminated without OSE editorial intervention] Ulyukayev: extraordinary efforts needed to not introduce food embargo, non-preferential trade regime with Ukraine starting Jan 1 BRUSSELS. Dec 2 (Interfax) - The trilateral consultations between Russia, the European Union and Ukraine in Brussels on Tuesday did not lead to reaching the needed agreements, and experts were ordered to try to find acceptable solutions within a month in order to ease Russia's concerns about Ukraine's association agreement with the EU, but "extraordinary efforts [will be] needed" so that no food embargo and no non-preferential trade regime are introduced in relation to Ukraine, Economic Development Minister Alexei Ulyukayev told reporters after the negotiations. He said that the introduction of a food embargo against Ukraine is not related to the issues of association itself, but to the fact that Ukraine has joined sanctions against Russia. Ulyukayev also said that EU proposals to ease Russia's concerns are unacceptable for Russia, while Russian proposals have been only partially taken into account and this is clearly not enough. "The discussion was fairly positive today. And if this conversation, and if the positions that we reached in mutual understanding had taken place a year ago, I would have thought that we were progressing well. But since we have a month left, of course the situation still causes concern," Ulyukayev said after the trilateral consultations with ministers from the European Commission and Ukraine. "We considered several options for a possible agreement. In our view, what was prepared by our colleagues from the EU is unacceptable, primarily because these documents are not legally binding but consist of statements of willingness by the parties to find solutions to problems as actual harm is identified. But we're saying that it's late to resolve problems when harm has already occurred. We need to create a situation that will not allow such harm to occur. Therefore, we're saying that a legally binding structure needs to be formulated where each party would have its obligations," Ulyukayev said. He said that the association agreement between Ukraine and the EU that goes into effect on January 1 implies fundamental changes to the legal terrain. "And the degree of obligations that Ukraine assumed toward Russia in our bilateral agreements and multilateral agreements within the context of the CIS decreases. They want us to agree to the degree to which the obligations of our Ukrainian partners decrease while maintaining our obligations concerning preferential trade with a zero customs tariff. We believe that this is not fair and economically detrimental. Therefore, we have presented our proposals, our version of this document, in which we took into account a great deal of what our European colleagues are proposing but included a mechanism of obligation - first we agree on the principles, and then we already form working groups that monitor, track how these risks materialize or don't materialize, and help in making decisions," Ulyukayev said. He also said that Russia has proposed specific mechanisms under which there would be a "trilateral system of information exchange in the area of customs that would make it possible to track the origin of goods and close possibilities for goods from third countries to fall under the preferential trade regime between Russia and Ukraine." "We proposed maintaining the system of compliance certificates that Russian exporters now work with on the Ukrainian market, and the parallel functioning of two systems of standards - European standards that Ukraine is introducing at home and the standards that Ukraine needs to meet under CIS agreements, so that they be in effect side by side and businesses can choose. We proposed approximately the same thing in the area of sanitary and phyto-sanitary control," Ulyukayev said. He also said that, in the area of energy, Russia proposed maintaining the parallel operation of the Ukrainian and Russian energy systems, as well as wording that ensures an acceptable investment climate for Russian and Ukrainian companies - "its non-deterioration, non-application of measures that discriminate against investors." "Our colleagues agreed with a lot of this. Nonetheless, there is no acceptable document yet and in our joint statement following the meeting we authorized experts to continue the work. We agreed to continue the work on both the expert level and at the ministerial level, but since there is little time left, some kind of extraordinary efforts will be needed in order to achieve agreement," Ulyukayev said. "Nonetheless, we are proceeding from the assumption that the work will be conducted based on the draft that we presented. Our colleagues have taken an additional break for study. But we all need to understand that you can study as much as you want, but after January 1 we'll have to already study in a different economic reality," Ulyukayev said. Mk of vp ak

[DONETSK, Ukraine. June 7 (Interfax) - The head of the legislature of the unilaterally proclaimed "Donetsk People's Republic" expressed the belief it was he who had been the target of the gun attack in the center of Donetsk on Saturday that killed one of his assistants. "That was a political assassination. I had been traveling in that car quite often myself. There were two persons inside the car. One of them was my assistant Maxim, a deputy of the Supreme Council of the Donetsk People's Republic. His duties were humanitarian relief and supplies of drugs for Slovyansk and Kramatorsk," Denis Pushilin said. The bullet-riddled Toyota was provisionally left on the crime site, where detectives were at work, and some of the surrounding streets were cordoned off by traffic police, An Interfax correspondent reported from the site that the dead body also remained on the site. Two of the bullets had pierced the windshield. "They confused him with me a little. I wore a suit the same color as his, and he had a beard, just as I do. Thank God, the other man who was in the car, one of our people, managed to leave the site of the attack. He jumped out and run away in the opposite direction. The situation is that the car stopped, for some reason, most likely because the computer inside had been switched off. It wasn't just an accidental attack. It had been planned," Pushilin said. When the vehicle stopped and the gunfire started, Maxim, who was at the wheel, told the passenger they ought to get out and dash off in different directions, and that is what saved the passenger, Pushilin said. "After the latest bloody murders, any peace negotiations with the Kyiv government are out of the question," he said. Earlier, in reporting the assault, the press service of the "Donetsk People's Republic" told Interfax: "On Pushkin Boulevard in the city center, not far from the Piramida cafe, the car of an assistant to Denis Pushilin, head of the Supreme Council of the Donetsk People's Republic, came under fire from an assault rifle. Maxim died on the spot." The press service did not disclose the assistant's last name and just said he had been a Supreme Council deputy. However, the Ukrayinska Pravda newspaper named the victim in a tweet as Maxim Petrukhin. The Munitsypalna Hazeta newspaper also named him as Maxim Petrukhin and added that he had been aged 28 and born in Makiyivka. He had been a Donetsk City Council deputy, and Pushilin's humanitarian affairs aide, Munitsypalna Hazeta said. In testimonies contradicting Pushilin's words, witnesses said Pushilin and Petrukhin were standing outside a restaurant when more the 10 shots were fired at them from a car that was passing by.

A Moscow court arrested Ukraine's interior minister in absentia Wednesday, the Investigative Committee said in a statement.   Arsen Avakov is suspected of using prohibited means of warfare and killing civilians en masse during the Ukrainian government's campaign against insurgents in the country's east, the committee said.   Earlier the same court - Basmanny District Court - arrested in absentia the governor of Ukraine's Dnipropetrovsk region, Igor Kolomoisky, who is also accused by Russian investigators of organizing the mass killing of civilians. Russia has issued an international warrant request for the arrest of Kolomoisky and Avakov. The court rulings against the Ukrainian officials are widely seen as a political move, as Russia does not have the authority to detain foreign nationals outside Russian territory. Moscow has repeatedly condemned the military campaign being waged by Ukrainian troops against pro-Russian rebels in the country's conflict-torn east.

A swastika sign appeared on the building of the Ukrainian consulate in the city of Hrodna in the early hours of 21 May, the Belarusian independent Nasha Niva newspaper's website reported at 0926 gmt on 21 May. The employees of the consulate expressed their indignation at the act of vandalism and noted that nothing like this had happened in Hrodna since the start of the mass protests in Ukraine back in November 2013, when "locals were bringing flowers and candles to the consulate building" and expressed their compassion to the Ukrainians. The swastika was painted over later on 21 May and the consulate decided to purchase a video-surveillance device in near future. According to the newspaper, there is a memorial plate dedicated to the Belarusians of Jewish descent, who died during the WWII in Hrodna, on the other side of the same building which hosts the Ukrainian consulate. Local neo-Nazis have been vandalizing the plate several times in the last few years. Source: Nasha Niva, Minsk, in Belarusian 21 May 14

A trucks of a Russian convoy carrying humanitarian aid for Ukraine. MOSCOW, September 13 (RIA Novosti) - The Russian Red Cross Society representatives are not accompanying the second convoy carrying Russian humanitarian aid to violence-torn eastern regions of Ukraine, Raisa Lukutsova, the head of the organization, told RIA Novosti Saturday. No escort, Lukutsova said, answering a question about whether the trucks are being escorted by the Russian Red Cross representatives. Earlier in the day, Russian customs officers confirmed that the customs procedures for all Russian trucks with aid for Ukraine were completed. On Friday, the self-proclaimed Luhansk People's Republic said that Moscow had formally notified it that the second Russian humanitarian aid convoy would arrive Saturday. The convoy includes 200 trucks that are carrying canned food, sugar, flour and other aid of a total weight of 1,880 thousand tons. The first convoy of 280 trucks carrying about 2,000 tons of Russian humanitarian aid was sent to eastern Ukraine in late August and entered the country through a checkpoint controlled by independence forces after spending more than a week waiting at the border. Residents of the conflict-ravaged Luhansk, who had been living for several weeks on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe, greeted the aid delivery.

A view of Crimea Meshkov was elected as the President of Crimea on January 1994 winning more than 70 percent of the vote in run-off presidential elections. After winning the election, Meshkov promised to hold a referendum on Crimean independence in the spring of 1994. Furthermore, it was decided to make Russian the official language and introduce the ruble as the official currency in the peninsula, The New York Times reported in 1994. The Ukrainian government in Kiev, then led by Leonid Kravchuk, was not happy with Meshkov's endeavors. Meshkov was forced to cope with political terrorism and assassination attempts due to his political stance, which was unfavorable for the government in Kiev. The first Crimean president had to travel with two bodyguards armed with machine guns, according to a New York Times article from 1994. The people of Crimea were very much in support of the independence referendum in 1994. "We need a change. Khrushchev gave the Crimea to Ukraine as a gift in 1954. You can give territory, any physical thing you like, but you can't give people. Crimea was and is Russian," an unnamed Crimean businessman was quoted by the New York Times. "Russia has to help us somehow, give us rubles, something. After all, we're Russians," said Sasha Mochalko, a 21-year old police officer from Simferopol, as cited by the New York Times. Eventually, Meshkov was arrested and taken to the court. The government in Kiev did everything to bring chaos into the peninsula, soldiers were brought in, while Meshkov himself was removed from his post and the position of the president removed. The outspoken politician himself later had to flee and could only return to his native Crimea last year, when his life was no longer in danger. The New York Times article from 1994 gives a very different description of the situation: unbiased, objective journalism that back then the Western media was still capable of writing. The article's tone is that the Crimean people had a right for self-determination, as words, such as "re-unification with Russia" are used in the article.

The toppling of the elected government of Ukraine and the voting of the Crimean parliament – by 78 votes with 8 abstentions – deciding the day of referendum (16 March 2014) when Crimean voters will choose between joining the Russian Federation or to remain part of Ukraine as as an autonomous region with very strong powers, according to the 1992 constitution appears to be a reincarnation of the Cold War. The Cold War was a sustained state of political and military tension between powers in the Western Bloc (the United States with NATO and others) and powers in the Eastern Bloc (the Soviet Union and its allies in Warsaw Pact). Following the demise of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic (USSR) on 26 December 1991, leading to the breakup into twelve republics, the US became the sole super power and marked the end of the Cold War. The energy sources of the Central Asian States, made them lucrative targets for influence by both the US and European Union as well as Russia. In the past two decades, Russia was in a weakened economic state to be able to assert its influence authoritatively but in the near past, the Russian bear has woken up from its hibernation and is vying for regaining control. Its moves into Abkhazia, Ossetia and Georgia virtually went unchallenged by the Occident, renewing Russian confidence. The current crisis in Ukraine came into effect because of a regime change forced by civil unrest and protests. Pro Russian troops control Crimea. According to a Russian-Ukrainian treaty signed in 2010, Moscow has an agreed and constant military presence in the Crimean peninsula. Russia pays Ukraine $97.75 million annually for use of the naval base in Sevastopol. Under the Russian-Ukraine agreement, Russia is permitted 25,000 troops in Crimea. If the Russian narrative is to be given credence, (based on a leaked telephonic boast by US spokesperson Victoria Nuland), in the last ten years, the US invested US$ 5 billion to effect a regime change and force the pro-Russian President Viktor Yanukovych to flee and be replaced by What Moscow regards as an illegal, neo-Nazi infiltrated government in Kiev, led by Prime Minister Arseniy "Yats" Yatsenyuk, an Ukrainian Jewish banker playing the role of Western puppet, who insists Crimea must remain part of Ukraine. Yet this "government" – supported by the US and the European Union – has already declared the March 16 referendum illegal. Yats has banned the official use of the Russian language in Ukraine; got rid of the communist party, which amassed 13% of the votes in the last election, more, incidentally, than the neo-Nazi-infested Svoboda ("Freedom") party, now installed in key government security posts; and banned a Russian TV station, which happens to be the most popular on Ukrainian cable. The US narrative pleads that democracy-seeking protesters forced Russia's puppet president from office and are building a new government, which represents Ukraine's Western values. Meanwhile, the city council of Sevastopol – the headquarters of Russia's Black Sea fleet – has already voted to join Russia. And next week the Duma in Moscow will study a bill to simplify the mechanism of adhesion. EU is caught in the middle. Its energy resources as well as trade are dependent on Russia. The 9 billion euro (US$12.4 billion) Nord Stream between Russia and Germany via the Baltic Sea form its lifeline. Angela Merkel, the former Russian president Dmitri Medvedev, and former German chancellor and now Nord Stream chairman Gerhard Schroeder were instrumental in launching the pipeline project carrying Russian gas to Germany when it went online in 2011. Moreover, two-way trade between Russia and the EU was around a whopping US$370 billion in 2012, with Russia exporting mostly oil, gas and cereals, and the EU exporting mostly cars, medicine, and machine parts. US President Barack Obama has declared that the referendum in Crimea would "violate international law". Last Thursday he ordered sanctions on people responsible for Russia's military intervention in Ukraine, including travel bans and freezing of their US assets. Meanwhile, the US Defense Department has announced plans to add several fighter jets to US aircraft squadrons based near Russian borders, in a move to embolden the Baltic States and Poland. Sources indicate that the Pentagon plans to send six additional F-15 fighter jets, and a Boeing KC-135 refueling Stratotanker, to beef up the squadron of four F-15 currently flying air patrols over the Baltic States. NATO has been carrying out patrols in the Baltic States for the last 10 years. The threat of sanctions may backfire. Russia in solidarity and alliance with China has all the trumps in its court; Europe depends to 40% on gas supply from Russia, of which 80% passes through Ukraine; China holds about 1.6 trillion dollars of US debt it could drop and annihilate the US economy; that Russia, China, India, Brazil and South Africa – the BRICS – with almost 50% of the planet's population and about one third of the world's GDP will not be affected by the sanctions. Russia, on the other hand is reminding the US of its interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq and the US sponsored secession of Kosovo from Serbia in 2008. Moscow may not be bothered about Ukraine being promised a membership of the EU because the overwhelming majority of Europeans don't want it as part of their club. It would be concerned regarding NATO bases in Ukraine. Moscow might even compromise on Ukraine remaining a sort of Finland between Russia and Europe. With Crimea still inside the Ukraine, a NATO base side by side with the Russian base in Sevastopol would be nightmarish. While a US-Russia standoff continues to deepen a cold war like milieu, the crisis in Syria is likely to take a major hit. Russia is a guarantor in the destruction of Syrian strongman Bashar Al-Asad's arsenal of chemical weapons and any efforts to further widen the chasm between Russia and the US will directly affect the prospects of peace in strife torn Syria. The cold war is thus being revived.

VILNIUS, May 13, BNS -- Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister Konstantin Gryshchneko says former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko is being treated pursuant to the law, and pledges that Kiev will ensure "the best medical treatment" for the politician having health problems. "She is in hospital now, and, of course, everything possible is being done for her to receive the best medical treatment," Gryshchenko told BNS on Monday [ 13 May] in Vilnius. He also said that Tymoshenko's situation is a subject of conversations with EU officials, but added that in this case everything is being done pursuant to the law. "This issue is being discussed at meetings with representatives of various European states and the European Commission. Nevertheless, we are acting pursuant to the Ukrainian law," the Ukrainian deputy prime minister said. Following a meeting with Lithuanian Prime Minister Algirdas Butkevicius, Gryshchenko told BNS   he hoped that an Association Agreement between Kiev and the European Union would be signed during the forthcoming EU Eastern Partnership meeting in Vilnius in the fall. The EU has accused Ukraine of "selective justice" and demands that Kiev prevents such a practice before the signature of the Association Agreement which also includes an agreement on free trade.

Acting Ukraine president upbeat about anti-militia op in east KYIV. May 21 (Interfax) - Acting Ukrainian President Olexander Turchynov on Wednesday visited Ukrainian Army positions near Slovyansk, Donetsk region, and held a conference in a new military camp near the city with Interior Minister Arsen Avakov, Defense Minister Mykhailo Koval and National Guard commander Stepan Poltorak. The conference focused on "objectives for the final phase of the counterterrorist operation," parliament said in a statement. "The logistical base of our military is improving daily," Turchynov said, adding that on Wednesday modern communications equipment had been supplied to the forces involved in the "counterterrorist operation." Turchynov also held a conference with senior security officials of the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk on the organization of voting during the planned presidential election of May 25 and on proposed measures to enable the local population to vote. He said people in eastern Ukraine "are coming to realize that the terrorist separatists are leading the region into an abyss." "It is for this reason that the anti-terrorist action of the Ukrainian government has been receiving stronger support in these regions." Turchynov said. He said he had given the forces deployed locally the task of purging the region of "terrorists" and "restoring peace in the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk." as mk

Agency: Russian detectives ready go to Ukraine to test claim MH17 downed by Ukraine pilot MOSCOW. Dec 29 (Interfax) - Russia's Investigative Committee said on Monday it is ready to promptly send detectives to Ukraine to verify claims that MH17 may have been shot down by a Ukrainian air force jet. "Representatives of the Russian Investigative Committee are ready to leave for Ukraine shortly with all necessary equipment for testing the pilot Voloshyn and all others who might know anything about the [crash]," spokesman Vladimir Markin told reporters. Markin cited Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) spokesman Markiyan Lubkivsky as saying "let them come here" in a comment on an Investigative Committee offer to check Vladyslav Voloshyn on a lie detector. "We have said repeatedly," said Markin, "that we are open to any form of interaction, including with the Ukrainian side, in investigating the crash of the MH17 Boeing. It's just that our Ukrainian counterparts are showing an unsurpassed lack of openness and any desire to give any role in the investigations to anyone who seeks to find the true cause of what has happened and not to juggle facts to fit the official theory that serves the interests of Kyiv and the West." "So they're inviting us to Ukraine? We'll be glad if the SBU is as good as its word and organizes joint work of this kind. Our Malaysian partners shouldn't be forgotten either, though," the spokesman said. "Now we're waiting for a response from the SBU - whether we ought to set off right now or wait till their supervisors' holidays are over," he said. Last week Markin told Interfax that Russian investigators had obtained evidence that MH17 had been shot down by a Ukrainian air force plane. "The investigators didn't put off interrogations, and last night they were able to meet with a Ukrainian serviceman who confirms that he has voluntarily left his armed forces unit and came across to the territory of the Russian Federation," the spokesman said. "According to the testimony of what is now a witness, whom a pseudonym has been given in the interests of his security, the Boeing 777 airliner of Flight MH17 might have been shot down on July 17 by [a Sukhoi] Su-25 combat aircraft of the Ukrainian air force that was piloted by Capt. Voloshyn of the Ukrainian air force," the spokesman said. "The facts and information that the witness possessed and shared - clearly, without getting confused - convince the investigators that his testimony is truthful, something that, by the way, a polygraph test has confirmed," he said. "As the witness may be in danger, the investigators are considering providing him with state protection under the witness protection program," Markin said. SBU spokesman Lubkivsky on Wednesday claimed that SBU investigations had overturned the allegations that MH17 might have been downed by a Ukrainian warplane were false. "It has been found out that, in conformity with the plan for the counterterrorist operation, no aircraft from the Air Force … were used on July 17," Lubkivsky told a briefing in Kyiv. Moreover, data from the radar center in Dnipropetrovsk of the Ukraerorukh enterprise confirmed this, he said. Lubkivsky said Voloshyn did take part in the military operation in eastern Ukraine but that on July 17 he was on an airfield in Dnipropetrovsk. "According to a report from the command of the Air Force of the Armed Forces of Ukraine and military unit A4465, the above-named officer made no flights that day, and his aircraft was under repairs because of damage inflicted during landing on July 16," Lubkivsky said. The spokesman cited Voloshyn as saying he didn't know how the allegations about his possible attack on the Malaysian jet had found their way into the Russian media. "Voloshyn claims that the photograph posted on the Internet had been taken during a flight show for the press in Mykolayiv [Ukraine] in summer 2012," Lubkivsky said. He added that Voloshyn's Su-25 was shot down on August 29 and that Voloshyn ejected, hid on militia-controlled territory for a while, and had never carried out any flight missions since then. Also on Wednesday, Markin urged Ukraine to make official records of July 17 hostilities available to Dutch or Malaysian investigators of the crash. "It is an achievement already that the SBU admits that pilot Voloshyn exists. It is easy to check whether he flew on July 17 - just make the so-called journal of hostilities available to the Dutch authorities that are conducting the official investigation, or, better still, enable the same Dutch or, even better, Malaysian specialists to test Voloshyn, who, as we know now, does exist, on a polygraph," Markin said in a statement made available to Interfax. "Neither would it hurt to question and test the traffic controllers who, for some unclear reason, took the Boeing off its route. But first of all, one would have to find them, Markin said. "Clearly, all this is very difficult, or most likely impossible, to do. It's much easier to call the information and evidence that has been reported by the Russian Investigative Committee a fake," he said. The crash killed all the 298 people on board the Boeing, which was en route from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur. Among the victims were 196 Dutch nationals, 44 Malaysians, including the 15-member crew, and 27 Australians. There were also citizens of Indonesia, Germany, Belgium, the Philippines, Britain, Canada, and New Zealand among the passengers. International investigations have led to a tentative conclusion that the crash was caused by damage from an external source, most likely a missile. as

Almost 2,000 people from Ukraine enter Belarus in past months - Lukashenko KLIMOVICHI, Mogilev region. April 28 (Interfax) - In the past months almost 2,000 people from Ukraine entered Belarus, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko said. "You know, this is the scariest thing when people leave and are forced to flee with their children. It is good that we take them. Where are people to go?" Lukashenko said on Friday when addressing Klimovichi residents. According to the information by Lukashenko, "literally 4,500 people entered Belarus and almost 2,000 of them are from Ukraine." Ukrainian citizens are disoriented, Lukashenko has said in his address to the parliament and Belarusian citizens. "The European Union proposes integration, Russia - federalization and they do not understand what the essence of the two is. Two forces are fighting and people are sucked into this trap. Ordinary people like you, who do not know what to do," the Belarusian president said. "Some are calling for barricades, others are given arms - go and shoot. Shoot who? Our people, own brothers?!" he said. The Belarusian president said he could not ban entry to Belarus, but they are watching who is coming. "Families, it is clear. But criminals could rush here too. We have enough of those and can barely cope," he said. Belarus is concerned about the situation in Ukraine, Lukashenko said. "And the worst is yet to come," he said. "Of course, we do not want to interfere in Ukrainian issues too much but this is at our doorstep. So I, same as you, take this with pain and told the president yesterday - tell yourself if something is needed from Belarus, I can help in this regard. If necessary, pick up the telephone and say it - we will come and help," the Belarusian president said. ez mk

Ambassador: Ukraine crisis settlement is EU chair country Latvia's priority MOSCOW. Jan 22 (Interfax) - Latvian Ambassador to Russia Astra Kurme hopes that Latvia will promote the peace process in Ukraine in the capacity of the EU chair country. "Hopefully, the Ukraine crisis settlement will be progressing in the period of our presidency and we will be contributing to that as much as we can," she said at a press conference at the Interfax central office on Thursday. "The resolution of other problems will not begin until then," the Latvian ambassador added. "As long as the EU and Russia have not reached [consensus] over such important matters as security in Europe, it will be very difficult to speak about something else," she noted. "Yet, I would like to assure you that Europe and Russia need one another. We should restore our relations as rapidly as possible and put an end to all military and non-military crises in Europe as they are totally inappropriate in the 21st century," the Latvian ambassador underscored. Another 16 trucks from Russian aid convoy arrive at Donetsk border checkpoint DONETSK, Rostov region. Aug 21 (Interfax) - The next 16 KamAZ trucks from Russia's Ukraine-bound humanitarian aid convoy approached the Donetsk checkpoint in the Rostov region near the Russian-Ukrainian border on Thursday. The 16 vehicles were parked on the premises of a transport enterprise, located near the checkpoint. The first 16 trucks from the aid convoy that entered the premises of the Donetsk checkpoint late on August 20 have not moved anywhere so far.

Another humanitarian aid convoy formed in Rostov Region MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Russia's 38th humanitarian aid convoy for residents of Ukraine's troubled southeast (Donbass) is heading for the Donetsk and Lugansk regions, a spokesperson of the Russian Emergencies Ministry said early on Thursday. "At 04:00 Moscow time [01:00 GMT] the Russian Emergencies Ministry convoy with humanitarian aid for Donbass left the [Russian] Donskoy rescue center in the Rostov region," the spokesperson told journalists. At the border with Ukraine the convoy vehicles will split into two groups, one of which will head to the southeastern region of Donetsk, while the other one will go to Lugansk. The convoy consists of over 100 vehicles that are carrying over 1,200 metric tons of aid including food, such as flour, tea and grains, as well as school and university textbooks for Donbass students. The Donetsk and Lugansk regions have been severely affected by fighting between Ukrainian troops and Donbass independence supporters, which started in April 2014 when Kiev launched a military operation in the region. Overall, Russia has sent more than 45,000 metric tons of humanitarian aid to Donbass since August 2014. In November 2014, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko ordered to impose an economic blockade on Donbass, withdrawing all state-funded health, educational and social protections from the region. Earlier this week, the Russian Foreign Ministry stressed that Kiev must avoid any actions that could lead to the deterioration of the humanitarian crisis in Donbass, stressing that the bombardment by Kiev-led forces and the restrictions on cargo transit and water supplies across the line of contact between the conflicting sides were the main triggers of the humanitarian crisis.
