column1: Anti-govt demo held in Donetsk during peace talks DONETSK, Ukraine. 23 (Interfax) - An anti-government demonstration started outside the regional administration headquarters in Donetsk on Monday evening even as representatives of the Ukrainian government, eastern Ukrainian militias, Russia and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe were holding peace talks inside the building. The demonstrators were holding banners reading "Donbas is Russia and "Get fascism out of Donbas." Pensioners and women were joining in the demonstration. as

Anti-govt militia registered by admin of Ukraine city LVIV, Ukraine. Feb 19 (Interfax) - The Lviv city administration said on Wednesday that it had registered an anti-government militia. The charter of what is called "People's Self-Defense" had the approval of the city police chief, its commanders were appointed and its members listed, the administration said in a statement. People Self-Defense's activities would be coordinated by the administrations of Lviv districts, which would make up patrols from personnel from local companies and institutions. On Tuesday night and early on Wednesday, protesters captured the buildings of the Lviv region's police authority, Security Service branch, the regional prosecutor's office, and several district police stations. Subsequent reports said weapons and ammunition had disappeared from police and law enforcement buildings seized by protesters. Protesters also stopped Interior Forces troops from leaving one of their bases, threw several Molotov cocktails at one of the buildings at the base and at its checkpoint, setting off a fire in which the checkpoint burned down and an administrative building was seriously damaged. as

Any Western demands on Ukraine are currently inappropriate - Russian diplomat MOSCOW. Feb 20 (Interfax) - Russian Deputy Foreign Minister and State Secretary Grigory Karasin believes that it is inappropriate to put forth any demands on Ukraine at the moment. "It is difficult for me to comment on the remarks of the French minister. I have not seen them yet. But the word "demand" is hardly appropriate in this situation," Karasin told Interfax over the phone from Kyiv, when commenting on French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius's statement that the European Union would soon demand that the Ukrainian authorities call new elections. tm cm

Astakhov asks Ukrainian president for corridor to evacuate children from southeast regions MOSCOW. June 3 (Interfax) - Russian Presidential Children's Rights Ombudsman Pavel Astakhov has asked Ukrainian President Elect Petro Poroshenko to meet international commitments and to open a humanitarian corridor for refugees. "The president elect should pay attention to the Ukrainian fulfillment of the commitments it undertook as a UN member country," Astakhov told reporters on Tuesday. Russia is ready to admit about 90,000 Ukrainian orphans, he said. "We are quite capable of admitting orphans from southeastern Ukraine, all orphans from boarding schools," Astakhov said, adding that the absence of humanitarian corridors hindered that project. "How can you preach European values and disregard your commitments at the same time?" Astakhov said indignantly. Ukrainian border guards stopped a bus of underage refugees on the border with Russia on Saturday. The children had to leave Ukraine on foot. Te

Astakhov: Some 70,000 schoolchildren in DPR, LPR need textbooks, stationery MOSCOW. April 8 (Interfax) - Russian presidential children's rights ombudsman Pavel Astakhov has announced the collection of stationery and textbooks for Donbas children who are going to school this year and fund-raising campaign to raise money to rebuild schools and kindergartens in Donbas. "We need to equip some 70,000 schoolchildren [in Donbas] this year, including 50,000 children in the DPR and 20,000 in the LPR. They should study, they should have schools, not basements," Astakhov told a press conference on Wednesday. Astakhov said the action is being conducted by a non-commercial organization Association of Children's Rights Ombudsmen, which consist of children's ombudsmen in the Russian regions. Astakhov also said universities can join the action to equip the children of southeastern Ukraine who are going to school ion the initiative of Russian Education and Science Minister Dmitry Livanov. "Education and Science Minister Dmitry Livanov has suggested involving students in this action," Astakhov said. Astakhov said he is hoping that Russians will be able to collect the needed number of textbooks, stationery, schoolbags and other things school students need. He said the total weight of the "packages" may exceed 500 tonnes. He said that Russia is also raising funds for the rebuilding of a school in the DPR and a kindergarten in the LPR. The bank accounts for this fundraiser are stated on Astakhov's official website. av cy

AZERBAIJAN Azeri president urges intl community to step up Karabakh settlement Azeri President Ilham Aliyev urged the international community and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to work more actively to settle the Armenian-Azeri conflict peacefully. "I hope that the international community and the OSCE will work more actively on this issue in order to restore international law and historical justice, and to allow Azerbaijan to start restoration work after the liberation of the occupied territory," Aliyev said on Monday after talks with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's Chairman-in-Office, Swiss President Didier Burkhalter. Aliyev said that Nagorno Karabakh is Azerbaijan's historical integral part. He also said that the UN Security Council passed four resolutions demanding Armenian troops' immediate and unconditional withdrawal from the occupied Azeri territory. "Despite repeated statements made by the presidents of the states co-chairing the OSCE Minsk Group that the status quo is unacceptable, Armenia wants to perpetuate it. If the status quo is to be changed Armenia must start pulling out its troops," Aliyev said. Necessity has arisen to hold one more meeting between the presidents of Azerbaijan and Armenia within the framework of the talks on the peaceful settlement of the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, the Organization for Security and Cooperatiion in Europe's Chairman-in-Office, Swiss President Didier Burkhalter said. Burkhalter said, while making a joint statement with Azeri President Ilham Aliyev following bilateral talks on Monday, that the goal of his arrival in Baku was to hear different views and, possibly, to find ways of ensuring progress in the negotiating process. He also said that his attitude to the settlement of the Armenian-Azeri conflict as the OSCE's chairman-in-office, is obvious. Consistent steps should be made towards peace, he said. This means, he continued, that two main things should be done. First, dialogue should be intensified, he said. Dialogue was underway already, but necessity has arisen to hold a new meeting between the Azeri and Armenian presidents, Burkhalter said. A proposal is on the agenda to organize such a meeting in Paris, he said. The OSCE supports this idea and wants the meeting to be held in the near future, Burkhalter said, adding that the meeting must become the starting point for a new phase in the talks. On the other hand, it could be a structured negotiating process leading to a peace agreement, he said. This negotiating process must proceed on the basis of the model principles, Burkhalter said. The second thing to be done is to strengthen the ceasefire regime, he said. The mechanism of investigating incidents, approved by all the parties in the past, but never implemented, remains the most important issue, he said. Burkhalter said that Switzerland is ready to assist the peaceful negotiating process for the sake of settling the Armenian-Azeri conflict. Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has reaffirmed his country's commitment to inter-religious peace. "We will always be reliable neighbors, partners and friends to all people, whatever their religion and whatever church they choose," Lukashenko told the attendees of the European Christian Orthodox-Catholic Forum titled, "Religion and cultural diversity: challenges to Christian churches in Europe," in Minsk on Tuesday. "I want to reassure you that in this respect you will never have any grievances against the Belarusian people and state," the president stressed. He also said that his meeting with the forum attendees "obliges me and the whole of Belarusian people to approach the question of preserving inter-religious peace and national accord with even greater diligence and responsibility." "Belarus is unique in that its history is not darkened by religious wars and inter-ethnic conflicts," Lukashenko said. "We caringly preserve and pass from generation to generation the good traditions of our ancestors: mutual understanding, tolerance, compassion, respect for labor, peacefulness and patriotism," he said. "The Orthodox Christianity and Catholicism have historically shaped the mentality and national character of the Belarusians. And today the Christian faith remains an integral part of the worldview and spiritual life for a majority of our citizens," Lukashenko said. He said in his view, the European Christian Orthodox-Catholic Forum "must foster stronger cooperation between people of various faiths and views and help them find common ground through discussion and fruitful dialogue." "One must not forget that the present-day world sees an ever increasing number of hotbeds of tensions and war conflict zones which bring enormous suffering to people," the president said. This is why all nations must work together to ensure a peaceful future for humankind, Lukashenko said. "But such work is only possible with active and concerted efforts of both the authorities and public institutions, and first and foremost religious organizations," he said. President Giorgi Margelashvili will attend the inauguration ceremony of Ukrainian president-elect Petro Poroshenko in Kyiv on June 7. Margelashvili received an invitation to Poroshenko's inauguration ceremony as early as May 27, Georgian media said on Tuesday citing the Georgian presidential administration. In his telephone conversation with Poroshenko on May 27 Margelashvili congratulated him on winning the election and said the success of the elected Ukrainian counterpart should bring stability to Ukraine, according to the Georgian president's press office. Moscow interferes in Abkhazia's affairs and in the affairs of Georgians residing there, Georgian President Giorgi Margvelashvili said. "We are watching closely the events in Abkhazia as it is occupied territory where our citizens reside, whose interests we are not able to defend," Margvelashvili said at a news conference joint with Swiss President Didier Burkhalter on Tuesday. "It is absolutely evident that Russia interferes openly in the life of our country and lives of our citizens," he said. "The issues of Abkhazia, Tskhinval region and Crimea should be a constant priority at international talks and international agenda," Margvelashvili said. Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev has arrived in Bodrum where he will take part in the 4th Summit of the Cooperation Council of Turkic Speaking States, the president's press office says in a Tuesday press release. In addition to the Summit, Nazarbayev will hold bilateral meetings with heads of the Council member-states, according to the press release. Kazakh President Nursultan Nazarbayev has signed a decree organizing a "green economy" council, the president's press office says in a press release. The new council is aimed to support the transition to the "green economy" in pursuance of Kazakhstan's green economy concept. The council will be led by the prime minister of Kazakhstan. The Ministry of Environment and Water Resources is designated as executing agency. The council will to organize working groups to deal with specific issues such as financial and investment policy, water resources management, agriculture development, energy saving and development, waste management, air pollution reduction, ecosystem management and others. Kyrgyz Deputy Prime Minister Abdyrakhman Mamataliyev and UK Ambassador to Bishkek Judith Margaret Farnworth have discussed the continuing fight against extremism and the possibility of signing a bilateral agreement permitting the extradition of convicted persons, the Kyrgyz government's press service told Interfax on Tuesday. "The meeting addressed ways to step up cooperation in combating terrorism, extremism and trafficking in humans, as well as cooperation in reforming the law enforcement services of our country," the press service said. "At the end of the meeting, the sides agreed to further bolster ties between the law enforcement agencies of the two countries," it said. Bishkek's plans to sign an extradition agreement with London can mainly be explained by the Kyrgyz authorities' plans to secure the return of former President Kurmanbek Bakiyev's son, Maxim, who has been accused by Bishkek of corruption, misappropriation, corporate raiding and other crimes. Maxim Bakiyev currently resides in the United Kingdom, where he has been given political refugee status. Russian President Vladimir Putin intends to issue instructions to his secretariat and the government on providing assistance to refugees from the southeastern regions of Ukraine and residents of Crimea experiencing difficulties with acquiring Russian citizenship due to problems with residency registration. Human Rights Commissioner Ella Pamfilova briefed Putin on problems that refugees and Crimean residents are experiencing at a meeting on Tuesday. "I will instruct the presidential secretariat to help implement all of your proposals along with the government," Putin said. Pamfilova said the number of refugees from southeastern regions of Ukraine has begun to grow, but not all Russian regions are providing assistance to them. "According to my information, the inflow of people from the east [of Ukraine] has begun to grow, and not only to the border districts [of Russia], but some of them have even reached Yekaterinburg. In some places, the authorities are reacting promptly, but in others absolutely indifferently. People are helping, but there's no system. It seems to me that we need an urgent systemic program as to how these people should be received, provided with jobs, and so on," she said. Pamfilova said also with reference to experts whom she said she trusted that about 50,000 people in Crimea and Sevastopol want to acquire Russian citizenship but cannot do so as they did not have permanent residential registration in that territory. ***Russian Human Rights Commissioner Ella Pamfilova is astounded by the Western countries' reaction to the humanitarian situation in the southeastern part of Ukraine and calls for setting up a humanitarian corridor for refugees there. "A humanitarian corridor is needed there [in the combat area]. I am simply astounded by seeing how a lot of our authoritative international organizations, the entire illuminated Western world, have suddenly become simultaneously deaf, mute, and blind and don't see that there is a truly horrible tragedy there with children and people wanting to flee areas fired upon," Pamfilova said at a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday. Russian President Vladimir Putin and German Chancellor Angela Merkel have talked on the telephone, the Kremlin press office said in a statement on Tuesday. "Ahead of the bilateral meeting in Normandy on June 6, 2014, the leaders have exchanged opinions on the situation in Ukraine. The Russian president and German chancellor have supported developing coordinated measures to de-escalate the crisis," the document said. The negotiations between Russia, the European Union and Ukraine on Russian gas supplies have been discussed as well, the press office said. A meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and British Prime Minister David Cameron in Normandy on Friday has been accorded, Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters. "The meeting between Putin and Cameron was accorded for Friday. Ready to discuss any issues," Peskov said. When asked to elaborate whether the Ukrainian topic will be raised at the meeting, Peskov said that the Russian president was ready to discuss any issues. In the framework of celebrations marking the 70th anniversary of the Allied troops landing in Normandy, Putin "will have many contacts, as they say, on foot," Peskov said. Peskov announced that the Russian president and British prime minister would discuss Ukraine in a comprehensive way. "We will make a point that the continuing punitive operation in southeastern Ukraine is unacceptable," he said in an interview with the Russian News Service. The Russian and British leaders will not discuss the negative comments regarding the Russian president, reportedly made by Prince Charles, he also said. "This is far from being the key issue," Peskov said, adding that there are far important themes to be discussed. Russian President Vladimir Putin has held a meeting with former French leader Nicolas Sarkozy in Russia's Black Sea resort of Sochi, Putin's press secretary Dmitry Peskov told Interfax. "I confirm this. Indeed, such a meeting took place in Sochi. It was a private one," Peskov said. The meeting was first reported by French media. While discussing the gas issue with Ukraine, Russian negotiators show flexibility but it is evident that the issue of debt for which was gas supplied be resolved, Russian President Vladimir Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters. "In any case first the debt issue should be resolved," Peskov said. At the same time, "one thing is evident - in this case Russian negotiators show flexibility and interest in searching for a solution," he said. "As it is known, for now the sum, which came in the settlement of the debt, is far from covering the entire debt," Peskov said. When asked whether the discussion of gas topics could be brought to a different level, the spokesman said that "everything should be done stage-by-stage" but first the debt issue should be resolved. "A lot will depend on Ukraine," Peskov said. The United States is set to support Tajikistan in the suppression of terrorism, extremism and drug trafficking from Afghanistan, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Nisha Desai Biswal said on Tuesday. She told Tajik President Emomali Rahmon the United States would back the Tajik border forces and other agencies fighting terrorism, extremism, drug trafficking and other transnational crimes. Biswal is paying a working visit to Dushanbe. She noted an important role of Tajikistan in the provision of peace and stability in Central Asia and Tajik support for international forces seeking to achieve sociopolitical stability in Afghanistan and thanked President Rahmon and the people of Tajikistan on behalf of her country. Tajikistan provided the United States and the NATO antiterrorism coalition in Afghanistan with air and ground routes for non-military cargo transit. A French air force unit supporting NATO operations in Afghanistan was stationed at the Dushanbe International Airport from 2001 to June 2013. Tajikistan has the longest border with Afghanistan, 1,344 kilometers, amongst CIS countries. Tajik law enforcers annually impound tonnes of Afghan drugs in transit to Russia, Eastern and Western Europe. Some experts fear security levels in Afghanistan may reduce with the pullout of NATO forces and attempts of incursions from Afghanistan into CIS countries may grow frequent. The United States pledges to help Tajikistan's border reinforcement. The Tajik presidential press service said the sides also discussed bilateral relations and cooperation in politics, regional, security, economy, trade, investment, science and technology. The Ukrainian Central Election Commission announced on Monday that Petro Poroshenko, an independent parliamentary deputy, was elected president in the early presidential elections on May 25. According to the Central Election Commission's report, signed by all of its 15 members on Monday, Poroshenko won 54.7% (9,857, 308) of the ballots cast by voters. Batkivshchina leader Yulia Timoshenko mustered 12.81% of the votes (2,310,050). Radical Party leader Oleh Lyashko won 8.32% or 1,500,377 votes, Civil Position Party leader Anatoliy Hrytsenko 5.48% (989,029), parliamentary deputy Serhiy Tihipko 5.23% (943,430), ex-head of the Kharkiv regional state administration Mykhailo Dobkin 3.03% (546,138). Head of the All-Ukrainian Jewish Congress Vadym Rabinovych got 2.25% of the votes (406,301), doctor Olha Bohomolets 1.91% (345,384), Communist Party leader Petro Symonenko 1.51% (272,723), Svoboda party leader Oleh Tyahnybok 1.16% (210, 476), Rights Sector leader Dmytro Yarosh 0.70% (127,772). The other candidates got less than 0.5% of the votes. The results of the early presidential elections held on May 25 approved by the Central Election Commission, which declared Petro Poroshenko the winner, were posted in the official Holos Ukrainy and Uriadovy Kurier newspapers on Tuesday. The electronic versions of the new issues of the newspapers appeared in the early hours of June 3 on their Web sites. As reported, the CEC announced on Monday that Petro Poroshenko, an independent parliamentary deputy, was elected president in the early presidential elections on May 25. Poroshenko garnered 54.7% (9.86 million) of the ballots cast by voters. Ukrainian President Elect Petro Poroshenko will take the oath of office at the parliament on June 7. The motion gained support of 300 out of 347 deputies on Tuesday. "The Verkhovna Rada resolves to hold a ceremony in which the Ukrainian president elect will take the oath of allegiance to the people of Ukraine at the session hall at 10 a.m. on June 7, 2014," the resolution runs. The Ukrainian Foreign Ministry has said that about 20 heads of state and government have already confirmed their attendance of the inauguration ceremony of the Ukrainian president-elect, Petro Poroshenko, scheduled for June 7. "To date, we have received confirmations of attendance from around 20 foreign heads of state and government," Foreign Ministry spokesman Yevhen Perebyinis said at a briefing on Tuesday. This figure is not final since confirmations keep coming from foreign states, he said. In particular, attendance was confirmed by the presidents Bronislaw Komorowski of Poland, Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania, United States Vice President Joe Biden, Swiss Foreign Minister Didier Burkhalter, European Council President Herman van Rompuy, and OSCE (Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe) Secretary General Lamberto Zannier. Invitations have been sent to the heads of state of European Union, a number of European countries, the United States, Canada, the Caucasus countries, and senior officials from international organizations, Perebyinis aded. Ukrainian president-elect Petro Poroshenko has reassured European Council President Herman van Rompuy that Ukraine is ready to sign an association agreement with the European Union any time once "the European side completes the necessary technical and legal arrangements." Poroshenko made this claim in a telephone conversation with van Rompuy on Tuesday, Poroshenko's spokesperson said. "The EC president reaffirmed his personal readiness to assist in resolving this issue," the spokesperson said. The parties also agreed to continue the dialogue in France during the June 6 festivities on the occasion of the 70th anniversary of the Normandy landings. Ukraine insists on keeping the price of $268.5 per 1,000 cubic meters of Russian natural gas, but it is prepared to agree to a certain increase of this price as part of a possible compromise to be reached with Russia, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk has said. "It [the gas price] may deviate somewhat from the price of $268.5," he said in parliament on Tuesday. Yatseniuk, however, declined to say exactly how the new figure could differ from today's price, saying that his remarks may influence the ongoing trilateral talks. Ukraine needs to purchase 7 billion cubic meters more gas to ensure the next heating season, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said in Verkhovna Rada on Tuesday. "When we [the new government] came, underground storage facilities had 5 billion cubic meters gas - this is virtually buffer gas, which is impossible to lift. Underground storage facilities currently have 12 billion cubic meters gas. It is necessary to buy at least 7 billion cubic meters more to get through the heating season," Yatseniuk said. It has been reported that in 2013 Ukraine pumped 11.635 billion cubic meters of gas into underground storage facilities. In 2013 withdraws of natural gas exceeded pumping 8.9% (1.03 billion cubic meters) and amounted to 12.665 billion cubic meters, in particular 12.328 billion cubic meters were withdrawn from Ukrtransgaz underground storage facilities and 0.337 billion cubic meters from Chornomornaftogaz or Black Sea Gas. Ukraine has 13 underground gas storage facilities with a total capacity of around 32 billion cubic meters. Ukrtransgaz operates 12 storage facilities (31 billion cubic meters) and Chornomornaftogaz the other one (1 billion cubic meters). Since Crimea's accession to Russia, Naftogaz Ukrainy does not receive information from Chornomornaftogaz on storage, extraction, transportation and use of natural gas, oil and condensate from March 14, 2014. The Ukrainian government intends to file a lawsuit exceeding one trillion hryvnia for damage sustained as a result of Crimea's accession to Russia, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said. "As to the lawsuits: Ukraine has started this process, I would like to inform you that the Prosecutor General's Office has started the investigation and in the framework of the criminal case the Ukrainian government files a lawsuit exceeding one trillion hryvnia," Yatseniuk said in Verkhovna Rada on Tuesday when asked about lawsuits over Russia's actions in Crimea and damage inflicted to Ukraine. Ukraine will create public joint-stock companies Ukrainian GTS and Ukrainian Gas Storage Facilities on the basis of Ukrtransgaz, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said in the parliament on Tuesday. "The Ukrainian government will create public joint-stock company Ukrainian gas transport system, which will only transport gas under EC directives and according to our liabilities from Ukraine's membership in the Energy Community," he said. "We're also creating public joint-stock company Ukrainian Gas Storage Facilities. This will be only the operator that will work with all entities in the area of storing and selling natural gas," he added. Yatseniuk said that Ukraine, as a member of the European Energy Charter and Energy Community, proposed that the point of accepting Russian natural gas is transferred to the Ukrainian-Russian border and the new agreements are signed. "As a part of this work we addressed Europe in public, as it is time to change the point of accepting Russian natural gas. Let me noted that now due to unclear reasons Russian gas is accepted by the European Union not on the Ukrainian-Russian border but on the EU-Ukraine border," he said. The premier said that Gazprom is involved in blackmailing by assigning different prices for natural gas for various EU companies. "We believe that jointly with Europe we should change the EU energy map, and this is not only in the interests of Ukraine. Gazprom is blackmailing Europe the same way. Gazprom and Russia are trying to offer a better contract to one companies and the worse contract to other companies," he added. Ukrtransgaz, whose 100% stake is held by Naftogaz Ukrainy, operates a system of trunk gas pipelines and 12 underground gas depots. The Ukrainian gas pipeline system's handling capacity is 288 billion cubic meters at the entrance and 178.5 billion cubic meters at the exit, including 142.5 billion cubic meters channeled to Europe and 3.5 billion cubic meters to Moldova. The building of coal-fuelled synthetic natural gas (SNG) and national gas liquid (NGL) plants in Ukraine planned by the previous government using Chinese funds secured by the state is inappropriate, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk has said. "The so-called coal gasification project has neither an economic basis nor technological basis," he said speaking in the parliament on Tuesday. As reported, Naftogaz Ukrainy in December 2012 signed a loan agreement with the China Development Bank Corporation on the attraction of government secured $3.656 billion to realize projects on the replacement of consumption of natural gas with coal. The credit line is opened for 19 years (2012-2031). Its value is $2.396 billion. Four years is given to prepare and agree the approved projects and the signing of individual credit agreements for a period of 15 years. The SNG plants will be built in Luhansk, Donetsk and Odesa regions using the oil company Shell's technologies, which have been tested in China. The implementation of the project for the construction of SNG plants will allow Ukraine to save up to 4 billion cubic meters of natural gas, sell 10 million tonnes of coal per year, and create more than 2,000 jobs. The terms of the start of the realization of the project has been postponed several times. The terms were again announced early 2014 when former Energy and Coal Industry Minister Eduard Stavytsky said that Ukraine would start building coal gasification plants in cooperation with China in September 2014. Compiled by Andrei Petrovsky, Galina Seregina ###

AZERBAIJAN Opposition in Azerbaijan withdraws from parliamentary race in protest The opposition National Council of Democratic Forces (NCDF) of Azerbaijan has decided not to run in the upcoming elections to parliament, the Milli Majlis (National Assembly). "There are not even half of the necessary preconditions for free and fair elections in the country. This is why the NCDF decides not to run in the imitation of elections and does not want to serve as a means of their legitimization," the NCDF said in a statement circulated in Baku on Thursday. The NCDF said of the motivation for its decision that the Azeri authorities had ignored the measures proposed by the opposition to make the elections and the country's governance system more democratic. The NCDF's core force, consolidating a number of political parties and movements, is the Azerbaijani Popular Front Party. Armenia intends to allow Russian citizens entry on Russian internal passports and without foreign travel passports. At a government meeting on Thursday, Armenian Prime Minister Ovik Abraamyan ordered State Migration Service Director Gagik Yeganyan to begin negotiations with Russian partners on this issue. "There is information that only 10% of Russian citizens have foreign travel passports. As members of the EEU, we need to begin working in this direction and find a solution to enable Russian citizens to visit Armenia on their internal passports. It will promote the development of tourism and will boost economic relations," Abraamyan told the parliament. Incumbent Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has been registered as a candidate to the post of president of Belarus. This decision was made by the Central Election Commission on Thursday, an Interfax correspondent has reported. Lukashenko is thus running for president for a fifth time. Sergei Gaidukevich, chairman of the Belarusian Liberal-Democratic Party, has also been registered as a presidential candidate. Gaidukevich is running for president for a fourth time: he received 2.48% of the votes (the least of all the candidates) in 2001 and 3.5% in 2006 (taking third place among the candidates). In the 2010 elections, Gaidukevich withdrew his candidacy after collecting signatures. Nikolai Ulakhovich, supreme ataman of the association Belarusian Cossacks, has also been registered as a presidential candidate. The Central Election Commission has also recognized the right of Tatyana Korotkevich, an activist of the civil campaign Speak the Truth!, to run in the elections. Being a country situated on the Asia-Europe crossroads, Georgia has proven its reliability as a transit route, Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili has said at the New Silk Road panel session of the World Economic Forum in Dalian, China, on Wednesday. The Georgian prime minister staunchly supported the New Silk Road concept, 'One Belt, One Road', and noted the role of Georgia as a transit country in its implementation, the prime minister's press service reported. "The goal of the Georgian government is to transform the country into a center of peace, logistics and trade, which is a historic mission of Georgia," Garibashvili said. "Concerning the Silk Road, Georgia can play a very significant role considering its strategic position. We have proven to be a reliable transit country for energy resources and transport, and we have an ambition to establish Georgia as a logistics center," Garibashvili said. The prime minister told the audience about plans to construct a new deep-water port in Anaklia on the Georgian Black Sea coast with an annual cargo handling capacity of 100 million tonnes. "This port will be constructed in seven steps, and American and Chinese companies are very enthusiastic about joining this project," Garibashvili said. Negotiations on the construction of roads, bridges and other infrastructures have begun, he said. "It is a matter of investing several billions of dollars in Georgia," the prime minister said. First Deputy Prime Minister of Kazakhstan Bakytzhan Sagintayev held a meeting that discussed transition to a "green economy", the prime minister's press office says in a Thursday statement. The meeting reviewed a draft INDC document (Intended nationally Determined Contributions) that regulates Kazakhstan's contribution to limitation and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in 2021-2030. The document says that the republic will limit and/or reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15% in 2021-2030 or by 25% by 2030 compared with 1990, according to the statement. In pursuance of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Kyoto Protocol, as well as the national concept of transition to a "green economy", Kazakhstan is working towards improvement of the energy efficiency at its industrial enterprises, introduction of renewable energy sources and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the statement says. In December this year, the governments of more than 190 nations will gather in Paris to discuss a possible new global agreement on climate change that is supposed to take over from Kyoto. As prerequisite to the new agreement, the nations should adopt their own documents on Intended Nationally Determined Contributions or INDCs. The Senate of the Parliament of Kazakhstan at the plenary session on Thursday ratified the Inter-American Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. Thus, the document is adopted by the Parliament as a whole and is sent to the President for signing. The Inter-American Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters was adopted in Nassau on May 23, 1992. The states parties shall render to one another mutual assistance in investigations, prosecutions, and proceedings that pertain to crimes over which the requesting state has jurisdiction at the time the assistance is requested. The assistance envisaged under this convention shall include the following Procedures among others: notification of rulings and judgments; taking of testimony or statements from persons; summoning of witnesses and expert witnesses to provide testimony; immobilization and sequestration of property, freezing of assets, and assistance in procedures related to seizures; searches or seizures; examination of objects and places; service of judicial documents; transmittal of documents, reports, information, and evidence; transfer of detained persons for the purpose of this convention; and any other procedure provided there is an agreement between the requesting state and the requested state. The upper chamber of the Kazakh parliament, the Senate, approved Thursday the Draft Laws on Ratification of the Treaties on Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters with Romania and Bulgaria. The Agreement between Kazakhstan and Bulgaria on assistance in criminal matters was signed on 14 November 2014 in Sofia. The agreement between the Republic of Kazakhstan and Romania was committed in Bucharest on November 14, 2014. In accordance with the provisions of the contract, the parties shall provide mutual assistance to each other in the field of investigation, prosecution and prevention of criminal offenses, and in other proceedings related to criminal matters. Assistance may include obtaining testimony or statements; authentication of documents and material evidence; locating or identifying persons and objects, transferring persons in custody for testimony or other assistance in accordance with the contract, conducting searches and seizures and confiscation of assets. The Central Authority of the requested State may refuse assistance if the request relates to a military offense that is not a crime under general criminal law, if it poses a threat to the sovereignty, security, public order or other essential interests of the requested State, or the request does not comply with the provisions of the contract. Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev will attend the summit of the heads of state of the Cooperation Council of Turkic Speaking States, which will be held in Astana on September 11, the presidential administration told Interfax on Thursday. The source told Interfax that Atambayev is also expected to attend a session of the CSTO Collective Security Council in Dushanbe on September 14-15. The Cooperation Council of Turkic Speaking States comprises of Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan and Turkey. Moldovan Prime Minister Valeriu Strelet said at a meeting with representatives of the so-called Council of the Grand National Assembly that the government would not resign. "We are prepared to discuss all issues and the protesters' demands, except for the government's resignation. If you agree to discuss people's problems, we are prepared for this. We are prepared to develop a road map together so as to move forward and resolve the people's problems together," he said. "The government's resignation would destabilize the situation, which cannot be allowed in any circumstances," he said. "There are too many forces interested in destabilizing the situation and turning the country away from its strategic course towards European integration. If you agree with this, we are ready to discuss this and set up a joint commission that would address all these problems. I repeat: discuss all issues except for the government's resignation," Strelet said. Andrei Nastase, the chairman of the Council of the Grand National Assembly, said, "This is the fourth protest but the authorities haven't done anything to satisfy at least part of the protesters' demands." "We don't want to discuss problems but to make sure that they are resolved. This is within the authorities' powers. If the authorities have not done this, then they must go. We will insist on meeting our demands, that is, the people's demands voiced at a rally of 100,000," Nastase said. Moldovan Prime Minister Valeriu Strelet, who intends to meet with protesters on Thursday, has given an account of his work and made public the government's plans for the future. "The government was set up on July 30, and so we've been working for 42 days. I don't see reasons for its resignation as the government is working efficiently. We have resolved a lot of problems inherited [from the previous administration] in this time. We have held six sessions, considered over 130 issues and held four sessions of the Financial Stability Committee. This is all aimed at improving the people's lives," Strelet said at a press conference on Thursday. "The government's actions create a platform and preconditions for resolving the problems that society is facing," he said. "I don't see reasons for the government, which has just started working, to resign. We know for sure that most of the people want the government to work rather than resign. We will continue to work. I believe that our report on the first hundred days of the government's work will be much fuller and more informative," he said. He confirmed that a meeting with representatives of the so-called Grand National Assembly council set up by the participants of the protest on the central square of Chisinau was scheduled for Thursday morning. "We will discuss their demands together and try to find solutions to problems in a way that meets the people's interests together," he said. Russian President Vladimir Putin, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Francois Hollande and Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko will have agreed to meet in Paris on October 2 in a telephone conversation on Wednesday night, the Russian presidential press service reported. "It was agreed to continue active work in the 'Normandy format', which includes the holding of negotiations at the level of foreign ministers in Berlin on September 12, as well as a personal meeting of the leaders of Russia, Germany, France and Ukraine in Paris on October 2," the press service said in a statement. The parties also discussed the settlement of the crisis in southeastern Ukraine given the results of meetings of the Trilateral Contact Group for Ukraine and its working groups in Minsk on September 8, it said. Russian President Vladimir Putin has stated the need for the finetuning of a full-fledged dialog between representatives of Kyiv and southeastern Ukraine in a telephone conversation with the 'Normandy four' leaders on Wednesday night, the Kremlin press service reported. "Particular attention given to the implementation of the political provisions of the Minsk agreements, primarily the holding of the constitutional reform in Ukraine, including the formalization of the special status for Donbas regions, as well as the organization of local elections and the adoption of the amnesty law. In this regard, Putin has again stressed the need for the fastest possible fine-tuning of a full-fledged direct dialog between Kyiv authorities and representatives of southeastern Ukraine," the press service said in a statement. The parties agreed to continue active work in the "Normandy format' which include a meeting of foreign ministers in Berlin on September 12, as well as a personal meeting of the leaders of Russia, Germany, France and Ukraine in Paris on October 2. The leaders of 'Normandy format' countries, Russia, France, Germany and Ukraine, have welcomed the ceasefire in southeastern Ukraine, the Kremlin press service said. "The leaders welcomed the ceasefire that recently has been established in southeastern Ukraine. The withdrawal of mortar under 120 mm and artillery under 100 mm would meet the tasks of the further de-escalation of the situation and the creation of perquisites for the economic restoration of Donbas regions," a statement issued by the Kremlin press service on Wednesday night reads. Meanwhile, according to the Ukrainian presidential press service, the arms withdrawal process should be monitored by SMM OSCE inspectors, "in particular, through the creation of permanently active points along the contact line." Russia is willing to share its unique experience in conducting rescue and humanitarian operations in the world, and it expects to analyze the similar experience of its foreign partners, Russian President Vladimir Putin said. "Manmade and natural disasters have been increasingly trans-frontier in their nature, and therefore it is extremely important to promote regional and global interaction in every possible way to prevent emergency situations and overcome their aftermath," Putin said in a greeting message to the participants in and guests of an international forum of firefighters and rescuers, published on the Kremlin website. Russia has always sought to consolidate the efforts of countries and organizations in this field, Putin said. "We have a very rich experience in conducting rescue and humanitarian operations across the world. We are willing to share our unique achievements and provide assistance in personnel training. In turn, we expect to have the opportunity to thoroughly analyze the methods applied by our foreign partners," he said. Putin said he was sure that the forum would make a significant contribution to resolving relevant problems related to efforts against modern challenges and threats, and it would strengthen partnerships. Russian President Vladimir Putin will highlight the Syria problem and the fight against ISIL, the same as a majority of other speakers at the UN General Assembly session, Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Thursday. "Apparently, most speeches delivered from the General Assembly rostrum will give much attention to Syrian affairs and the ISIL problem. One can presume with a high degree of probability that President Putin will also dwell on this problem," Peskov said. Russian President Vladimir Putin's meeting with U.S. President Barack Obama on the sidelines of the upcoming UN General Assembly has not been planned so far, Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov said. "No such meeting is on the schedule so far," Peskov told journalists on Thursday. "Certainly, he sees how the schedules coincide and when some initiative arises, then there'll be a more concrete analysis," he said. Asked whether the White House has made proposals on a meeting between the two leaders, Peskov said, "No, there have been no such proposals so far." Different options for Putin's meetings are being explored now, which includes both "separate bilateral meetings and the use of various protocol and other events within the General Assembly framework for the president to be able to talk with the heads of other states on the General Assembly's sidelines," Peskov said. Costs of taking in and accommodating refugees from the Middle East should be covered by the countries related to the destabilization in the refugees' home states, the Kremlin said. "We expected most expenditures to be covered by the countries related to what had led to such a catastrophic situation in certain Maghreb countries in the Middle East," Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Thursday. Speaking about Russia's part in the refugee assistance program, the Kremlin representative said: "The issue is hardly topical for the Russian Federation." Peskov did not say which countries he was implying. "I'd rather not go into details," he said. Russia is recording refugees' attempts to use its territory, including for moving to other countries, and the principal problem is that Islamic State fighters might be getting to Europe together with true refugees, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "It's true that attempts to use Russian territory have been recorded. In addition, as it's been said on numerous occasions, the greater danger is that, unfortunately, people from the so-called Islamic State, who have to do with combat actions, terrorist attacks, and killings, have been detected among the refugees in Europe, which the European authorities have confirmed," Peskov told journalists. "This is a huge danger," he said. Russia's territory has been used both for settling in the country and for moving further to other states, he said. The issue of quotas on refugees is not on Russia's agenda: it is necessary to deal with the causes of this situation rather than its consequences, the Kremlin has said. "It is impossible to resolve this problem on the external perimeter. One should not fight the consequences but rather address the cause that triggers the exodus of these people from their homeland," Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Thursday. In his words, quotas on refugees are not topical for Russia. "This is not on the table, this is not a topical matter," Peskov said. The press secretary said he knew nothing about the European partners' request to the Russian president to ponder this issue. "I know nothing about that, no. This is not an item on our agenda," Peskov said. Russia is providing assistance to the Syrian authorities in combating the Islamic State as they are the only force opposing this movement, says Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov. "Russia has stressed repeatedly that the threat emanating from the ISIL and from the ongoing expansion of the territory it influences and the territory it controls is absolutely obvious. The Syrian authorities are the only force that can offer resistance to this movement," Peskov said. "There are simply no other organized and efficient forces there," Peskov said. Therefore, naturally, "Russia sees it as its mission to provide assistance to Syrian authorities in combating this dangerous phenomenon," he said. "This is exactly what's happening. This is what both the president and the foreign minister said. This is what explains the Russian Federation's attempts to provide the necessary assistance," Peskov said. Russian military specialists are helping Syrian counterparts to handle equipment, they do not participate in military actions, Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "Russia considers its task to give support to the Syrian authorities in the struggle against dangerous phenomenon such as the so-called Islamic State," Peskov told reporters on Thursday. "This is exactly what explains Russia's attempts to provide necessary relevant aid," he said. As for the information about the alleged participation of Russian Armed Forces in combat actions in Syria, the spokesman said: "The threat coming from ISIL and constant attempts to expand the area of influence which ISIL is controlling is absolutely obvious. And the only force which is resisting this advancement is the Syrian armed forces. There are just no other well-organized and viable forces." Peskov recalled Russian President Vladimir Putin's previous statements on this issue. "Nothing has changed for this period of time. There is no point in repeating anything," he said. Asked earlier in Vladivostok about the possible participation of Russian servicemen in the events in Syria, the Russian president said that different variants were considered but it is premature to talk about this. In reply to a question about confirming or rejecting the reports of some media outlets on the direct participation of Russian servicemen in the armed conflict in Syria, the presidential spokesman said that the Russian Foreign Ministry has already commented on this issue: "All was explained. There are military specialists there who are engaged in the maintenance of special property, which is delivered to Syria absolutely according to international law," Peskov said. Russia is interested in retaining its positions on the global weapons market, Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said. "Our revenues from exports [of weapons and military hardware] are significant, and this is a very considerable factor in forming our budget. The existing contract portfolio amounts to $40 billion, and we are certainly interested in increasing its volume," Medvedev said at the official unveiling ceremony of Russia Arms Expo 2015, the 10th international exhibition of arms, military equipment and ammunition. Medvedev pointed out that some specimens displayed at the exhibition have no analogues and were manufactured based on Russian know-how. The 2015 exhibition has seen a record number of visitors, among them delegations from more than 60 countries and representatives of more than 160 Russian and foreign companies, including from Turkey, South Korea, France, Jordan, and others, he said. "We cannot but be delighted by such a representative competition of foreign companies, which is an indicator of interest displayed in our exhibition and our weaponry specimens," Medvedev said. The course towards substitution of imported technologies in the defense sector is not a one-time affair, it is long-term, Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev has said. "It will not be altered in our plans to fulfill the state armament program and to develop our military-technological cooperation," Medvedev said at the opening ceremony of the tenth international arms show, Russia Arms Expo 2015. Modernization and technological re-arming of defense plants are included in the Russian government's priorities in the period until 2018, he said. "This work is in full swing, and it will be continued despite the not so easy budget situation," Medvedev said. President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko has instructed Cabinet of Ministers, Central Election Commission (CEC) and local self-government authorities to ensure a proper organization and holding of the local elections on October 25, 2015. The respective decree No. N538/2015 as of September 9, 2015, which was signed by the president at a meeting of the Regional Development Council, was posted on president's official website. President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko has thanked Italy for ratifying the Ukraine-EU Association Agreement with the European Union. "I'm grateful to Italy for the ratification of Ukraine-EU Association Agreement," Poroshenko wrote on Twitter page. As reported on Wednesday, the Upper House of the Parliament of Italy (Senate) ratified the Association Agreement between Ukraine and European Union. Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk has proposed setting up a new platform in the European Union to support reforms in Ukraine, which would include countries that recently became EU members after implementing reforms. "It would be a very good idea if the EU formed a new and strong mechanism to support reforms in Ukraine. This would be an association of all countries that have carried out reforms and become EU members over the past 20 years," Yatseniuk said at a joint press conference with Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in Kyiv on Thursday. Such countries as Slovakia and Poland understand Ukraine's problems better than anyone else, Yatseniuk said. "Surely, this platform should include Slovakia and Poland, and we talked about this with the premier. And everyone could be practically involved, like Slovakia, in helping Ukraine," he said. Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said he is hoping that the European Union will not take into account issues relating to the new wave of migration to Europe when deciding on the issue of granting a visa-free regime to Ukraine. "The liberalization of the visa regime for Ukrainians, to be more precise a visa-free regime for Ukrainians, is another real result of European integration that can be achieved. We are now going through technical missions with the EU and I hope that the decision on granting a visa-free regime to Ukraine will not have political aspects, including those related to the wave of migration to the EU," he said at a press conference he gave jointly with Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fiko in Bratislava on Thursday. Yatseniuk emphasized that Ukraine understands the program of migration that has arisen in Europe very well. "Because the problem of migration is now estimated at thousands of people in Europe. It is due to conflict zones, to instability. The war is the reason why there are now 1.5 million temporarily displaced people in Ukraine," he said. The prime minister said this issue leads to huge budget losses associated with the cost of helping these people and their adaptation. "We should look for answers to these questions together," Yatseniuk said. Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk has said that the Nord Stream II gas pipeline project goes against the European gas market's declared principles, would cause significant damage to Ukraine and Slovakia, and would perpetuate the European Union's energy dependence on Russia, and therefore Kyiv expects the European Commission to block this project. "I hope that not only will the European Commission take note of this, but that the right decision will also be made, which would meet not the price but European values," Yatseniuk said at a joint press conference with Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in Bratislava on Thursday. It was reported earlier that the shareholders in the company that would build the third and fourth lines of the Nord Stream gas pipeline had signed an agreement in Moscow on September 4. The new consortium includes six participants, i.e. Gazprom, E.ON, BASF/Wintershall, OMV, Engie, and Shell. Gazprom said in a statement that the joint project company New European Pipeline AG would deliver the project. Gazprom will own 51% of the company, E.ON, Shell, OMV and BASF/Wintershall will have 10% each and Engie 9%. Nord Stream II will add two lines, whose combined capacity should reach 55 billion cubic meters, to the existing pipeline that transports gas along the Baltic Sea floor from Russia to the German coast. The construction of the second phase of the Nord Stream gas pipeline would deprive Ukraine of the opportunity to pump 140 billion cubic meters of Russian natural gas to the European Union and to make $2 billion on this annually, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said at a joint press conference with Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in Bratislava on Thursday. "What does the Nord Stream II construction mean for Ukraine? First, it absolutely excludes Ukraine from transit supplies to the European Union. Second, it's the loss of $2 billion in revenues that we get for the transit and safe shipment of gas to the European Union. And third, it's simply unjust both to our European partners and to Ukraine," he said. The Nord Stream II construction would monopolize the routes of gas transportation to the European Union and would increase the price for the end users, he said. If Nord Stream II is built, the European Union will lose the opportunity to receive Russian gas directly along the shortest route across Ukraine, Yatseniuk said. This project would also deprive Slovakia of $800-million revenues from gas transportation, he said. After the first phase of the Nord Stream gas pipeline was built, Ukraine has lost $1.5 billion in revenues from gas transportation, Yatseniuk said. "And this hasn't brought about any energy independence for the European Union: What's the difference where you get gas as long as you have the same supplier?" he said. It was reported earlier that the Nord Stream II consortium comprises six participants, i.e. Gazprom, E.ON, BASF/Wintershall, OMV, Engie, and Shell. Nord Stream II will add two lines, whose combined capacity should reach 55 billion cubic meters, to the existing pipeline that transports gas along the Baltic Sea floor from Russia to Germany. Ukraine has increased the utilization of the Vojany-Uzhgorod gas pipeline, through which it receives gas from Slovakia, to 100%, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said at a news briefing with Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in Bratislava on Thursday. "Over the past several weeks, we have significantly increased the volume of gas purchases and have virtually reached the 100% capacity [of the Vojany-Uzhgorod gas pipeline utilization]," Yatseniuk said. "The volume of gas purchases depends on several factors. The first factor is internal consumption (naturally, it is significantly lower in a summer period). The second is the price for gas. The difference in prices between that at the beginning of the year and the current moment is already $30 per 1,000 cubic meters. Taking into account these two factors, we have decided now to increase the volume of the reverse flow from Slovakia to the maximum and use it 100%," he said. It was reported earlier that Ukraine has the opportunity to import gas from the EU through the Vojany-Uzhgorod pipeline, daily capacity of which is 40 billion to 41 billion cubic meters of gas. In May-July 2015, Ukraine utilized only 45% to 60% of this pipeline's capacity. Ukraine wants to become a part of the new European gas hub being created by Poland, Romania, Hungary and Slovakia, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk said after a meeting with Poland's Prime Minister Ewa Kopacz on Wednesday in Warsaw. "Ukraine wants to become a part of the large gas energy hub being created by Poland, Romania, Hungary and Slovakia. This means that gas flows between our countries would be free, and we will be ble to freely trade, without any restrictions," the press service of the government reported, citing Yatseniuk. He also said that Ukraine and Poland have signed a memorandum on construction of a gas interconnection pipeline between the two countries. He said that construction of the Ukrainian section of the gas pipeline would cost around $160 million. "We're waiting for calculations from Polish friends," he said. Compiled by Maya Sedova Galina Seregina

Back before the 27 May incident on the Russian-Ukrainian border, your Novyye Izvestiya correspondent talked with Igor Strelkov, commander of the volunteer militia in Slovyansk. [Barkov] What forces does the volunteer militia in Slovyansk have? [Strelkov] We have a small quantity of weapons. Until recently we had small stocks of ammunition for prolonged fighting. The fighting with the enemy forces is in the proportion of 10 to one, with 10 National Guard combatants to one self-defense volunteer militiaman. In terms of weapons the proportion is 30-50 to one. We have a few trophy armored vehicles and a cannon. [Barkov] Where do you weapons come from? [Strelkov] We are arming ourselves using local resources. For instance, there are mines and mortars, but no fuses for them. A mine will not detonate without a fuse. Local inhabitants are bringing us everything -- from food to everyday items. They all want to help us. We are fed on the basis of donations from the local population. But if the enemy carries out his plan -- a total blockade of the city of Slovyansk -- the food situation will be bad too. [Barkov] What about people? [Strelkov] The entire volunteer militia in Slovyansk consists of volunteers who almost without exception are young men who have not served in the army. There are some who have served a year. We have an acute shortage of specialist officers. We lack company and platoon commanders, and experienced machine-gunners and grenade launcher operators. We have no administrative workers. But the volunteer militia are prepared to fight, and they are fighting. The enemy does not have the morale for fighting. So we are beating him. [Barkov] Where do your volunteers come from? [Strelkov] The volunteers who come to us are mainly from the local population, from neighboring cities and settlements. There are very few new volunteers from Russia. Almost none. People do not want to die. And people are being killed here. For instance, 50 men came to us. They were at Krasnyy Lyman -- which is very close to Slovyansk. They were there for two days. They saw things were hard here and there was real fighting, and they left for Antratsyt, 50 kilometers from Slovyansk, and set up there. A small unit of about 10 men arrived from Rostov Oblast. Those men are fighting. All members of public movements and parties, if they want to join us and help us, are taken on here, on the post, after undergoing testing, on the same basis for all. There are no separate formations if they join us and no party structures. We have the principle of one-man command., We have Crimean Cossacks., They are fighting. Armenians arrived, three of them, they stayed a few days, and they left. There is no one from Abkhazia and Chechnya. Those are all rumors. In general there is no big influx of volunteers. They say it is hard to reach us in Slovyansk. They are all lying! [Barkov] In your view, what should Russia do in the situation that has taken shape? [Strelkov] We will stand to the death in Slovyansk. But Russian troops should be brought in. Moscow does not understand the full gravity of the military situation. It is essential to make the political decision to bring Russian military forces into Ukraine. The Ukrainian military are afraid of Russia. I repeat once more: The political decision to bring in Russian troops is needed!

BAKU. Feb 25 (Interfax) - The conflict in Ukraine broke out as a result of problems accumulating in Russia's relations with the West, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said during his visit to Azerbaijan. "Ukraine is now paying the price of the problems existing between the West and Russia the same as Georgia did in the past," he said in a speech at the Azerbaijani Diplomatic Academy in Baku. The minister said that relaxation is needed in the present situation otherwise new conflicts are possible in the region. "The breath of cold war is apparent today even though the Berlin wall fell a long time ago… Barriers remain in people's minds. If people continue sticking to such an approach, conflicts will not be limited only to Ukraine and Georgia," the minister stressed. He noted that despite two agreements in Minsk people continue dying in Ukraine. "In Ukraine 35,000 foreign mercenaries are fighting. This is a great problem. What is going to happen when they return to their countries? Since last April the death toll in Ukraine has reached scores of thousands. The number of refugees has reached 1.2 million people. Radicalism is growing. How can we resist that?" the Turkish official asked. He also spoke of the need to settle so-called frozen conflicts. "The world must settle the frozen conflicts in Nagorno Karabakh, Transdniestria etc," the minister said adding that in the past few years hotspots also appeared in countries of the Arab Spring. In his opinion, in Nagorno Karabakh Armenia "won nothing at all." "The documents adopted by the international community confirm that Nagorno Karabakh belongs to Azerbaijan. Armenia only lost in this conflict and failed to sign an association agreement with the European Union," Cavusoglu said. He said that the unresolved Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict remains the greatest problem standing in the way to peace and stability in the South Caucasus. "We don't want war or problems with neighbors but they should also respect the territorial integrity of neighboring countries. In the first palce this applies to Armenia. We want peace and stability in the region," Cavusoglu said. Ml (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

BEIJING, August 16 (Itar-Tass) - Chinese president Xi Jinping said Saturday efforts should be made to prevent Ukraine from falling into humanitarian crisis, Xinhua reported. When meeting with Ban Ki-moon, secretary-general of the United Nations, Xi described the crash of a Malaysian plane in eastern Ukraine as an imperative to properly address the Ukrainian crisis, the agency said. On July 17, Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, a Boeing 777 en route from Amsterdam to Kuala lumpier, went down in eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 people on board. The cause of the incident remains unknown and the investigation cannot go smoothly due to the armed conflicts in the region. Xi urged all parties to negotiate for a programme that could take into consideration the interests of all parties in a balanced manner, Xinhua reported. He stressed that China continues to support the UN to play a major part in the process. Ban Ki-moon said that a political solution, rather than use of force, is the only right way to resolve the Ukrainian issue. The United Nations appreciates China"s stance on the issue and hopes China will continue playing a constructive role in advancing dialogue and addressing the Ukrainian crisis in a peaceful way, the Xinhua agency reported.

BEIJING, June 18 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying on Wednesday expressed condolences over the deaths of two Russian journalists who were killed near Lugansk in eastern Ukraine. China has always opposed violence against journalists, Hua told a daily press briefing, urging effective measures to safeguard journalists to avoid similar tragedies. She said China is deeply worried about the situation in Ukraine, calling on relevant sides to keep calm, exercise restraint, stop violence and conflict to create conditions for a political solution. Two Russian television journalists, Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin, were killed on Tuesday in mortar fire.

BELGRADE. May 15 (Interfax) - Serbia calls for a prompt shift to economic, humanitarian and political matters in Ukraine, Serbian Foreign Minister Ivica Dacic has said. "It is necessary to gradually shift from defense and security matters to the economy, wages, banking system operation, humanitarian and political issues, such as the electoral system, the constitution reform, and the launch of a national dialogue in Ukraine, as soon as possible," he said at a press conference on Friday, after negotiations with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in Belgrade. "Being the OSCE Chair Country, we want to assist in the fulfillment of the agreements reached in the 'Normandy format'," he said. Dacic called for honoring the ceasefire in Ukraine and other provisions of the Minsk agreements. te cy (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

BERLIN, September 26 (RIA Novosti) – The European Union and the World Bank could act as guarantors for the debt payments that Ukraine would be submitting to Russia under the plan proposed at the trilateral gas talks in Berlin Friday, Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak said. "The funds that Ukraine received today from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which amount to $3.1 billion, could be used as a source of paying off the debt on the [Russian] gas deliveries, and the World Bank and the European Union can act as guarantors for the repayment of this debt," Novak told journalists after the talks. The European Union proposed that Ukraine pay Russia's Gazprom a total of $3.1 billion by the end of this year. This "winter package" also stipulates that Russia supply Ukraine 5 billion cubic meters of gas at a proposed price of $385 per 1,000 cubic meters for six months. Commenting on the proposals, Novak said that "The Russian side and the European Union have practically no disagreements on these packages. It can be said that our positions are similar." However, no final decisions have been made yet. Russia will hold direct talks with Ukraine on the issue of gas supplies next week, where the sides might come to an agreement. As a result of the ongoing political crisis in the country, Ukraine is currently on the verge of a default. Kiev authorities are trying to rescue the country's economy with international loans, including a $17 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. Kiev has a significant gas debt that its gas company Naftogaz owes to Russian gas giant Gazprom, which is estimated to stand at over $5.3 billion. The IMF approved a loan to Ukraine in May in the form of a two-year stabilization program so that the country would be able to clear its debts, carry out economic reforms and recover. To receive the IMF funds in full, Ukraine agreed to a severe austerity program that includes shedding 24,000 government jobs, raising taxes, selling off state assets and withdrawing subsidies on natural gas.

Bratislava, April 4 (TASR) - Freedom and Solidarity (SaS) denounces any efforts on the part of Slovak or foreign senior state representatives to misuse the anniversary of Bratislava's liberation and the defeat of Nazi Germany to belittle and legitimise the violation of international law and aggression against neighbouring states, SaS's expert on foreign policy Martin Klus told TASR on Saturday [4 April]. Klus was referring to an official visit of Russian Foreign Affairs Minister Sergei Lavrov [Sergey Lavrov] to Slovakia on Saturday, during which the Russian minister - among other things - set off for Bratislava's Slavin War Memorial to pay respect to Soviet soldiers who died in the liberation of Bratislava towards the end of WWII. Klus went on to complain that at Lavrov's press conference with his Slovak counterpart Miroslav Lajcak earlier in the day the former talked about the conflict in Ukraine as if Russia had nothing to do with it and referred to Crimea as a Russian territory "without hesitation". "Such behaviour of a guest in a country that declares to observe a completely different line of foreign policy can be labelled as unacceptable," stressed Klus.

BRISBANE, November 15 (RIA Novosti) - Russian President Vladimir Putin and UK Prime Minister David Cameron expressed their interest during the G20 summit in Brisbane, Australia in restoring the relations between Russia and the West as well as in finding measures for settling the Ukrainian crisis, Kremlin Spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said. "Even though the rather long talk was mainly on Ukraine, a conversation was held on the fundamental reasons behind the current problems in Russia's relations with the United States and a number of European countries. Besides, Putin and Cameron expressed their interest in restoring these relations and in undertaking measures for settling the Ukrainian crisis, which in turn would contribute to refraining from confrontational moods," Peskov told reporters Saturday. Tensions in relations between Russia and the West have started to build up since the very outset of the Ukrainian crisis. The Western community criticized Russia for allegedly playing a role in Ukraine’s internal political situation as well as for the reunification of Crimea with Russia. The condemnation by the United States, the European Union and a number of other countries was followed by several rounds of sanctions being imposed against Russia. All this happened despite assurances by Russia that it is no party to the crisis in Ukraine. Russia also repeatedly reminded that Crimea's reunification with Russia occurred merely by the volition of the territory's residents.

Brussels, Jan. 19 (Jiji Press)--Visiting Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida and senior European Union officials agreed Monday that Japan and the EU will strengthen their cooperation against terrorism in response to recent attacks in France. The EU officials, including Federica Mogherini, the EU's high representative for foreign affairs and security policy, referred to counterterrorism measures discussed at a meeting of EU foreign ministers earlier in the day. Terrorism should never be tolerated for any reason, Kishida told Mogherini. Kishida said Japan will provide 7.5 million dollars in aid for antiterrorism measures in the Middle East. He also explained Japan's security policy, including so-called proactive pacifism. In a statement issued after the meeting with Kishida, Mogherini said that the EU supports Japan "in taking up more of its responsibilities on regional and global security." "We are expanding our joint peace and security agenda, cooperating in the context of EU crisis management operations and working together in crisis areas," the statement added. At a separate meeting with Frans Timmermans, first vice president of the European Commission, Kishida called on the EU to remove its import restrictions on agricultural products from Fukushima Prefecture and other parts of Japan that were introduced after the accident at Tokyo Electric Power Co.'s Fukushima No. 1 nuclear power plant damaged in the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami. Timmermans said that the EU is studying a positive response to the issue. Kishida and the EU officials agreed to work on setting up a Japan-EU summit for the first half of this year in Japan. Kishida also met with German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier. During the series of meetings, Kishida unveiled Japan' plans to offer additional financial assistance to Ukraine, citing the country's tough fiscal and economic conditions.

BRUSSELS, January 15 (Sputnik) - The European Union must keep the sanctions against Russia in place and adopt "benchmarks" that would allow them to be lifted, the European Parliament said in a press release following its plenary session on Thursday. "[Members of the European Parliament] urge the EU Council at its March 2015 meeting to maintain current EU sanctions against Russia and approve 'benchmarks' for lifting them," the resolution read. According to the bloc's legislative body, these benchmarks should include "respecting the ceasefire, unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops and illegal armed groups, exchanging all prisoners and restoring Ukraine's control over its whole territory, including Crimea." The release added that "in the event of further Russian actions destabilizing Ukraine" restrictive measures would be further expanded to encompass the nuclear sector and international financial transactions in addition to existing banking, energy and defense sanctions. On Tuesday, European Council President Donald Tusk reiterated the EU's intention to review current anti-Russia sanctions in March. According to EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini and remarks made by other regional leaders, the lifting of anti-Russia sanctions is subject to the observation of the Minsk agreements on Ukraine and the stabilization of the situation in Donbas region. Russian authorities have repeatedly denied claims of involvement in Ukraine's internal affairs, a subject that led to the souring of relations between Moscow and the West in 2014. Several rounds of sanctions were adopted in Brussels, Washington and a number of allied states in response to Russia's alleged military support to southeast Ukraine's militia. These measures were met in August with Moscow's introduction of year-long food import bans from countries that imposed sanctions against it. The European Parliament's resolution is non-binding for EU bodies on the issue of sanctions.

BRUSSELS, September 3 (Itar-Tass) - Rallies in support of Ukraine’s cities of Donetsk and Lugansk in front of the European Parliament building in Brussels will be continued until the Right Sector is listed as a terrorist organization, Tatjana Zdanoka, a Latvian member of the European Parliament, told ITAR-TASS on Tuesday. A "Stop Fascism" picket was held in front of the European Parliament’s building on Tuesday. About 20 activists, both Russian and Ukrainian nationals and French and Belgian citizens, took part in the action. They were holding slogans "Stop Fascism," "Save Donetsk" and a Russian flag. They demonstrated dozens of photos made on May 2 in the Ukrainian city of Odessa, where at least 48 protesters against the Kiev authorities had been burnt alive by radicals. "We will stage such rallies on the second day of each month to commemorate the Odessa tragedy. We will be here until the Right Sector is listed as a terrorist organization," she said. "Today, similar actions were held in Riga, Warsaw, Berlin, Copenhagen, London, Madrid, Milan. People learnt about these actions from anti-fascist organizations, from the European Russian Alliance." "There is a solid anti-fascist and anti-war movement in Europe involving tens of thousands of people. The main thing is that we know people who think the same way in all countries of the European Union. Despite the West’s massive pro-Kiev propaganda, there are a lot of people who do not believe it," Elena Politova, an activist and administrator of the Facebook anti-war group, said.
