Earlier on Tuesday, about a hundred people formed a human chain between the Russian and Ukrainian embassies in Riga in a Remembrance and Solidarity action dedicated to the May 2 massacre in the Ukrainian city of Odessa. The action was organized by activists of the party Latvian Russian Union. "We gathered here not only to pay tribute to those killed on May 2 in Odessa, but also to demand that the Ukrainian government do two things. First, it must conduct a really objective investigation and punish those responsible for this tragedy. Second, it must do away with radical right organizations that are now flocking round power in Ukraine," Miroslav Mitrofanov, a co-chairman of the Latvian Russian Party, told ITAT-TASS. "It is inadmissible to flirt with fascists, they must be controlled and kept away from the state. Otherwise, Ukraine will never be a democratic country." Unrest in the southern Ukrainian port city of Odessa started on May 2, when football fans from the east Ukrainian city of Kharkov marched along city streets with Right Sector radicals and supporters from Kiev"s Maidan Self-Defence Force. Clashes broke out between them and activists seeking a referendum on the issue of Ukrainian federalisation and Russian"s official status as a state language. At least 48 people died and more than 200 were injured in clashes in Odessa after radicals set ablaze the regional House of Trade Unions, where pro-federalisation activists had taken refuge, and a tent camp near it where they had been collecting signatures in support of the referendum. Some Ukrainian politicians said the clashes had taken the lives of at least 116 people and that Kiev"s incumbent authorities sought to conceal exact figures.

BRUSSELS. Jan 31 (Interfax) - Lithuanian Foreign Minister Linas Linkevicius said he is convinced that good relations between Ukraine and Russia are the only right solution, but it is now time to make a strategic choice. Linkevicius said the issue was addressed in the meeting between the foreign ministers of the EU countries, who consider themselves friends of Ukraine, and Ukrainian Foreign Minister Leonid Kozhara, which took place in Brussels on Thursday. Lithuania will become chair the EU in the second half of 2013. Having pointed out that "there are various signals, various judgments on how [the country] could associate itself with the Customs Union while at the same time moving on on the free trade zone with the EU," the Lithuanian minister said. "A choice needs to be made here. There are borders that can't be crossed. If the border of free trade with the Customs Union is crossed, it will be a contradiction with the common market in the EU. There can be no contradictions. The thing is that a choice needs to be made," he said. At the same time, Linkevicius said the economic ties the EU has also need to be taken into account. "If we look a the problem in an unpoliticized way, but in a practical way, the very wish to have good relations with both Russia and the EU is the only choice and there can be no other way. However, speaking about the choice specifically, we come to the point when a choice needs to be made. It's up to your politicians to decide: literature and poetry end and specific agreements begin, which will determine the future of Ukraine. The main thing is that it should be done without conflicts," Linkevicius said. "We don's see any reasons for which you, having selected one way, should burn all bridges. That shouldn't happen. However, how this can be done is a different issue," Linkevicius said. av

Bucharest, Nov 27 /Agerpres/ - The speech of Chairman of the State Duma of the Federal Assembly of the Russian Federation Sergey Naryshkin on the occasion of taking over the chairmanship of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation Organisation (PABSEC) for the next semester was interrupted by delegates of Ukraine. During the official speech, the Ukrainian delegates displayed two banners reading '2008 - Georgia, 2014 - Ukraine. Who's next? PUTIN STOP!'and 'Putin, return Crimea back to us!' Sergey Naryshkin interrupted his speech in order to tell delegates who were protesting that 'they would be more comfortable seated.' In his turn, Romanian Senate President Calin Popescu-Tariceanu called on the delegates engaged in protest to take a seat. 'I ask delegations that are taking a stand to take into consideration my request for the good conduct of works, to return to the seats assigned to them,' Tariceanu stated. The speech of the Russian official ended with an invitation addressed the protesters and asked them to attend the 47th plenary session of the Assembly, scheduled for June 28-30, 2016, in Moscow, to which the delegates answered with hootings. AGERPRES

Budapest, June 16 (MTI) -- Once Europe's planned energy union is completed, it will ensure a supply of safe, comptitive, and sustainable energy to its citizens, Maros Sefcovic, vice-president of the European Commission, said in Budapest on Tuesday [16 June], adding that the current energy situation cannot be maintained. Sefcovic said that energy security for the European Union cannot be ensured unless member states diversify their energy sources. He noted that Hungary buys 80 percent of its gas solely from Russia's Gazprom. As part of the energy union, Hungary would be less dependent on a single gas or nuclear fuel supplier, while diversification would not only reduce risks of an outage but increase competition which could result in lower energy prices, Sefcovic said. The energy union and energy security are top priorities for the Commission, issues that need to be handled at community level and through a comprehensive approach, Sefcovic said. CEE, Hungary Still Vulnerable in Energy Security, Says [Sefcovic] Budapest, June 16 (MTI) -- Central and Eastern Europe, and Hungary as well, is still vulnerable from the point of view of energy security, the Hungarian foreign minister said, after meeting European Commission Vice President Maros Sefcovic in Budapest. Romania and Croatia have not yet carried out investments required for its interconnectors to ship natural gas despite relevant EU and bilateral agreements, Peter Szijjarto said after their talks. This makes building a gas delivery infrastructure difficult, he said. The government will do its utmost to cater for Hungary's energy security and will seek to serve that goal by linking the CEE region's electricity networks, the minister added. Among tasks for Hungary, he mentioned the creation of a large capacity strategic gas pipeline to link Central and Eastern Europe with Turkey. This would diversify not only the delivery routes, but the sources of supplies as well, he said. The interconnector linking Hungary and Slovakia can start shipping gas on July 1, Szijjarto said, noting that Hungary was the first EU member state to conclude an agreement with Ukraine on reverse gas deliveries. This served as a model for other member states on how Ukraine can be linked up with the community's energy market, he said. On another subject Szijjarto confirmed the government's position on the utility cuts scheme. There will be no increase in utility fees "as long as you see us in this post," he said, adding that the government seeks to reach an agreement with the EU that would not lead to a fee hike. The EC vice president said he highly appreciated Hungary's "constructive and responsible" approach towards the interconnector projects. These pipelines must be made suitable for reverse gas transmission as soon as possible, he said. Sefcovic visited Hungary as part of his tour of EU member states with- a mission to present the opportunities that the Energy Union will bring to European citizens and businesses.

Business AUTHOR: The Jakarta Post, Jakarta PUBDATE: July 21 2014, 12:10 PM (BK - The Jakarta Post/Business) - The rupiah traded among banks in Jakarta on Monday morning appreciated by 20 points to 11,590 per US dollar. Monex Investindo Futures analyst Zulfirman Basir said the confidence among market players in the hope of a smooth presidential election result announcement, slated to be conducted on Tuesday, had created positive sentiment in the domestic market. He said the improvement had also been triggered by foreign capital continuing to enter the country, despite the crises in Ukraine and the Middle East. However, he added that the rupiah remained volatile, since the global price of crude oil was still above US$100 per barrel. The possibility of increasing tension in Ukraine and the Middle East in the near future would likely increase the price of crude oil further, he explained, thus affecting Indonesia's trade balance and current account. "In this situation, we predict that the rupiah will trade for between 11,510 and 11,640 per dollar today," Zulfirman said Monday as quoted by Antara news agency. (nfo)

By arresting Russian journalists Ukraine put Europe in difficult position - Pushkov MOSCOW. May 20 (Interfax) - Alexei Pushkov, chairman of the State Duma committee on international affairs, believes the actions taken by the Kyiv authorities who have arrested Russian journalists will create problems for Europe. "The Kyiv regime has crossed the line by arresting Russian journalists. No one will believe the 'terrorist' nonsense. Kyiv is putting Europe in a difficult situation," Pushkov said on Twitter in the early hours of Tuesday. According to earlier reports, the Ukrainian military detained LifeNews journalists Marat Saichenko and Oleg Sidyakin in Kramatorsk on May 18. The Ukrainian authorities accused the journalists of terrorism. On Monday, OSCE Representative of Freedom of the Media Dunja Mijatovic called on the Ukrainian authorities to release the journalists. The Russian Foreign Ministry has taken note of Mijatovic's statement. "We expect the OSCE administration to take drastic action in this issue and publicly react to the outrageous violations of freedom of the media in Ukraine," the ministry said. av mk

By launching operation in southeastern Ukraine, Kyiv makes nationwide dialogue impossible - Russian envoy to UN NEW YORK (UN). May 2 (Interfax) - The punitive operation that the Ukrainian leadership has launched in the southeastern part of the country shows that Kyiv has dropped the idea of a nationwide dialogue involving all regions and political forces, Russian Permanent Representative at the UN Vitaly Churkin said at an extraordinary UN Security Council session convened at Russia's demand on Friday. "The punitive measures that the current Kyiv leadership has taken against its own people attest to its inability or unwillingness to deliver on the obligations it assumed under the Geneva statement of April 17 in favor of putting an end to any violence and starting a broad nationwide dialogue involving all regions and political forces as soon as possible," Churkin said. "If the criminal undertaking by the Kyiv clique is not stopped immediately, there is no way to avoid gravest and disastrous consequences for Ukraine. We have warned about this more than once," he said. "By supporting the organizers of the coup d'etat in Kyiv and their line toward quelling protests by force, the U.S. and the EU are assuming immense responsibility and actually cutting ways to a peaceful resolution of the crisis," he said. va

By Lukas I. Alpert MOSCOW--A shootout erupted early Sunday at a roadblock outside an eastern Ukrainian city that has become the focal point of a pro-Russian separatist movement, with varying reports of casualties. The incident represented the first reported bloodshed in the region since Ukraine, Russia, the U.S. and the European Union signed a joint agreement on Thursday in Geneva to try to stabilize the situation in eastern Ukraine, where pro-Russian militants have taken control of 10 cities. Following the agreement, Ukraine said it would halt a military operation to regain control of the region over the Easter holiday. Ukraine's interior ministry said one person was killed and three wounded in a gunbattle just north of Slovyansk around 3 a.m. between two groups, but gave no further details. Russian news agencies, citing officials with the pro-Russian militia that seized control of the city last weekend, reported that up to five people had been killed--three who were guarding the checkpoint and two who had opened fire from inside a pair of vehicles as they approached the roadblock. Photos from the scene showed two vehicles bearing Ukrainian license plates that appeared entirely gutted by fire. A report on Russia's state-run news channel Rossiya 24, citing no source, stated that a large quantity of arms--including explosives, smoke bombs, U.S.-made night-vision goggles and aerial maps of the region were found inside the cars. The report also said that materials found in the car were linked to a small Ukrainian ultranationalist group, Pravy Sektor, which has repeatedly been held up by Russia as a sign that Ukraine has been overrun by armed fascists who are threatening the rights of ethnic Russians. Little evidence of such threats, however, has ever emerged. The report prompted a statement from the Russian foreign ministry repeating Rossiya 24's details of what was found in the cars and blaming the new government in Kiev of failing to rein in and disarm "nationalists and extremists." "It is astonishing that this tragedy happened after the signing of the April 17th Geneva declaration...which calls for refraining from all acts of violence, intimidation and provocation," the statement said. "Russia insists that Ukraine sticks to its commitments to de-escalate the situation in the southeast." Viktoria Syumar, deputy head of Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council, called reports blaming Pravy Sektor "propaganda" intended to support the argument that Ukraine has plunged into civil war in order to justify a possible Russian invasion in the future. Russia has moved tens of thousands of troops close to the Ukrainian border and has repeatedly said it reserves the right to defend the interests of ethnic Russians living in eastern Ukraine. On Friday, pro-Russian militants refused to vacate government buildings they have occupied as the Geneva agreement calls for them to do, undermining the effectiveness of the deal at the outset. Write to Lukas I. Alpert at lukas.alpert@wsj.com (END) Dow Jones Newswires April 20, 2014 07:12 ET (11:12 GMT)

Churkin: Russia expects Kyiv to take real steps towards peace UNITED NATIONS (New York City). Aug 29 (Interfax) - Moscow expects Kyiv to take real steps towards resolution of the conflict in Ukraine, Russian Permanent Representative to the United Nations Vitaly Churkin said. "President Petro Poroshenko has repeatedly made peace-loving statements. He has also mentioned a certain new urgent settlement plan, but where is this plan? Or is it just the same distracting maneuver which actually conceals the stake on a military solution? Hopefully, the Ukrainian administration will not squander the positive potential of the Minsk meetings," Churkin said at the UN. The Ukrainian army is using weapons non-discriminatively and prohibited means are being applied, the diplomat pointed out. Te

CIS border department chiefs to discuss anti-terrorist fight, border security in Odesa ODESA. May 16 (Interfax) - Border department heads of CIS member countries will discuss suppression of terrorism and illegal immigration and security of CIS borders at the 69th meeting of the Council of CIS Border Force Commanders. "Ukraine's hosting of the 69th meeting of the Council is of paramount importance for the Ukrainian border department. We value the Council work towards coordinated efforts of CIS border agencies and deterrence of modern threats and challenges of terrorism and illegal immigration to national security along CIS borders," Ukrainian State Border Service Head Mykola Lytvyn told a Thursday press briefing in Odesa. He explained the choice of Odesa as the meeting venue with the display of Ukrainian Border Service security techniques on land and sea borders. In turn, Chairman of the Coordination Service of the Council of CIS Border Force Commanders Alexander Manilov said the meeting would discuss anti-drug measures and special border operations. "The Council will ponder eleven major issues today related to operations of border departments and security along CIS borders and sign over 20 documents pertaining to border security. One of the topical questions is Central Asia and the situation taking shape because of the planned coalition withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2014," Manilov said. Ukraine is hosting the meeting of the coordination council for the fifth time. Eleven heads of CIS border departments and deputy heads of the CIS Executive Committee and the CIS Anti-Terrorist Center are taking part in it. Representatives of the EU Border Assistance Mission to Moldova and Ukraine will attend, too. The sides will familiarize themselves with engineering and information innovations the Ukrainian State Border Service is using in consistency with European border standards and the experience of Euro 2012 in Ukraine, Eurovision 2012 in Azerbaijan and the Seventh Winter Asian Games 2011 in Kazakhstan.

CIS NEWS No plans to cut Russian-Belarusian Union State programs - head Manifestations of a crisis in the Russian and Belarusian economies will not lead to cuts in the Union State's budget, or a reassessment of the package of joint programs, said state secretary of the Union State, Grigory Rapota. "The figures remain unchanged. No proposals have been made to cut the budget or Union programs," Rapota told reporters in Minsk on Tuesday. He also said that the Union programs were aimed at developing innovative products and rested on the two countries' scientific and industrial potentials, and therefore depend on imports to a smaller degree. "The crisis will not have an effect on Union programs, I am sure, except the fact, perhaps, that our currency exchange rates have changed," Rapota said. The Belarusian-Russian integration projects remain in force, despite the crisis, he also said. "They remain on the agenda and progress has been made in fulfilling the tasks set," he said. The work to implement the integration projects "will be discussed by the Union Council of Ministers, to convene in the first half of the year, and will be discussed in contacts between the prime ministers," he said. President Ilham Aliyev has ordered to adjust pension insurance for inflation, according to a statement on his website. The insurance component of employment-based pensions will now be adjusted for the 2014 inflation. The average annual pension in Azerbaijan in 2014 stood at 1.4%. Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko and Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko had a telephone conversation on Tuesday. "Issues of mutual interest were discussed during the conversation," the Belarusian state news agency BelTA reported. Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko will give a press conference for Belarusian and foreign journalists on January 29, the Belarusian presidential press service told Interfax. It is expected that 260 journalists from 152 newspapers, 16 news agencies, three online media, 26 TV channels, 41 radio stations will take part in the press conference. A total of 142 journalists will represent Belarusian regions. The governments of Belarus and Russia are drafting a joint action plan to deal with the economic crisis. The plan is to be submitted for discussion at a meeting of the Supreme State Council of the Union State, tentatively set for early march, said Belarusian Prime Minister Andrei Kobyakov. "I guess the Supreme State Council will convene soon, in early March. We must ready ourselves for the current economic conditions. The two governments are drafting a joint economic-policy action plan which is expected to give them levers to find a worthy and well-coordinated response to the crisis," Kobyakov told Grigory Rapota, state secretary of the Belarusian-Russian Union State, in Minsk on Tuesday. He also said that both countries have certain ideas readied, and experts are working on them. The Belarusian and Russian finance and economics ministries, and central banks are maintaining intensive contacts, as well, he said. "Certain problems have cropped up in bilateral relations, as well, which found themselves in the limelight last year. We didn't expect them to arise in the Customs Union," the Belarusian prime minister said. Hopefully, these issues will be discussed today, he said. The presidents of Kyrgyzstan and Mongolia, Almazbek Atambayev and Tsakhia Elbegdorj, respectively, have been discussing bilateral cooperation. "On Tuesday Atambayev met with Mongolian President Elbegdorj, who is in Kyrgyzstan on a working visit," the Kyrgyz head of state's press office told Interfax. At the meeting, the parties discussed the bilateral Kyrgyz-Mongolian cooperation in various areas, the spokesperson said.. "The presidents called for further intensification of political dialogue between Kyrgyzstan and Mongolia and for broader bilateral cooperation in trade, economy and culture," the spokesperson added. Moldovan President Nicolae Timofti started political consultations with the parliamentary factions on Tuesday concerning the nomination of a candidate for prime minister. Timofti planned to meet on Tuesday with the deputies of four factions, i.e. that of the Liberal-Democratic Party of Moldova (LDPM), the Democratic Party (DPM), the Liberal Party, and the Party of Communists, the presidential press service told Interfax. The president had earlier met with the parliamentarians from the Party of Socialists, which had refused to take part in forming the government or nominate a prime ministerial candidate, the press service said. The Socialists, who control 25 out of the 101 parliamentary mandates, had said on Monday they would be in stiff opposition to the ruling majority and would not support any of its decisions in the parliament. The LDPM and DPM agreed last Friday on setting up the Alliance for European Moldova holding 42 (23+19) out of the 101 mandates. The two parties declared their intention to set up a minority government with support from the Party of Communists, whose faction numbers 20 deputies. The decision was made after the LDPM and DPM had failed to reach an agreement on setting up a parliamentary majority with the Liberal Party (13 mandates). The Alliance for European Moldova, supported by the Party of Communists faction, unblocked the parliament's work last Friday by electing its speaker and governing bodies nearly two months after the parliamentary elections. The establishment of the government is supposed to be the next step for the parliament. Article 98 of the Moldovan constitution stipulates that the president is expected to nominate a candidate for prime minister after conducting consultations with all factions. Within 15 days after the nomination, the candidate is supposed to ask the parliament to pass a vote of confidence in the government's composition and program. Based on a vote of confidence, the president is to endorse the government. Article 85 of the Moldovan constitution stipulates that, if a government is not formed after the president's consultations with the parliamentary factions, the president is entitled to dissolve the parliament. The parliament can also be dissolved if it fails to pass a vote of confidence in a government at least twice within 45 days after its composition and program were proposed. The agreement on putting together the Alliance for European Moldova says that the LDPM will nominate a candidate for prime minister. LDPM Chairman Vlad Filat told journalists that incumbent Prime Minister Iurie Leanca would remain the candidate for prime minister and the government would be formed within two weeks. Attempts to rewrite history, including Holocaust events, are impermissible and amoral, Russian President Vladimir Putin said. "Such crimes cannot and do not have an expiration date, an excuse or oblivion. Any attempts to keep silent about these events, to distort or rewrite history are impermissible and amoral," Putin said at the Moscow Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center. "A wish to conceal one's shame, the shame of cowardice, hypocrisy and treasury, and to find an excuse for direct or indirect silent connivance with the criminal policy of the Nazi are often behind these attempts," the chief of state added. The danger of double standards in the resolution of global problems has manifested itself with renewed vigor in southeastern Ukraine, President Vladimir Putin said. "History shows to what dangerous line mankind can be brought by aspirations of world dominance and what military pressure on sovereign states and disrespect for their rights can be fraught with," he said, speaking at the Moscow Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center on Tuesday. "And we also know the dangerous and destructive nature of double standards and indifference towards the fate of others, which has been exhibited in today's tragedy in southeastern Ukraine where civilians of Donbas, Luhansk, have been being killed in cold blood for months," Putin highlighted. "A crime the scale of the Holocaust must never be repeated. This is our duty and it would not be an exaggeration to say that this is the most important and pressing task of the entire international community," Putin said. "Enormous changes have taken place on the international scene over past decades but we can still see hateful ideas across the globe," he said. "We are still encountering attempts to split society over nationality, race or religion, as well as anti-Semitism, Russophobia and aggressive intolerance towards other peoples, cultures and traditions," the chief of state said. In the past "these primitive instincts were used by the Nazi regime and now they have been adopted by nationalists, extremists and terrorists operating in some countries and regions of the world." "We need to resist these threats together, to protect peace and freedom together and to defend the right of states to choose their own development path," Putin emphasized. President Vladimir Putin said "social stability" must be the main objective of the crisis plan being prepared by Russia's government. "Because it's called an anti-crisis plan, we realize that above all it must guarantee social stability. But this objective can only be attained if acceptable economic parameters are maintained," Putin said at a government conference in Moscow on Monday. He said he was referring to inflation and foreign debt levels, budgetary principles and amounts of emergency reserves. "That is all that we have justifiably been proud of in recent years. The name of it is macroeconomic stability. It must become the basis for economic growth as one of the conditions for private investment," Putin said. He called for revisions of state spending in order "to increase the financing of some of the economic sectors the way this was done in 2008-2009." "We should look at our priorities once again," he said. President Vladimir Putin has given the economy ministers in the Cabinet seven days to meet with lawmakers to discuss the parameters of the anti-crisis plan. "The prime minister plans to confirm this plan tomorrow. I would ask you to meet with State Duma deputies in the coming week to discuss all parameters of this plan in order to ensure the maximum consolidation of the executive and legislative branches of authority," Putin told the Cabinet on Monday. Putin said that he was planning to discuss the ideas proposed by the economy ministers in the Cabinet during the meeting. Putin is expected to confirm the anti-crisis plan. Russian President Vladimir Putin, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande discussed the latest sharp escalation of tensions in south-eastern Ukraine over the phone, the Kremlin press service has reported. "The president of Russia reiterated that the reason for this was the Kyiv authorities' policy aimed at suppressing Donbas by force," the press service said. Putin noted that on January 15, he had forwarded a letter to Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, proposing the immediate withdrawal of the sides' heavy weapons from the line of contact in an attempt to prevent further shelling of residential areas and further civilian casualties. "A formal response to this message arrived only today. And, prior to this, large-scale fighting had been launched, resulting in a catastrophic deterioration of the situation in the south-east," the press service said. During these telephone conversations, Putin reaffirmed the extreme importance of establishing political dialogue between the Kyiv authorities and representatives of Donetsk and Luhansk in order to stop the bloodshed and help settle the internal Ukrainian crisis, the press service said. Moscow is "cautiously optimistic" about a recent meeting in Donetsk at which Viktor Medvedchuk, Ukrainian Choice public organization head, represented Ukraine on the orders of President Petro Poroshenko. He met with the leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics, Alexander Zakharchenko and Igor Plotnitsky, Kremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov said. The sides held preliminary consultations ahead of the Minsk negotiations "primarily because, against the backdrop of offensive operations of the Ukrainian side, the DPR and LPR representatives were reported to have expressed extreme skepticism about prospects of the Minsk process," Peskov said. The Donetsk consultations were also attended by militia representatives to the Minsk negotiations Denis Pushilin and Vladislav Deinego. "Moscow regrets that representatives of the Ukrainian army and Ukrainian presidential advisor Ruslan Demchenko who were planned to appear at the Donetsk meeting changed their mind at the very last moment and did not come to the negotiations," Peskov said. "Moscow hopes that the discussion started at the preliminary consultations in Donetsk will be continued, for instance, in regards to such subjects as the ceasefire, the pullback of artillery and missile systems from the demarcation line, the launch of work to determine the demarcation line and the prisoner exchange," the Russian president's press secretary stated. "The appointment of an official representative to the Minsk negotiations by Kyiv will contribute to the achievement of these goals a lot," he opined. Standard & Poor's decision to lower Russia's investment rating was politically motivated, and all of such ratings should be looked at as political tools, Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said at a meeting on livestock in Bryansk. "All of these ratings everyone is talking a lot about now are obviously a purely political tool," he said. Medevedev said he was saying this "not just because such decisions have been reached with respect to our country." "Let's think about how these ratings are formed," he said. "A number of states impose restrictions against the economies of other states, in this case against our economy, that is, they take, of course, political decisions. And then, on this basis, the conclusion is made that a specific economy is working not entirely as it ought to, that economy is not coping with something. And it is on the basis of this that decisions are made to lower ratings," he said. "Is this not a political decision? He said. "We'll get over all this," he said. "But it's bad that in general, this complicates the situation in the country, and let's be frank, in the world," he said. "You and I have to work out pinpoint solutions that will help our economy in these conditions," Medvedev said. Russia is not experiencing a food deficit, but the situation with prices needs to be controlled and solutions must be found, Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev told journalists at a meeting on livestock on Tuesday. "There have already been certain successes as concerns replacing imports. It must be said that in any case our store shelves aren't empty, and they are being filled more and more by Russian products," he said. "There is not a deficit for goods that people kept talking about. It's clear there's an issue with prices, and this requires separate control and separate decisions. But there's not a deficit," Medvedev added. Discussing support for the livestock industry over the last several years, Medvedev said that 390 billion rubles were allocated for these purposes in 2008-2014. As a result, meat consumption in the country was 75 kilograms per person per year in 2014, which is in line with the "recommended rational norm." "I hope that this year, despite current difficulties, livestock will have decent prospects," Medvedev said. Russian agriculture is capable of not only meeting the domestic needs of the country, but also of supplying food for export, which needs to be stimulated, Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said. "Russia, of course, is capable of not only feeding itself, but also of carrying out exports," Medvedev said at a meeting on the development of animal husbandry on Tuesday. He said that in 2014 the export of live stock products increased by almost 50% compared with 2013. "It will be necessary to adopt additional measures for the stimulus of exports. Of course, this will be after filling our market with high-quality products. But exports are also an important topic so that we can provide producers with opportunity to earn money in foreign currency and advertise our opportunities. Therefore it will also be necessary to engage in this, including the Economic Development Ministry," the prime minister said. Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said Russia's reaction to any decision to restrict the participation of Russian banks in the SWIFT system would be tough and unlimited. "If such decisions are reached, I'd like to say that our economic reaction, and any other for that matter, will be unlimited," Medvedev said at a meeting in Bryansk. He said that apart from a lack of budgeted funds, there was an "additional set of restrictions, which we've also already come up against - finance, liquidity restrictions." "The foreign money markets are closed, and that of course reflects on the domestic situation," he said. "And we are constantly being threatened with additional retribution against our banking system - yet again, restrictions related to SWIFT are being discussed," he said. "Well, we'll just have to wait and see what will happen," Medvedev said. President Petro Poroshenko has informed the representatives of factions of the Verkhovna Rada coalition about the results of the meeting of the National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine (NSDC) on January 25. The NSDC suggested amending the laws aimed at the establishment of military-civilian administrations in the populated areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions, the press service of the president reported. "This will let us resolve the issue of absence of authorities in the liberated territories, when all deputies of local councils, who supported separatist positions and committed crimes, have absconded from justice," the head of state noted. In this regard, Poroshenko said that military-civilian administrations would perform the local government functions, until the elections of competent representative authorities were held. According to him, not only members of the military, but also civilians with relevant experience can be appointed. The main criterion is the capability of being responsible for the solution of security and humanitarian problems of people in the liberated territories. Poroshenko stressed that the humanitarian situation was especially complicated in the areas severely affected by constant shelling. The security of important infrastructure facilities in eastern and southern regions must be increased, particularly in Kharkiv, Odesa, Kherson, Dnipropetrovsk, Zaporizhia, Mykolaiv, Donetsk and Luhansk regions. Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk, who was also present at the meeting, has informed about the decision of the Cabinet of Ministers to impose emergency rule in Donetsk and Luhansk regions, based on the results of the meeting of the NSDC and in accordance with the President's order. The government has also upgraded the regime of emergency response all over Ukraine up to the "full readiness". The Prime Minister said that the inventory of all objects of civilian protection had been initiated that day. According to the preliminary examination, held over the past two months, half of them are not prepared to take people in. One of the reasons, the lack of funding, is planned to be solved at the cost of the government's reserve fund. "The main reason is that nobody cared about this during last 20 years," the Prime Minister said. The meeting was also attended by Verkhovna Rada Chairman Volodymyr Hroisman, NSDC Secretary Oleksandr Turchynov, faction leader of the party "Bloc of Petro Poroshenko" Yuriy Lutsenko, Batkivschyna party leader Yulia Tymoshenko, Radical Party leader Oleh Liashko, Samopomich faction leader Oleh Bereziuk and first deputy leader of the People's Front party Andriy Teteruk. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has expressed hope in a telephone conversation with the EU High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy that the trilateral contact group for the Donbas settlement will meet soon to make it possible to promote further dialog at the highest level, the Ukrainian presidential press service reported. Ukraine has remained committed to the peaceful resolution of the situation in Donbas and speaks for the fulfillment of the Minsk accords by all parties, Poroshenko said. Poroshenko also thanked Mogherini for her effort to convene an extraordinary meeting of the EU Foreign Affairs Council and discuss the EU's reaction to the shelling of Mariupol. Mogherini in turn expressed hope that the EU Council of Foreign Ministers will be able to reach a constructive consensus. The parties also agreed to continue close coordination of effort to assist a comprehensive peaceful settlement in Donbas, the Ukrainian presidential press service reported. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko spoke with European Council President Donald Tusk on the phone on Monday night, the presidential press service reported. "Petro Poroshenko told Donald Tusk about the events happening in Donbas after the terror attack in Mariupol. He thanked the European Council President for his strong support for Ukraine," the report said. The sides coordinated their positions in view of the January 29 sitting of the Foreign Affairs Council. "The Ukrainian President also informed the European Council President about the progress made by Ukraine in the second stage of the visa liberalization action plan and urged the European Union to make a political decision and approve a visa-free travel regime for Ukrainian citizens visiting Schengen countries at the May summit of the Eastern Partnership in Riga," the report underlined. In addition, Poroshenko called on the EU to enlarge macro-financial assistance to Ukraine and discussed issues related to a donor conference due in April 2015. Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatseniuk has addressed the organizers and participants of the "Six Millions of Hearts" event which commemorates the victims of the Holocaust during the Second World War, the Cabinet of Ministers' press service has reported. "Dear Friends! January 27, 2015 is the date of the 70th anniversary of the liberation of prisoners from the death camp at Auschwitz, where in a short time two million people were exterminated, with the majority of them being Jews. The decision of the United Nations is to mark this day as International Holocaust Remembrance Day…While commemorating on this day we pay the tribute to the six million victims of the Holocaust, we remember with sorrow the hundreds of thousands who were killed, tortured and exterminated on the territory of Ukraine in those terrible years: Jews, Romanians, Ukrainians and other nationalities," the premier said. "We honor those who survived in those inhuman conditions and brought to us the awful truth about where an ideology built on ideas of hatred and fanaticism, the superiority of one nation over others leads. We strongly condemn all crimes against the Jewish people, all cases of anti-Semitism, genocide, ethnic and religious intolerance," he said. "These days, when Ukraine is suffering from military aggression, and the terrorists commit reprisals, and sometimes murders basing on national or religious grounds, we again and again declare the commitment of our people to build our future on the principles of tolerance and mutual respect, respect for the freedom and uniqueness of a person," the premier said. Compiled by Maya Sedova, Galina Seregina

CONTENTS OIL Rosneft ups oil production 45% to intl standards in 7M MOSCOW. Aug 6 (Interfax) - Russian oil major Rosneft increased oil production to international standards by 45% year-on-year in January-July - to a little over 102 million tonnes, company materials say. By Russian standards, Rosneft increased output 43.8% to 104.245 million tonnes. Rosneft is now factoring in production by TNK-BP, which it finalized the purchase of this past March. MOSCOW. Aug 1 (Interfax) - RN-Holding, formerly TNK-BP Holding made 33.5 billion rubles in first-half net profits, a 60% drop from the 85 billion rubles it earned for the same period last year, the company reported. Sales revenues, on the other hand, rose 4.5% year-on-year to 526 billion rubles. Cost of product sold increased even more - almost 19% to 451 billion rubles. Earnings "from involvement in other organizations" amounted to 57 billion rubles for H1 2012, where that figure for this year was just 387 million rubles. RN-Holding's gross profits dropped 37.5% to 75 billion rubles and sales profits almost by two thirds to 28 billion rubles for the half. Pretax profits slumped 54.6% to almost 40 billion rubles. MOSCOW. Aug 2 (Interfax) - Alexander Nekipelov, the chairman of the board of directors at Rosneft, has acquired a 0.0008% stake in the Russian state-owned oil producer, the company reported. Nikolai Laverov, a member of the board of directors who, like Nekipelov, previously had no ownership in the company, acquired a 0.0007% stake on July 31. Another member of the board, Artur Warnig, raised his stake in Rosneft from 0.0002% to 0.0009% on the same date. According to Rosneft's press service, Nekipelov, Laverov and Warnig received their stakes as remuneration for serving as independent directors. MOSCOW. Aug 2 (Interfax) - The board of directors of Lukoil will meet on August 8 to discuss preparations for an upcoming extraordinary shareholder meeting, the independent Russian oil producer said in a statement. Lukoil's press service declined to comment on the topic. Lukoil President Vagit Alekperov recently said the board of directors would mull over interim dividends in September. "There should be a board meeting and later a shareholder meeting on interim dividends, like last year," he said. He said dividends will be paid out for the first half of the year. Last year Lukoil made the decision to pay out interim dividends. For 2012 the oil producer shelled out 50 rubles per ordinary share in dividends, which did not include interim dividends of 40 rubles per ordinary share. Altogether, dividends came to 90 rubles per ordinary share, an increase of 20% over payouts for the previous year (75 rubles for 2011). Lukoil's charter capital comprises 850.563 million shares. According to the company's dividend policy, it is to earmark at least 15% of profit to GAAP for dividends. Alekperov has promised to give shareholders 23% of net profit for annual dividends. Lukoil later plans to boost that share to 30%, then by 2021 to 40%. MOSCOW. Aug 6 (Interfax) - Gazprom Neft made net profits to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) of 77.621 billion rubles in the first half of 2013, 1.4% less than in the same period last year, the company reported. Analysts surveyed by Interfax had anticipated the company would make 75.9 billion rubles. The company's second-quarter net profits were up 25% year-on-year at 38.054 billion rubles. The analysts had predicted 36.3 billion rubles. "The company's financial performance in H1 2013 compared to H1 2012 was positively affected by growth in hydrocarbon production and a rise in petroleum products sales via premium distribution channels. The impact of these factors led to a 1.8% year-on-year increase in revenue and a 0.9% year-on-year increase in adjusted EBITDA. The 1.4% year-on-year decrease in profit attributable to Gazprom Neft's shareholders was related to foreign exchange losses due to the revaluation of the credit portfolio, as well as a rise in depreciation expenses resulting from the investment program," the company said. "An increase in production volumes, refining throughput and domestic petroleum product sales drove revenue up by 2.4% quarter-on-quarter. Falling crude oil and oil product prices, combined with the negative impact of the export duty lag in Q2 2013 drove a 3.7% quarter-on-quarter decrease in adjusted EBITDA and a 3.8% quarter-on-quarter decrease in profit attributable to Gazprom Neft's shareholders," it said. "Hydrocarbon production volumes in H1 2013 increased by 3.6% year-on-year to 224.87 mmboe (30.61 mmtoe), due to the ongoing development of major projects (Orenburg, SeverEnergia), continued production growth at the Priobskoye field, and the successful application of high-tech operations at mature fields, as well as programs aimed at improving associated petroleum gas utilization," the company said. "Refining throughput decreased 0.8% year-on-year to 21.19 million tonnes in H1 2013 due to planned maintenance. Sales via premium distribution channels reached 10.98 million tonnes, and average daily sales per petrol station in Russia grew by 9% to 18 tonnes/day," it said. "Capex increased by 31.3% year-on-year, driven mainly by new project development and the use of new technology to maintain production at mature fields," Gazprom Neft said. Gazprom Neft reduced purchases of oil in Russia by 33% year-on-year to 2.66 million tonnes in the first half of 2013, the company reported. Gazprom Neft attributes the reduction to the end of its oil supply contract with TNK-BP, which was bought by state oil major Rosneft in March. Gazprom Neft deputy head for refining, logistics and sales Anatoly Cherner said earlier that Rosneft broke off the contract to supply 200,000 tonnes of TNK-BP crude per month to Gazprom Neft's Omsk Oil Refinery. Gazprom Neft also said in its report that it had reduced oil purchases on the international market by 30.8% to 74,000 tonnes due to the reduction of trading operations. At the same time, the company increased purchases of oil products on the international market by 52.8% to 1.1 million tonnes in the first half due to an increase in trading operations. Purchases of oil products on the domestic market increased by 16.5% to 92,000 tonnes due to scheduled repairs at Gazprom Neft refineries. Gazprom Neft's overall crude sales fell 21% to 6.88 million tonnes in the first half, with exports dropping 35.7% to 4.29 million tonnes due to the redistribution of export sales in CIS countries and a reduction in trading operations. Sales of oil products, meanwhile, rose 3.8% to 22.41 million tonnes. Exports rose 18.7% to 8.2 million tonnes and sales on the international market grew 26.2% to 1.35 million tonnes, while domestic sales dropped 4% to 11.83 million tonnes, and exports and sales in CIS countries fell 20% to 1.03 million tonnes. Gazprom Neft extracted 224.87 million barrels of oil equivalent (boe) in the first half of this year, a 3.6% increase on H1 of 2012, the company reported. The board of directors of Gazprom Neft has deferred its discussion of interim dividends to the fall, CFO Alexei Yankevich said during a conference call. The board was supposed to consider interim dividends this month. Gazprom Neft decided this year to start paying out interim dividends after previously only paying out dividends once for the year as a whole. Gazprom Neft shareholders received 9.3 rubles per share in dividends for 2012, totaling 44.09 billion rubles, or 25% of net consolidated profit to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Gazprom, which controls slightly more than 95% of the oil producer's shares, is the primary recipient of dividends. MOSCOW. Aug 1 (Interfax) - Surgutneftegas increased its net earnings to Russian Accounting Standards (RAS) by 52% year-on-year to 154.223 billion rubles in the first half of the 2013, company materials say. Meanwhile, revenues declined 3.7% to 378.199 billion rubles, but cost of goods sold decreased 2.8% to 255.122 billion rubles. Gross profit was down 5.6% to 123.077 billion rubles, and sales profit dropped 11% to 88.28 billion rubles. However, profit before tax soared 50% to 185.831 billion rubles. KAZAN. Aug 6 (Interfax) - OJSC Tatneft produced 15.15 million tonnes of oil in Tatarstan in January-July 2013, a 0.2% increase over the same period last year and 2.7% above plan, the company said in a press release. In July alone, the company boosted oil production 0.7% year-on-year to 2.218 million tonnes. Tatneft slashed well drilling by 11.8% in the seven-month period to 334,700 meters, including a 8.4% decline for Tatneft itself to 258,300 meters and a 36.3% drop for its subsidiaries to 21,800 meters. The company built and delivered 215 wells to customers, down 3.2% year-on-year. That included 151 wells built and delivered by Tatneft (159 wells in the same period last year) and 18 wells built and delivered by its subsidiaries (17). OJSC TANECO, a subsidiary of Tatneft, refined 730,500 tonnes of crude oil (up 17.5% year-on-year and 5.2% against June) and produced 725,500 tonnes of petroleum products (also up 17.5%) in July, the press release said. IRKUTSK. Aug 7 (Interfax) - The administration of Irkutsk region has signed an agreement on cooperation with AFK Sistema, the regional government said in a press release. The agreement covers cooperation in the forest products and oil and gas sectors, as well as in high tech, creation of innovation-technology parks, and telecommunications, including expansion of broadband internet access and other communications systems. "The two parties to the cooperation agreement will strive to coordinate their operations to attract investment to the Irkutsk region to achieve priority goals in socioeconomic development and strengthen the region's scientific-innovation potential," the press release says. Irkutsk region Governor Sergei Yeroshchenko signed the agreement with AFK Sistema board chairman Vladimir Yevtushenkov. AFK Sistema owns and manages a portfolio of investments in businesses in various industries. Its most significant assets lie in the telecommunications industry (MTS and SSTL), the fuel and energy complex (Bashneft), transport (SG-Trans), electronics (OJSC RTI) and the media sector (SMM). It also develops in other areas, including retail trade (Detsky Mir), finance (MTS-Bank), medical services (Medsi), pharmaceuticals and biotechnology (Binnopharm), tourism (Intourist) and agriculture. AFK Sistema's largest shareholder is founder and board chairman Vladimir Yevtushenkov, with 64.19% of shares. Nineteen percent of its shares are traded on the London Stock Exchange. MOSCOW. Aug 7 (Interfax) - The Swedish company Lundin Petroleum extracted 2,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day (boepd) in Russia in the first half of this year, a 14% decrease, the company said. Overall, Lundin edged up hydrocarbon production 0.3% to 35,200 boepd, mainly due to a 27% increase in gas production, to 7,500 boepd. Oil production alone declined 5% in the six months to 27,700 bpd. In Russia, Lundin owns a 50% stake in the development of the Sotchemyu-Talyu deposit and the North Irael deposit in Komi and a 70% stake in the Lagansky block developer, Petroresurs LLC (oil trader Gunvor has the other 30%). A license to prospect this block valid until next August has been issued. But the company cannot extend it or obtain a production license, as by law only companies with more than 50% state involvement and over five years' experience operating in Russian waters can develop Russian shelf deposits. Lundin has been trying to get this matter settled for quite a while. In 2007, Gazprom was planning to join the development of the block. The Russian gas giant even signed a call-option agreement with Lundin concerning the acquisition of 50% plus one share in Petroresurs, but it was not exercised. In March of 2011, Lundin reiterated that it was negotiating the sale of this block, but to whom it did not say. "In the Lagansky Block in the northern Caspian a major oil discovery, Morskaya, was made in 2008. The discovery is deemed to be strategic by the Russian Government, due to its offshore location, under the Foreign Strategic Investment Law (FSIL). As a result a 50 percent ownership by a state owned company is required prior to appraisal and development. Discussions continue with third parties to meet the requirements of the FSIL," Lundin said in its H1 report. Gunvor has said it is prepared to sell its 30% stake in Petroresurs. The Russian oil was sold both at home and abroad in the first half. Imports accounted for 46% of total oil production at an average price of $107/barrel. It sold for $55/barrel on the domestic market. Overall oil sales declined 11.5% to 4.8 million barrels in the six months. The average sale price was $107/barrel, down from $112/barrel a year earlier. Gas sales rose 22% to 1.4 million barrels of oil equivalent. The average price was $63/barrel, up from $57/barrel. Net profit plunged 50% to $48.2 million and earnings per share fell to $0.16 from $0.37 in the same period last year. EBITDA was down 10% to $520.2 million and revenue of $627.8 million, down 8%. By the end of the year, production could rise to 40,000 boepd (about 2 million tonnes a year), 5% above target, Lundin said in a presentation. The company previously said it planned to increase hydrocarbon production 6.4% to 38,000 boepd. Lundin confirmed that 2013 capex would total $150 million for appraisal and $460 million for exploration, including $120 million in seismic surveying and $340 million in drilling. Spending on geological exploration rose 340% in the first half of the year to $134.3 million, due to implementation of new projects in Norway. Lundin plans to launch oil production at Brynhild, in which the company is the project operator with a 90% stake, in the fourth quarter of 2013. Reserves at the field (2P) are estimated at 23.1 million barrels of oil equivalent, and production is projected to plateau at 12,000 boepd. First oil from another project on the Norwegian shelf - Boyla - is expected in Q4 2014. The 2P reserves are estimated at up to 22 million boe, with a production plateau of 19,000 boepd. Lundin has a 15% stake in the project. One year later, it expects to receive first oil at Edvard Grieg, where Lundin is the project operator with a 50% stake. The other 50% is held by OMV (20%), Wintershall (15%) and Statoil (15%). The 2P reserves are estimated at up to 186 million boe with a production plateau projected to total 100,000 boepd. TOMSK. Aug 5 (Interfax) - The management at India's Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) Videsh Ltd., or OVL, has appointed to the post of Imperial Energy, a part of OVL that extracts oil in Tomsk Region, the senior engineer at Nord Imperial, part of Imperial Energy, Alexander Karataev. He assumed his new duties on August 2, Imperial Energy said in a statement. Nord Imperial sources told Interfax that Karataev replaces Igor Goncharov, the reason for whose departure the company is not commenting on. Interfax has been unable to contact Goncharov. "Mr. Karataev has passed his professional path in oil and gas industry in Tomsk region from the position of geological engineer to General Director of LLC Archinskoye. On November 1st, 2010 he became a Chief Engineer of LLC Nord Imperial. On August 2nd, 2013 Management of OVL appointed Mr. Karataev to the position of General Director of Imperial Energy Group (LLC Nord Imperial, LLC Allianceneftegaz, LLC Sibinterneft, LLC Stratum)," the company said. Nord Imperial LLC and Alyansneftegaz LLC are subsidiaries of Imperial Energy Ltd., which in January of 2009 became part of OVL, which manages the foreign assets of ONGC. The Indian corporation also has a 20% stake in the Sakhalin-1 project. Nord Imperial holds prospecting and production licenses for three hydrocarbon sections - Festivalny, Snezhny, and Kyiv-Yegansky - and six licenses for the Maisky section, Yuzhno-Festivalny sections 1, 2, and 3, and Verkhne-Nyurolsky sections 1 and 2. Production is currently underway at the Festivalny, Kyiv-Yegansky, and Maisky sections. MOSCOW. Aug 6 (Interfax) - HRT Participacoes em Petroleo S.A., which is exploring 21 hydrocarbon blocks in Brazil's Solimoes Basin jointly with Russian TNK-BP, has abandoned licenses to two of the blocks, HRT said in a statement. HRT said it would not renew the concession agreement to the SOL-T-219 and SOL-T-220 blocks due to the difficulty in receiving the environmental and operating permits due to the national nature preserves located within the license territory. The term for the first stage of exploration expired on March 3, after which a halt in operations until August 3 was declared. HRT is now the operator for 19 blocks in the Solimoes Basin, which it is exploring jointly with TNK-Brasil. Rosneft acquired TNK-BP - along with its 45% stake in the concession agreement to the 21 exploration blocks - in March 2013. The project brings TNK-BP potential reserves amounting to 789 million barrels of oil equivalent, according to an audit by Degolyer&MacNaughton. Capital investment will total an estimated $9.2 billion, or about $14 billion including pipeline construction costs. TNK-BP and HRT initially expected Solimoes to be an oil project. However, because only gas has been detected so far, the partners are studying options for monetizing that resource. Prior to its acquisition by Rosneft, TNK-BP had said it would make a decision on monetizing the gas in the third quarter of 2013. MINSK. Aug 2 (Interfax) - Belarusian state-owned oil production association Belorusneft has signed an agreement with Ecuadorean and Chilean oil producers to create an alliance that will jointly explore and develop a block of oilfields in Ecuador, the Belarusian company told Interfax. "A trilateral agreement was signed in Ecuador to create an alliance of companies to jointly explore and develop oil block 28 in the southwest of this Latin American country. State-run oil production companies Petroamazonas E.P. (Ecuador), Belorusneft and ENAP (Chile) joined the joint project," a Belorusneft spokesman said. In the negotiations preceding the signing, the heads of the Belarusian, Ecuadorian and Chilean companies "identified a model and form of interaction and coordinated the basic legal, financial and production aspects of cooperation," the spokesman said. The parties also set out short-term tasks and harmonized the start of work by technical specialists to draft a geological survey plan. An international scientific practice forum was recently held on seismic survey and geological exploration at oilfields. It was organized with the help of Russian company Geoseis on the basis of Belorusneft. "The forum's participants noted that Belorusneft possesses the technical, technological and HR potential that is in demand on the growing global market for these services. Experience in Russia, Venezuela and Ecuador confirms the effectiveness of the methods and equipment used. Belarusian technologies have proven a competitive commodity," the Belorusneft spokesman said, adding that the company does not rule out rendering seismic survey services in Bolivia, Peru and Colombia, as well. Ecuador provides for all of its own oil needs and exports up to 60% of the oil it produces. Established in 1966, Belorusneft specializes in the search, exploration and development of oil deposits, and it also produces oil and associated gas. In addition, it provides oil services outside of Belarus and offers tolling supplies of imported oil to Belarusian oil refineries. It sells the petroleum products it produces through its own chain of filling stations and trading organizations (the largest in Belarus), and it also exports. Last year the company produced 1.6 million tonnes of oil, compared to 1.6.8 million tonnes in 2011. ASTANA. August 5. (Interfax) - The Kazakh government might organize a National Service Company to become the prime contractor for the Future Growth Project (FGP) of Tengizchevroil (TCO), an informed source in the oil and gas industry told Interfax. "The Kazakh government is looking into possibilities of supporting TCO's Future Growth Project. It may create a National Service Company which could become a prime contractor to the Future Growth Project and protect Kazakhstan's interests in the project through seeking an increase in the local content in TCO's procurement plans," he told the agency. As prime contractor to the project, the National Service Company could be actively involved in all FGP related activities, including design and engineering, placement of long-term orders for goods and services, placement of orders with Kazakh manufacturers, training of local personnel for the project and invitation of foreign partners, he said. Creating a National Service Company is the only way for Kazakhstan to benefit from the project, as most of the expenses associated with the project will stay in Kazakhstan, he said. "Part of the shares of the new company could belong to either National Managing Holding Baiterek or National Company Kazakhstan-Engineering, the other shares could be owned by the Ministry of Industry," he said. TCO expects the investments in the Future Growth Project to total $23 billion, according to the source. "I am sure that TCO will announce that the cost of the project needs to be raised to reach $30 billion," he said. "TCO is hastening to seal a memorandum on FGP with the Kazakh government in early September this year on the terms and conditions that are the best for the company. The government, however, is preparing its own version of the memorandum, which will name the National Service Company as a key player in the project," he said. In late 2012 Baktykozha Izmukhambetov, governor of the Atyrau Region, and Krymbek Kusherbayev, who was vice minister at that time, slammed TCO for its low Kazakh content and low investments in social projects According to Izmukhambetov, local content only accounted for 4% in TCO's procurement, as the company preferred to contract foreign companies as service providers. KazMunayGas Deputy CEO Magzum Mirzagaliyev in mid-April said that KMG and TCO had been working towards increasing the local content in FGP up to 44%. "The project that will be starting this year will create thousands of new jobs. TCO says local content in the project will be 32% or $7.3 billion. However, KMG is still negotiating this percentage with TCO, and is suggesting increasing it to 44%, or by an additional $2 billion worth of locally produced goods and services," he said. The Future Growth Project is the next major expansion of oil production at Tengiz. FGP will increase Tengizchevroil oil production by a further 12 million tonnes per year to a total of approximately 36 million tonnes per year. Future Growth Project builds upon the success of the recent Sour Gas Injection and Second Generation Plant expansion, which is proving the viability of sour gas injection into the Tengiz reservoir. Tengizchevroil develops the Tengiz and Korolyov oil and gas fields in the Atyrau Region (west Kazakhstan). The partnership Tengizchevroil was formed between the Republic of Kazakhstan and Chevron Corporation in April 1993. Current partners are: Chevron, 50 percent; KazMunaiGas, 20 percent; ExxonMobil, 25 percent and LukArco, 5 percent. The Tengiz field was discovered in 1979 and now is one of the world's deepest producing super giant fields. ALMATY. August 5. (Interfax) - Standard & Poor's Ratings Services raised its long-term corporate credit rating on Kazakhstan-based oil and gas exploration and production company Zhaikmunai L.P. to 'B+' from 'B'. The outlook is stable. S&P also raised the issue ratings on Zhaikmunai's senior secured notes to 'B+' from 'B'. The upgrade reflects S&P's assumption that Zhaikmunai will continue to achieve robust credit metrics in 2013-2014, including funds from operations (FFO) to debt of 40% or higher (2012: 48.6%) and debt to EBITDA below 2x in 2013-2014 (2012: 1.3x),, the rating agency said in a statement. "This is based on our base-case scenario that the company will produce about 45,000 boepd (barrels of oil equivalent per day), which is close to full production capacity, and a realized price of no less than $95 per barrel in 2013 and $90 per barrel in 2014. We believe that adjusted EBITDA will be about $500 million in 2013 and between $400 million and $450 million in 2014. We also anticipate that oil prices will remain supportive," S&P says. The "weak" business risk assessment reflects S&P's view of the company's concentrated asset base, its dependence on one pipeline for crude oil and stabilized condensate and one pipeline for dry gas, as well as risks relating to the oil industry and operating in Kazakhstan. "These are somewhat mitigated by good profitability, low cash lifting costs, a supportive tax regime, and the part-ownership of its local partner, Kazakhstan-based engineering company KazStroyService. Zhaikmunai acquired three new oil and gas fields in Kazakhstan in the third quarter of 2012, but these will not be producing before 2016," says the statement. Zhaikmunai is able to self-fund sizable capital expenditure (capex), which sets it apart from its peers, S&P reckons. Planned capex is at least $300 million in 2013 and $200 million in 2014, including spending on phase two of investment in the new gas treatment facility (GTF). This is likely to lead to neutral or slightly negative free operating cash flows in 2013-2014. S&P expects Zhaikmunai to adhere to its financial policies of maintaining debt to EBITDA at or below 1.5x and paying dividends of about 20% of net income. In November 2012, Zhaikmunai was able to reduce its interest burden, extend debt maturities, and diversify funding sources when it successfully issued $560 million of new senior notes. Key supporting factors for the rating are the company's good cash flow generation (unrestricted cash on balance sheet was $280 million on June 30, 2013) and its long-dated debt maturity profile. "We understand that management aims to maintain a comfortable cash balance during the second GTF investment phase," the statement reads. The stable outlook on Zhaikmunai reflects S&P's expectation of robust credit metrics for the ratings on the back of near full capacity production in 2013 and 2014 of about 45,000 boepd. S&P anticipates that the company will adhere to its financial targets and the rating agency assumes neutral or slightly negative FOCF and continued adequate liquidity. "All else being equal, we would consider raising the ratings if Zhaikmunai builds a track record of meeting its financial targets and we receive more information on the shareholders' investment strategy. In addition, greater cushion for liquidity could support the likelihood of an upgrade," the statement says. S&P says it could consider lowering the ratings if Zhaikmunai's production levels become considerably lower than S&P currently envisages or if they consider that the company's liquidity management or financial policies have become less prudent. Zhaikmunai is an independent oil and gas enterprise currently engaging in the exploration, production and sale of crude oil and gas condensate in northwestern Kazakhstan. Zhaikmunai's main producing asset is the Chinarevskoye field located in the northern part of the oil-rich Pre-Caspian Basin. The parent company of Zhaikmunai LLP is Zhaikmunai L.P., which held an IPO on London Stock Exchange in 2008. ASTANA. Aug 6 (Interfax) - An exploration well in the Zhambyl geological area, situated in the Kazakh sector of the Caspian Sea, has encountered hydrocarbons. "An exploration well in the Zhambyl area has encountered hydrocarbons flowing at a rate of 60 tons per day. I am glad to announce that we have discovered a new oil field," Kazakh Oil and Gas Minister Uzakbai Karabalin told President Nursultan Nazarbayev. During their meeting, Karabalin briefed the president on the developments in such areas as oil and gas production, petrochemical industry and hydrocarbon transportation, the president's press office says in a Monday press release. They also discussed such large projects as Kashagan, Tengiz and Karachaganak, stressing that Kazakhstan's interests had to be protected, specifically, in the Tengiz project as well as in any other new projects, according to the press release. Nazarbayev commented on a good progress of the Kashagan project. The Oil Ministry should closely cooperate with international partners in order gain more knowledge and bring new technology, said the president. The minister informed the president about some oil statistics. "In January-June 2013 the republic produced over 40 million tons of oil and gas condensate, which demonstrated a year-on-year increase of 1.8%. The output of natural and associated gas is on target. Exports of oil and gas products are generally on target, some minor fluctuations will be leveled out by the end of the year," the minister said. As reported, a drilling rig in the Zhambyl structure was built in summer 2012 by a Consortium of Korean investors which owns a 27% stake in this project. National Company KazMunaiGas holds a 73% stake and operates the project through its subsidiary KazMunaiTeniz. The Consortium is comprised of South Korean companies: Korean National Oil Corporation (KNOC, 35%), SK Corp. (25%), LG International Corp. (20%), Samsung Corp. (10%) and Daesung Industrial Co. Ltd (10%). The Zhambyl structure lies in the north of the Kazakh sector in the Caspian Sea, 50 km from the coastline and 180 km from the Aktau seaport. MOSCOW. Aug 6 (Interfax) - The Ireland-registered, Dubai-headquartered Dragon Oil, which produces hydrocarbons in Turkmenistan, saw its net profits drop 22% to $241.4 million in the first half of 2013, the company reported. Operating profits were down 20% at $324.1 million and sales revenues 16% at $491.6 million. The company attributes the revenue decrease to sales being down 2% and to a lower ($86/barrel) price for oil ($102/barrel a year earlier). Cost of product sold was $151.8 million in H1 this year versus $169.3 million in H1 last year. Daily production at Cheleken in Turkmenistan was up 15% year-on-year at 73,600 barrels in H1. Dragon Oil is developing this field under a production-sharing agreement. Its stake was 44% of total output versus 49% the year before. The company sold 5.7 million barrels of oil in H1 this year against 5.8 million barrels during the same period last year. All Its oil is exported through Baku. Dragon Oil cut its capex 28% to $149 million in H1. Around 37% of it went into the creation of infrastructure and exploratory drilling in Tunisia. "A consortium of companies has been selected as the winning bidder for two exploration blocks, Sanduqli and Mazar-i-Sharif, in the Afghan-Tajik Phase-1 oil & gas tender. The consortium is currently in the final stages of negotiations with the Afghanistan Ministry of Mines and Petroleum for the exploration, development and production activities in these two blocks, which are expected to conclude in Q3 2013. The contract has been initialed and submitted for final approval of the authorities. The participating interest of Dragon Oil, Turkiye Petrolleri A.O. (TPAO) and the Ghazanfar Group in the two blocks is 40%, 40% and 20%, respectively. Dragon Oil shall be the operator of the Sanduqli block while the Mazar-i-Sharif block would be operated by TPAO. Dragon Oil's diversification strategy remains to screen and evaluate targets that fit our criteria within Africa, parts of Asia and the Middle East in order to create a diversified and balanced portfolio of exploration and development assets for the group," the company said. "On the infrastructure front, installation of the Dzhygalybeg (Zhdanov) A platform is progressing well with drilling expected to commence from this platform in Q4 2013. We are currently reviewing options for an optimum location of the Dzhygalybeg (Zhdanov) B platform. Limited availability of quality contractors in the Caspian Sea region has held back our plans to add new platforms as quickly as intended; however, significant progress has been made this year to enable the group to award contracts in the near future for the construction of up to four platforms," Dragon Oil said. The controlling stock interest in Dragon Oil is held by Emirates National Oil Company, Ltd. Dragon Oil is working the contract territory of Cheleken in Turkmenistan's sector of the Caspian Sea under a production-sharing agreement signed with the Turkmen government in 1999. Cheleken features two major deposits - Dzheitune (former LAM) and Dzhygalybeg (Zhdanov). At the beg

CONTENTS TOP STORIES Energy Ministry expecting oil production of 533 mln tonnes in 2015 MOSCOW. Oct 14 (Interfax) – The Russian Energy Ministry expects oil production will grow by more than 1% to 533 million tonnes in 2015 and by 1.3% again in 2016, Energy Minister Alexander Novak told reporters at a meeting of the management of the Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs (RUIE) on Wednesday. He said that despite external and domestic challenges, the Russian fuel and energy complex is coping with set tasks and the Ministry is hoping for the recovery of the balance of supply and demand for oil in the second half of 2016. He said that Urals crude will not necessarily fall in price when Iranian oil hits the market and announced an expert meeting would be held with OPEC next week. Novak also told reporters that tax discussions for the fuel and energy sector next year are now over and the export duty on oil will be kept at the level of 42% until September 1, 2016. The Russian budget will receive 133 billion rubles thanks to the decision and Novak said that the additional tax burden on oil companies, according to the estimates of the companies themselves, will lead to a fall in oil production in 2017 by about 1% of the current level or by 5 million-6 million tonnes. Production & exports Russian oil production will grow 1.3% to 532 million-533 million tonnes in 2015 and by 1.3% again in 2016, Energy Minister Alexander Novak told reporters. "We are proceeding from the expected volume of production for 2015. This year we are expecting growth by about 1.3%, correspondingly, 532 million-533 million tonnes. And our companies are confirming that next year the same level may be reached," the minister said. "But, based on the additional collections for the budget, there are risks for a reduction in production in 2017, because oil production is an inertial process, and not investing enough in 2016 will affect production in 2017. In general in the energy strategy we are focusing on the medium term at a level of 525 million tonnes. All of what is higher, this is an additional bonus received by the budget and companies," Novak said. Exports of Russian oil in 2015-2016 are forecast at the level of 237 million tonnes, Novak told journalists. "Our figure for 2016 was 237 million tonnes. For this year it will be just as much," he said. Novak said that next year this amount will be reached due to additional production and the fall in the volumes of refining. Novak said that despite external and domestic challenges, the Russian fuel and energy complex is coping with set tasks and the Ministry is hoping for the recovery of the balance of supply and demand for oil in the second half of 2016. External challenges Urals crude will not necessarily fall in price when Iranian oil hits the market, Novak told reporters. "There's no direct link. You shouldn't think in such direct terms," he said, when asked how much Urals crude might fall in price if Iranian oil hits the market. "It won't necessarily fall in price. Everything will depend on what other countries produce, what demand there is. This all needs to be considered in the balance," he said. "Each country has the right to work on any oil and gas market. We have the global oil market," Novak said, commenting on Saudi Arabia's entry onto new markets, including traditional markets for Russia. "It has the right to sell where it feels is needed. This is competition. Now there is fierce competition on the oil market, taking into account the fact that the volume of production exceeds the volume of supply for now. Although there is already the tendency, during the last third quarter, demand was higher than production. And we are seeing the tendency for the reduction of production by 300,000 barrels a day. Therefore, we are hoping that we will feel the recovery of the balance, somewhere around the second half of 2016, we will have the balance of supply and demand," the minister said. Meanwhile, the Energy Ministry will meet with representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in Vienna on October 21 at the level of experts, Novak said. "On October 21, we will have a meeting at the level of exports. Representatives of the ministry will go to it," he said. Russia held a meeting with OPEC representatives, and also four-party consultations on the day before the latest cartel meeting at the start of June. In addition OPEC Secretary General Abdalla Salem el-Badri during a seminar on July 30 discussed the situation on the oil market and its possible development with the Russian delegation, which was headed by Novak. After the meeting, in a joint announcement, the parties said that the next meeting of the Russian delegation and OPEC may take place in Vienna in the second half of 2016. At its latest meeting in June OPEC decided to keep quotas at 30 million barrels a day. The next meeting of the ministers of OPEC members will take place on December 4 in Vienna. Downstream Novak also noted the very high rates of modernization of processing plants. "We are undergoing [this stage of modernization] for three to five years, while Europe underwent this for 15 years," he said. The minister said that in 2015 Russia will reach full import substitution for polypropylene and in 2016-2017 for polyethylene. Novak said he intended to discuss a 40%-50% rise in polypropylene prices in Russia with the Federal Antimonopoly Service (FAS). A State Duma deputy said at the RUIE meeting that polypropylene producers had hiked their prices 40%-50%, "and simultaneously," adding that the enterprises that manufactured the end product could not raise their own prices for fear of becoming less competitive, and were having to lay off staff and buy products from abroad. Novak said in response that he planned to meet FAS chief Igor Artemyev this week and that he would "make a note of the issue." Novak said the state did not regulate prices for processing stage products. "We have to examine the situation, the reason," he said, adding that there could be various reasons, like "collusion, or objective growth resulting from producer price growth."
