Russia's biggest polypropylene manufacturers are Tobolsk-Polymer, with capacity for 500,000 tonnes per year, the TAIF Group's Nizhnekamskneftekhim (220,000 tonnes), the Titan Group's Omsk-based Poliom (180,000 tonnes), SIBUR's Tomskneftekhim (140,000 tonnes), Lukoil's Stavrolen (120,000 tonnes), Ufaorgsintez, which is controlled by AFK Sistema's Unit Petrochemicals Company (100,000 tonnes); and NPP Neftekhimia, a joint venture between SIBUR and Gazprom Neft Sistema (100,000 tonnes). Asia-Pacific The Energy Ministry is studying, on the government's instructions, a project proposed by Lukoil to build a pipeline to transport Euro 5 standard diesel fuel to Asian-Pacific markets, Novak told reporters. "Such an idea, really, was announced at a recent meeting with the prime minister on the development of oil refining in Kstovo on October 6. This idea was heard from Lukoil, on the construction of an oil product pipeline to the east. Currently we have the order to study all factors, opportunities and the feasibility of constructing such an oil product pipeline. We will work on this together with our companies, and we will study the issue in more detail," he said. "There is no talk about volumes. This is all account positions, based on the needs of the market, based on the opportunities of our market for the supply of oil products to the east, taking into account the fact that we have most of our oil refineries, as it is known, located in the western part of the country. Therefore, here, of course, it is necessary to very seriously calculate the economics of a project, the opportunities and resources. For now this is just an idea," the minister said. "The project is only being studied, there's no route yet," he said. In its updated energy strategy to 2035, the Energy Ministry said one risk to the industry is "saturation of the diesel fuel market in Europe and declining demand in the near abroad." The minister said that Russia will increase exports of oil and petroleum products, including to the countries of the Asia-Pacific region and to the European market, in connection with the fall in refining volumes thanks to the increase in the depth of processing. He said that in the framework of the Energy Strategy the reconstruction and use of oil pipeline capacities was envisaged, in particular, the reconstruction and transition of oil pipelines into petroleum product pipelines to the west. "That is, we are evaluating all markets: both western and eastern, from the point of view of supplies of Russian petroleum products," Novak said. Earlier sources told Interfax that at a government meeting on oil refining at the start of October in Nizhny Novgorod, Lukoil head Vagit Alekperov proposed construction of an oil product pipeline parallel to Eastern Siberia-Pacific Ocean (ESPO) oil pipeline to export diesel fuel to markets in the Asia-Pacific region. The proposal is connected to fears that Russia may face a serious Euro 5 diesel fuel overproduction situation in the next few years. Oil companies worry that leading automotive manufacturers are switching to more ecological gasoline engines, after Russia spent years intensively modernizing refineries and ramping up production of Euro 5 diesel fuel. It was expected that Euro 5 would be exported to Europe on the upgraded Sever oil product pipeline. In addition, Russia began construction of the Yug oil product pipeline to export Euro 5 diesel fuel to Southern Europe. Gazprom Neft chief Alexander Dyukov, who took part in the meeting, said Alekperov's proposal was interesting but difficult to implement. "This is not realistic," he told Interfax. "In order to recoup investment, the capacity would need to be over 50 million tonnes a year. We don't have those volumes. The project can probably be further worked up, but intuition tells me that it is unlikely to be realized, unfortunately," Dyukov said. "For us this would be an additional route for transporting diesel fuel, this is diversification, flexibility. For us this is necessary, important. The question is - who pays? Transneft is not ready to. If they are going to invest, they need to be able to recoup investment. Are they ready to build a pipeline with 10 million tonnes of capacity that will never break even? Or maybe they will charge tariffs that will make in uninteresting for us," he said. Elsewhere, plans exist to expand the capacity of the port of Kozmino, via which oil shipped along ESPO is exported, to 31.5 million tonnes from a current 30 million tonnes of oil per year, Novak said. In time, capacity could be increased to 35 million tonnes per year, he said. Tax & duties Tax discussions for the fuel and energy sector next year are now over, Novak told reporters. "Tax discussions for next year are over, at least at government level. Final decisions were reached at Thursday's Cabinet meeting," Novak said. But he recalled that no decisions had yet been reached on gasoline excise taxes. He said there might be a differential of up to 3,500 rubles between standard 4 and 5 gasoline. "This will probably come about due to raising the excise tax on Euro 4. It will have no bearing on the end price as standard 5 is effectively the price-forming gasoline today. Next year, this will make up around 90% [of all gasoline produced in Russia]," he said. "The decision will be reached now in the State Duma, when the tax package is debated," he said. Meanwhile, the export duty on oil will be kept at the level of 42% until September 1, 2016, Novak said. He said that the changes in the taxation of the sector may lead to a fall in Russian oil production by 5 million-6 million tonnes in 2017. The Energy Ministry and the Economic Development Ministry are both against an extension of the freeze of the export duty on oil after September 1, 2016, although the Finance Ministry supports it for the whole calendar year. "Whether or not the freeze will be extended, this is not a question for me. We are against an extension and feel that all decisions need to be made in accordance with the tax maneuver. Today's decision was made for one year and we are hoping that this decision will be restrained," he said. Business daily Vedomosti reported Deputy Energy Minister Kirill Molodtsov as saying that the duty should be lowered to 36% in September 2016, as prescribed by the tax maneuver in the oil industry. Keeping the duty unchanged until September will generate about 150 billion rubles in revenue for the government, and the budget will get another 50 billion rubles thanks to growth of oil production and, consequently, the tax base. The head of tax and customs tariff policy at the Finance Ministry, Ilya Trunin confirmed that the government has drafted a resolution to freeze the export duty only until the end of August, the paper said. The decision on the duty rate after August will be made next summer following an analysis of the situation with government budget revenues and the situation in the industry. The Energy Ministry also had other proposals, such as to lower the export duty to 38-39% while raising excise rates on diesel fuel, but this idea was abandoned. It was reported earlier that the Finance Ministry was proposing to keep the export duty on oil at the 2015 level of 42% in 2016 instead of lowering it to 36% as previously planned. This would generate about 200 billion rubles in extra budget revenues. The proposal has been harshly criticized by oil companies, which have warned of a possible drop in oil production in Russia as a result of such a decision, as well as by the Energy Ministry, which wants to stabilize the tax system in the industry for the next five years. The Russian budget will receive 133 billion rubles thanks to a decision to keep the export duty on oil at 42% until September 1, 2016, Novak said. "Literally last week, on Thursday, the government decided to keep oil export duty in the framework of a major tax maneuver at 42% until September 1, 2016, while [previously] the duty was to have been lowered to 36% on January 1, 2016. This additional burden will yield some 133 billion rubles in extra levies," Novak said. Oil cos skeptical Russia's oil companies doubt that the increased taxation approved by the government will only be in effect in 2016, Novak said, adding that the Finance Ministry needs to think about tax stability. "In my view, we have a clear contradiction. On one hand, we say that long-term rules of the game are needed, and on the other, that we change these rules every year," Novak said. This reduces the opportunities for investment and makes the business climate worse. "The Finance Ministry is probably saying that beginning next year we won't do anything. But the companies are skeptical and that means that they won't make any investment decisions," Novak said, adding that since many of the oil and gas companies are public, they make decisions based on various factors, notably, tax stability. Novak urged the Finance Ministry to think 10 years ahead. The tax hikes also mean that the state is taxing the market sector and deciding for itself how to spend the money, which is at odds with Russia's transition to a market economy. "At every turn, it is said that the state invests resources inefficiently," Novak said, citing in particular reports from the Audit Chamber. "But the decision has been made. We are not discussing it. We are carrying out these tasks, but continue to work on efficiency [in the fuel and energy sector]," he said, adding: "The idea of stability in the tax system must be promoted and fundamental principles that were approved when the tax maneuver was enacted must be fought for." Gas The mineral extraction tax (MET) on gas in 2016 will amount to 100 billion rubles. MET on gas will be raised for all of 2016, a representative of the Energy Ministry told Interfax. "The duty on oil is frozen until the end of August, but the MET on gas is being raised for all of 2016," he said. He said 100 billion rubles would be taken in MET for gas in 2016. He said that the Finance Ministry is insisting upon the need to receive an additional 200 billion rubles from the oil sector for the budget. The proposal on the freeze of the duty at 42% is a compromise. This will allow for the direct receipt of additional revenue of 133 billion rubles due to the duty. "The remaining funds will be received from the specification of the forecast regarding oil production: from the increase of the duty to the additional volumes and from the MET for additional volumes," the minister said. "This will mean the investment programs of oil and gas companies will have to be altered. The tax decision applies to Gazprom, where raising MET is concerned. The volume of investment will decrease by these very figures," Novak said. "This, the companies themselves estimate, could result in a change in the volume of oil produced in 2017. Not in 2016, as the sector will take time to respond, but in 2017, by around 1% of our oil production volume, that's around 5 million-6 million tonnes," Novak said. The minister said that gas production this year will be "somewhat higher" that it was in 2014. Last year Russia produced 640 billion cubic meters (bcm) of gas, which is 30 bcm less than in 2013. The Energy Ministry's forecast for gas production this year is 668 bcm, which is 4.3% more than the figure for last year. Meanwhile, the Ministry is not expecting Ukraine to import gas in reverse mode this autumn and winter, Novak told reporters, commenting on the recent resumption by Naftogaz Ukrainy of gas purchases from Russia's Gazprom. "Of course we're interested in direct gas supplies. The first advance payment has already been received, Russian gas went to Ukraine from Monday. In our view, this is positive as it means that to some extent, gas supply volumes can be restored ahead of the autumn-winter period. The main thing is that Naftogaz is able to find the resources to pay for gas supplies during the winter period. And apart from Russia and Gazprom Ukraine's needs for gas are unlikely to be met in the winter period, and I can even say for sure that they won't be met from reverse supplies," Novak said. "We think it's Ukraine's prerogative, where they get their gas from. Unfortunately, little consideration is given to economics when they decide where they get their gas. Throughout the third quarter, Ukraine bought gas for $30 more than Russian gas was being offered. In our view that is not right, because for the same money they could have bought more gas and pumped it into their underground storage facilities. As for reverse supplies from Poland, Hungary and Slovakia, then as you know, two-thirds of this comes from Russian gas that has been supplied to Europe," Novak said. MOSCOW. Oct 13 (Interfax) - Russian Finance Minister Anton Siluanov and Russian Economic Development Minister Alexei Ulyukayev disagree about the need for state support for the country's oil sector. Speaking at the at the Russia Calling! forum, organized by VTB Capital, in Moscow on Tuesday, Ulyukayev said the fuel and energy complex needs help as the principal contributor to the federal budget, while Siluanov countered that the sector is negotiating current global difficulties well and said concessions and preferences from the state should be received primarily by non-oil sectors of the economy. Ulyakayev meanwhile said that the forecast for Russian oil production in 2016 has been raised to 533 million tonnes from 528 million tonnes, and the forecast for oil exports has been increased by 7 million tonnes. He said this was the result of a reduction in planned collections from the oil sector from 600 billion to 200 billion rubles. Rosneft President Igor Sechin meanwhile warned at the Forum that oil production in Russia will fall by 25 million-30 million tonnes per year in the next three years if the tax burden on the fuel and energy sector continues to grow. Turning to regulatory issues, Ulyukayev said that tariffs in Russia should be set based on the principle of "inflation minus," and gas prices for industry in Russia should not exceed 70% of European prices. Need for support At the Forum, Siluanov and Ulyukayev argued over whether the oil sector needs state support, with the finance minister saying that the oil sector feels itself to be quite alright in the crisis, while the economic development minister said he believes that the fuel and energy complex should receive support given its position as the main donor to the budget. "Who is the main producer of value in our country? The oil sector. What needs to be done? It is necessary to help the oil business invest," Ulyukayev said. Concessions and preferences from the state should be received primarily by non-oil sectors of the economy, Siluanov said. "In our view, if one is to speak about some preferences, this should be processing, this should be industry, but we need to worry less about the oil sector, because the oil sector feels itself to be alright in crisis conditions," Siluanov said. He said that in recent times the state has mainly helped the oil sector. "It turns out that this volume of state resources that we have, it is concentrated there, because prices were high, the concessions, if one looks, which we gave recently, were mainly to the oil business, "the most downtrodden", in quotation marks, of course. Therefore, so that we develop the oil sector, the more we give concessions, the more we help oil workers, the less that remains for other sectors of the economy," the minister said. He called such a concentration of state aid in one sector "the tactical mistake" of the last few years. "Conversely, more resources are necessary to keep for other sectors. Not to develop the oil sector, not to topple into the Dutch Disease, not to become solely dependent on the oil sector, on the country's gas. This is absolutely the incorrect approach," Siluanov said. Ulyukayev said that the oil sector needs help to invest in mature fields. "There is not a large tax return there and there is not the largest demand for associated equipment. We have on the shelf a very large amount of imported equipment, and for mature fields, 100% [of equipment] was produced in Russia. With the Energy Ministry, we reviewed the forecast for oil production at plus 5 million tonnes, and for export - plus 7 million tonnes. This is a good source of funds for the budget, and most importantly, a good basis for investment development," the minister said. "Second of all, it is necessary to help them made the step to the next production area - to go into processing, to develop petrochemicals, gas chemistry. For this, it is necessary to share the risks. We have already a very good example in Western Siberia - we are developing there, with the Russian Direct Investment Fund, and part of the risks were taken on by the state in the form of its institute, part of the risks are being borne by the National Welfare Fund. We are actually enabling the diversification of the use of resources not on crude, but to high degree on processing, on large added value," Ulyukayev said. Production, not pressure Russia does not intend to put pressure on the oil industry by imposing additional taxes on it, Russian President Vladimir Putin said at the Forum. "I want to reassure you: we perfectly understand how important the oil and gas sector is. And in driving towards structural changes, we will not do this due to pressure on a sector, which is working effectively," he said. He said that initially the Finance Ministry proposed collecting 600 billion rubles from the oil industry, now the sum of 200 billion rubles is being discussed. The forecast for Russian oil production in 2016 has been raised to 533 million tonnes from 528 million tonnes, and the forecast for oil exports has been increased by 7 million tonnes, Ulyukayev said. "We have revised the forecast for oil production for next year up by 5 [million tonnes], from 528 [million tonnes] to 533 million tonnes, and for exports by 7 million tonnes, and it seems to me that there is still a reserve here," he said. The increase in the forecast is connected with the reduction of planned collections from the oil sector from 600 billion to 200 billion rubles, he said. "Initially there was the plan through the adjustment of the mineral extraction tax (MET) to collect 600 billion rubles from the oil sector, and then it was limited to only 200 billion rubles. Accordingly, the deduction from investments is turning out to be less, and this approximately corresponds to 5 million tonnes of produced oil," he said. Sechin meanwhile warned at the Forum that oil production in Russia will fall by 25 million-30 million tonnes per year in the next three years if the tax burden on the fuel and energy sector continues to grow. "The situation with investment programs in the industry is worsening after the decision to keep the export duty on oil at the current level. If this trend continues, in the next three years we will experience the risks of oil production falling by 25 million-30 million tonnes annually, which will produce a negative fiscal effect," Sechin said. "The oil industry had a negative cash flow in the first half of the year, and we need to understand that there is current stability of production. But I would like to point out that the results were obtained as a result of investment in past years, therefore we need to support, not remove resources from current investment programs," Sechin said, remarking that Rosneft is in favour of a stable tax system and support for investment. Despite this, production costs of Russian oil companies are the lowest in the world, Sechin said. "Our costs are the lowest in the world, in the whole industry. The cost of extracting oil is about $4 per barrel at Gazprom Neft, $4.50 at Lukoil. At Rosneft it is $2.80 per barrel. This is the best figure in the world," he said. Sechin said he is insisting upon the need to keep investments in the oil and gas sector at the level of previous years. "There is currently stability of production. But these results were received, as we say, as a result of investments of previous years. It is necessary to keep investments at the level of previous years," he said. Rosneft itself has all the necessary financial resources to settle for on loans and investment, he said. "Roseneft's financial situation is stable. The company has enough reserves of liquidity to settle for loans and investment," he said. He also argued that regulation of the world oil market has essentially passed from OPEC to the United States. "Regulation, which was earlier carried out by OPEC, has essentially begun to form on the regional market of the U.S., which has turned into a regulator of global scale," Sechin said. He said that this was not only due to the shale oil phenomenon, but a "whole set of factors," including financial sources, financial derivatives, exchanges, a developed pipeline system and developed system of contractors. The development of the oil market will also be determined by how contracts for shale production will be hedged, Sechin said. Tariffs growth Turning to regulatory issues, Ulyukayev said that tariffs in Russia should be set based on the principle of "inflation minus," and gas prices for industry in Russia should not exceed 70% of European prices. "We need to maintain the right correlation between businesses' costs and their revenues. A reasonable tariff policy, including two principles, is needed for this. The first principle is 'inflation minus' [or indexation of tariffs more slowly than inflation in the previous period] with a view to the Bank of Russia's target or the forecast figure rather than actual inflation. The second principle is maintaining a gap in resource prices between the Russian consumer and the average European consumer. We believe that this gap should be about 30% for gas. In other words, the price for the Russian producer should not exceed 70% of the price for the average European producer," Ulyukayev said. A final decision on tariffs will be made slightly later, most likely, within a month's time, although the proposals will be included in the forecast, he said. "No [a final decision was not made]. The final decision, as a regulator decision, will be later, but was made for the purposes of making a forecast," the minister said. Answering a follow-up question, when the final decision would be, Ulyukayev said: "Usually in a month's time, a final regulator decision is made." He said that the Economic Development Ministry kept its proposals for tariffs in its forecast. It was reported that the Economic Development Ministry in its socioeconomic forecast set the indexation of tariffs for gas in 2016 from July 1 at 2%, tariffs on railway freight from January 1 are to be indexed by 10%, tariffs on passenger railway transport from January 1 by 4%, grids tariffs from July 1 by 7.5%. the indexation of tariffs for the population from July 1 is proposed to be carried out according to the following principle: the growth of total tariffs for housing and utilities should not exceed 4%. The Ministry is keeping proposals for the increase in tariffs for power grids in 2016 at 7.5%, Deputy Economic Development Minister Nikolai Podguzov told journalists on the sidelines of the Forum. Podguzov said that the final decisions on all tariff adjustments for next year will be made in the next few days. No serious changes regarding their proposals are expected at the ministry. The tariffs of natural monopolies should be based on the cost of transporting oil and gas, not the prices of these commodities on global markets, Sechin said. "The growth of natural monopoly tariffs should primarily reflect growth of expenses needed to increase the accessibility of services. We are facing a situation where natural monopolies proceed not from the cost of pumping or transporting our commodities, but from their market prices. Or, for example, where we are forced to pay for the services of natural monopolies in foreign currency on Russian territory. Where is the depreciation effect here?" Sechin said. Central Bank of Russia (CBR) chief Elvira Nabiullina told the Forum she believes tariffs of natural monopolies should not increase by more than the rate of inflation. "If the tariffs of natural monopolies grow faster than inflation, this means that other sectors receive less revenue. It seems to me that this distorts economic growth, despite the fact that we can achieve inflation targets. Therefore, we support the policy of that part of the government that is in favor of having tariffs of natural monopolies grow more slowly than inflation," Nabiullina said. She said that if prices grow faster than inflation in a given sector, the CBR can achieve the same inflation targets with tighter monetary policy, but prices in other sectors will grow more slowly than inflation and might even see deflation. Essentially, other sectors will lose profitability. The tariffs of natural monopolies should be indexed more slowly than the rate of inflation, considering that for many years they have risen more rapidly than inflation and there is an accumulated reserve of this growth, Nabiullina said. In addition, natural monopolies have internal reserves to increase efficiency that should be used first of all, rather than shifting costs to other sectors, Nabiullina said. Dividend requirements Elsewhere at the Forum, Russian Federal Property Agency (Rosimuschestvo) head Olga Dergumova said the Agency is against lowering the 25% dividend requirement for state companies, despite the tax maneuver. "We think this must not be done. Our position: stable dividends, this is essentially the making of a successful investment climate." No specific discussions on adjusting the dividend policies of state oil and gas companies are currently in progress, but such a step is hypothetically possible, First Deputy Russian Energy Minister Alexei Teksler told reporters earlier. He said his ministry has received proposals from oil and gas companies and is now studying them and will put them up for discussion at the presidential commission for the fuel and energy sector. "The discussion at the level of the government has not finished yet," Teksler said. One such measure is the accelerated introduction of a tax on financial result, but there are various proposals, he said. At the beginning of October, business daily Vedomosti reported that state oil and gas companies are asking to reduce their dividend payments as compensation for the government co

Crimea leaders say will convene military tribunal for Poroshenko for pledge to regain control over Crimea SIMFEROPOL. Feb 23 (Interfax) - The Crimean leader, Sergei Aksyonov, said after Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko pledged to bring Crimea back under Ukraine's control after its reintegration with Russia in March 2014, that a military tribunal will be convened to try Poroshenko. "We pledged to convene a military tribunal in Crimea for Poroshenko and, believe us, we will deliver on our pledge. We will bring him here and try him," Aksyonov told reporters in Simferopol on Monday. Poroshenko earlier released a statement on the occasion of the anniversary since Crimea rejoined Russia, saying that Ukraine will regain control over Crimea and threatening to prosecute the organizers and participants in the change of Crimea's territorial status. The statement was posted on the Ukrainian president's website on Monday. Sd

Crimean authorities plan prompt nationalization of Ukrainian state companies SIMFEROPOL. March 12 (Interfax) - The Crimean authorities will nationalize the property of Ukrainian state companies on the territory of the republic in the next few days, and the nationalization will not affect private companies, Crimean First Deputy Prime Minister Rustam Temirgaliyev told Interfax. "The property of state companies, including resource-extracting companies such as Chernomorneftegaz, and other state companies such as Ukrzaliznitsya and some state-run health resorts will become property of the Republic of Crimea in the near future," Temirgaliyev said. "Ukrainian private companies will have no problem, they will work as they did if they are legally registered and operate on the territory of Crimea, if they have the right of property to the enterprises they operate," Temirgaliyev said. "Russian banks are already coming to Crimea. Several heads of Russian banks already plan to open their offices there. After Crimea joins Russia, Ukrainian banks can register here as foreign banks," he said. Commenting on the situation with the transition of Crimean businesses from the Ukrainian tax system to the Russian tax system, Temirgaliyev said this may take a transition period of about six months. "We understand that there will be a transition period. It may take some six months. The Crimean authorities will hold seminars and work with the heads of enterprises and businesses to facilitate their transition, including to the new taxation system," Temirgaliyev said. av cm

Сrash site of the Malaysian Boeing 777 EDINBURGH, July 21 (RIA Novosti) - European investigators, who unexpectedly arrived on the Malaysian aircraft crash site in eastern Ukraine, had no legal locus to participate in the investigation without Kiev's invite, Professor Robert Black of the University of Edinburgh, known as the architect of the Lockerbie trial, told RIA Novosti on Monday. If the nation decides that they dont have the necessary facilities or investigative infrastructure, then they can call on another state or states to lend them the expertise, said Black, a globally recognized legal expert, who specialized in examining the judicial issues surrounding the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie. Air investigation teams from Europe simply arrived at the scene and are now complaining that they werent immediately allowed free access to the site, the lawyer said. It is understandable that they should be annoyed, but they have no legal locus to be there whatsoever unless and until they are invited to participate by the state which has the legal responsibility to investigate, Black added. The law is that the responsibility to investigate is that of the state where the plane came down. But given the circumstances in that part of Ukraine at the moment, it is a difficult question to answer. Who is the state and who is the government of that state? the expert said. Black agreed it was important for the site to be secured and called for proper international investigation into the circumstances of the crash. Malaysia Airlines' Flight MH17 en route from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur crashed on July 17 near Donetsk in eastern Ukraine, causing death of 283 passengers and 15 crew members. Ukrainian government and militia have been trading blame for the alleged downing of the plane, with independence supporters saying they lacked the technology to shoot down a target flying at altitude of 10 kilometers (6.2 miles). Commenting on the crash, Russian President Vladimir Putin said it was vital to abstain from hasty conclusions on the case before the international investigation was over. The UN Security Council late on Sunday night completed the text of its resolution regarding the Malaysia Airlines crash. Russia introduced its own draft resolution to the UN Security Council, calling for an impartial investigation into the circumstances of the crash.

Dacic: OSCE doing all it can to solve crisis in Ukraine BUDVA, June 6 (Tanjug) - OSCE Chairperson and Serbian Minister of Foreign Affairs Ivica Dacic stated on Saturday that all OSCE instruments have been launched in the search for a solution to the crisis in Ukraine. At the same time, this serves as support to key steps Ukraine needs to take, including constitutional reforms, protection of national minority rights, national dialogue and reconciliation, Dacic said at the forum entitled 'Future perspectives of a global security architecture' in Budva. The package of measures announced in Minsk on February 12 constitutes the best road sign for recovery of peace in eastern Ukraine, he said. We have managed to set up four working groups in charge of key issues including stability, political process, humanitarian issues, economic issues and recovery. The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine is doing all it can to facilitate the reconciliation and withdrawal of heavy weapons, Dacic said and noted that OSCE observers are working in a dangerous and instable situation. Thanks to them, the international community has once more 'discovered' OSCE which is experiencing a form of renaissance, Dacic concluded. (end) bs/ak

Deputies of the Moscow city duma have issued a statement saying that any foreign interference in Ukraine's internal affairs is inadmissible, Russian state news agency RIA Novosti reported on 26 February. "We are alarmed by instances of physical violence against representatives of state authority bodies, political parties and law-enforcement officers, which have become more frequent, as well as arson and violence [Rus: pogromy]," RIA Novosti quoted Moscow city duma deputy speaker Andrey Metelskiy as saying. According to Metelskiy, Moscow city duma deputies hope that Ukraine's political leaders will do all they can to prevent another uprising and preserve Ukraine's territorial integrity. "As a brotherly state goes through a difficult period, we are ready to provide the necessary help and support. At the same time, the Moscow city duma considers any foreign interference in the internal affairs of sovereign Ukraine inadmissible," Metelskiy said. All 30 deputies voted in favor of the statement, the report said. Moscow's previous mayor, Yuriy Luzhkov, frequently advocated maintaining the Russian navy's presence in the Ukrainian republic of Crimea, and in 1999 he suggested building a bridge across the Kerch Strait to link Crimea to Russia's Krasnodar Region. In 2008 Ukraine temporarily declared him persona non grata after he said the port of Sevastopol should never have been handed over to Ukraine along with the rest of Crimea in 1954.

Director of the Moscow Bureau for Human Rights Alexander Brod MOSCOW, April 23 (RIA Novosti) - Russian human rights campaigners forecast a rise of xenophobia and anti-Semitic attitudes among Ukrainians amid the local governments failure to resolve the crisis, the head of the Moscow Human Rights Bureau Alexander Brod said Wednesday. Brod, who is also a member of the Presidential Council for the Development of Civic Society and Human Rights, said the Moscow Human Rights Bureau has unveiled a report focusing on new negative trends in modern Ukrainian society. The report marks growing anti-Semitic attitudes both in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, as well as in western Ukraine and the countrys eastern regions, where protesters have been campaigning in support of federalization since March. This is the desecration of synagogues and monuments related to Holocaust, attacks on Hasidic Jews and members of the Jewish community, Brod told a RIA Novosti video link-up between Moscow and Tel Aviv. The Jewish-Russian human rights activist said in most cases these crimes have been slurred over and used by protest groups and authorities in Ukraine to mobilize people and unite such radical groups. With the lack of sound forces capable of uniting the interests of people in western and eastern Ukraine, anti-Semitism and neo-Nazi incidents will continue in the country, Brod said. The activist criticized the United Nations, Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Council of Europe for failing to voice concerns over the rise of such attitudes in the country. The Ukrainian regime is absolutely encouraged by Western and US structures calling this an export of democracy, Brod said, urging Russia to find allies in Israel which cannot stay indifferent towards the rise of the neo-Nazi attitudes. We should tell the truth about what is going on in modern Ukraine, he said. In February, the Ukrainian parliament backed by far-right movements ousted President Viktor Yanukovych and scheduled an early presidential election for May 25. Moscow has described the uprising in Kiev as an illegitimate fascist coup and a military seizure of power, which resulted in it taking steps to protect ethnic Russians in Ukraine, including the reunification with Crimea.

DMITRIADOVKA VILLAGE, Rostov region. June 19 (Interfax) - Russian presidential chief-of-staff Sergei Ivanov has described the ongoing events in Ukraine as a "civil war escalating into genocide". Ivanov offered his opinion concerning the situation in Ukraine at a meeting with volunteers helping Ukrainian citizens arriving in Russia in the Rostov region on Thursday. "What is happening there today - I would like to avoid any bold phrases - is, in my opinion, a civil war that is steadily turning into genocide against their own people," he said. "One can see for himself in the Rostov region that it is a humanitarian catastrophe," the Kremlin official said. Ivanov promised that "both the regional and federal authorities, the government of Russia will respond to it and will help the refugees." "These are innocent people. They are our fraternal nation. They are our people. And we will do for them whatever they ask us to do. There are plenty of options - refugee status, temporary residence status, and we have a very easy procedure as far as citizenship is concerned," he said. tm (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

Donetsk "people's governor" demands end to arrests of rebels KYIV. May 12 (Interfax) - The "people's governor" of the Donetsk region appointed by the pro-Russian insurgency has demanded that Ukrainian authorities stop their "practice of abducting" rebels and threatened tit-for-tat retaliation. "We expect that the Kyiv junta will discontinue its practice of abducting people in Donbas [a large industrial area in eastern Ukraine of which the Donetsk region is part]. Otherwise we will be forced to react commensurately and continue to take Ukrainian soldiers and Kyiv special service personnel prisoner," Dmitry Gubarev wrote on Facebook on Thursday. Gubarev, who was appointed as "people's governor" at a rally in Donetsk city on March 1, was arrested by the Ukrainian Security Service in the city on March 6. The next day a court in Kyiv ordered two-month detention for him. However, on May 7, he and Igor Perepechayenko, deputy leader of the "Slovyansk Self-Defense," were released as part of a prisoner swap deal, with the rebels freeing three members of the Alfa special forces unit. The exchange took place at a checkpoint in Slovyansk, Donetsk region. as mk

DONETSK (Rostov Region), August 20 (RIA Novosti) – A convoy carrying Russian humanitarian aid to southeastern Ukraine remains at the border checkpoint with the representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) giving instructions to the drivers, a representative of the contractor carrier company transporting the cargo told RIA Novosti on Wednesday. "The Red Cross is dealing with the issues of security, the representatives of the organization are meeting with the drivers and instructing them," he said. The representative did not say when the trucks would start moving toward Ukraine. The first 16 trucks are at the Russian Donetsk checkpoint while the rest of the 280-truck convoy remains near the town of Kamensk-Shakhtinsky. Earlier reports suggested the pause might be due to the fact that the Red Cross had not received security guarantees for the convoy to safely drive through the conflict-torn Ukrainian regions to deliver the cargo. In early August, amid the worsening humanitarian situation in Ukraine, Russia proposed to send an international humanitarian mission to eastern Ukraine with Russian aid under the auspices of the ICRC. A convoy carrying about 2,000 tons of humanitarian aid including baby food, medication, grain, sugar and other basic necessities set off from the Moscow Region on August 12 heading towards Ukraine's conflict areas.

Donetsk on the eve of elections MOSCOW (Sputnik) — German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande agreed on Saturday that separate elections in Ukraine's breakaway Donetsk and Lugansk regions would undermine the Minsk peace agreement, the German government said. The leaders criticized Donetsk and Lugansk People's Republics' decision to hold separate elections of mayors and district governors on October 18 and November 1 respectively. The rest of Ukraine is set to vote in local elections on October 25. "Hollande and Merkel emphasized that separate elections in the breakaway territories were against the agreement and would pose a threat to the Minsk [peace] process," the German government said in a press release regarding Saturday's trilateral phone call between the two EU leaders and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Donetsk People's Republic leader Alexander Zakharchenko told RIA Novosti earlier in the day that Kiev had violated the Minsk agreement, hammered out in February between the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France, when it shut out east Ukrainian representatives from debates on the election law.

Donetsk republic remains opposed to peacekeeper deployment proposal MOSCOW. Feb 23 (Interfax) - The self-declared Donetsk People's Republic opposes the proposed deployment of peacekeepers on the Donbas stretch of the Russian-Ukrainian border. "Our position remains unchanged: a deployment of peacekeepers on the border with Russia would be at odds with the set of measures to implement the Minsk agreements of February 12, given that the border issue is to be discussed after municipal elections and constitutional reform, and following talks with our representatives," Denis Pushilin the Donetsk republic's chief negotiator, told Interfax. "In accordance with the Minsk documents, the buffer zone [between the Ukrainian military and the militia] requires verification by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe," he said. "This would be quite enough," he said. The Ukrainian presidential press service earlier reported that Polish President Bronislaw Komorowski had supported Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko's plan to deploy a peacekeeper contingent in eastern Ukraine. Sd

Donetsk republic urges Poroshenko to include Donetsk, Luhansk reps in Constitutional Commission DONETSK. April 6 (Interfax) - Speaker of the self-proclaimed Donetsk republic's legislature Andrei Purgin said Donetsk and Luhansk representatives should be invited to join the work to draft constitutional amendments. "I am urging Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko to include representatives of the republics in the Constitutional Commission," Donetsk News Agency quoted Purgin as saying. Purgin earlier told Interfax that neither the Donetsk, nor the Luhansk republic's representatives attend meetings of the Constitutional Commission in Kyiv. He also assailed President Petro Poroshenko's statement that Ukraine will remain a unitary state and that the Ukrainian language will be the country's only national language. The self-declared Luhansk republic's chief negotiator in the Minsk talks Vladislav Deinego said convocation of the Constitutional Commission without the Donetsk and Luhansk republics' representatives is beyond the limits of the Minsk peace process. Poroshenko said during the first meeting of the Constitutional Commission that the Ukrainian language will be the only national language in Ukraine. He also said that he was ready to call a referendum on Ukraine's state set-up. Almost 90% of Ukrainian citizens support the unitary model, he said. The planned decentralization will not affect defense, security and foreign policy, Poroshenko said. Sd mk

DONETSK, November 5 (RIA Novosti) – Kiev is ready to deliver gas and electricity to the self-proclaimed Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics (DPR, LPR), but will seek financial compensation after regaining control over the region, Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk said Wednesday. "We will deliver gas and electricity there. At the same time, I officially state that as soon as we re-establish control over these territories, the costs of the gas and electricity that we will deliver to the Donetsk and Luhansk regions now, which are temporarily out of central government control, will be subtracted from funds intended for social benefits and subsidies," he said during a Cabinet meeting. Last week, Yatsenyuk threatened to cut off the gas supply to the regions, which are outside of Kiev's control. The DPR and LNR refuse to recognize the new Kiev authorities that came to power in Ukraine after a February coup. Both republics declared their sovereignty, based on the results of the referendums held in May. On November 2, the DPR and the LPR held elections for the heads of local governments and representatives of the legislative bodies, which Kiev has called illegitimate.

DONETSK, Ukraine. July 21 (Interfax) - Twelve Malaysian experts held a briefing in Donetsk on Monday evening before leaving for Torez, a town near the crash site of the Malaysian Airlines jet, which fell on Thursday. The Malaysian delegation's leader, Col. Mohamed Sakri, said the purpose of the team's visit is not to investigate the crash or find those guilty but to organize the earliest possible evacuation of the bodies of those killed, which, he said, would be taken to Amsterdam. Sakri said refrigerator railcars might leave Torez on Monday evening. He said there had been no obstacles to the delegation's work either from the Ukrainian government or from the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic. Sakri said the team had arrived in Donetsk later than planned but blamed this on current fighting in eastern Ukraine. He said the delegates had equal respect for both parties to the Ukrainian conflict and were open to cooperation with them. The colonel said the team would closely collaborate with International Civil Aviation Organization experts. DPR Prime Minister Alexander Borodai told the briefing that the DPR was going to declare a ceasefire within a 40-kilometer radius of the crash site. "We, for our part, are doing everything under our control to guarantee security for foreign delegations. There will be a ceasefire within a 40-kilometer radius of the site of the tragedy," he said. Borodai said the DPR was currently in talks with the Dutch government on a planned visit of between 80 and 90 Dutch representatives. Three Dutch experts had been working on the crash site since Monday morning. as (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

DONETSK. Dec 23 (Interfax) - The self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic refutes the reports on the village of Kominternove, located in the 'grey zone', being taken by the militiamen. "This information is false. The statements made by Ukrainian forces contradict reality," a DPR Defense Ministry official said on Tuesday. The militia is not conducting any offensive while implementing the Minsk agreements, the official said. Kyiv said earlier that a group of DPR militiamen had taken the village of Kominternove, using armored vehicles. "The group has entered Kominternove. They have taken positions. We have informed the SMM [Special Monitoring Mission] OSCE and the Joint Centre for Control and Coordination. We are committed to solving this incident diplomatically," Ukrainian General Staff spokesman Oleksiy Mazepa told Interfax. Afterwards the press center of Ukraine's military operation headquarters posted a detailed report on its Facebok page, claiming that the armed opponents of the official Kyiv authorities are currently building up the armaments prohibited under the Minsk agreements along the line of demarcation in other parts of the Mariupol sector. In the early hours of Tuesday, militiamen, in the number of up to one reinforced company, arrived on armored vehicles at Kominternove situated in the 'grey zone' near Mariupol and entered the village, according to the report. Apart from small arms and grenade launchers, the enemy was equipped with combat armored vehicles, probably even tanks and other heavy weaponry, use of which is prohibited by the Minsk agreements, the press center said. The information on the alleged gross violation on the part of DPR militia forces of the preliminary agreements on the peaceful settlement of the Donbas conflict was promptly distributed by the Joint Centre for Control and Coordination to representatives of the Special Monitoring Mission of the OSCE, it said. In addition, the press center said that according to the most recent data, the enemy is stepping up its presence near the demarcation line in the Mariupol area, using the weapons banned from use by the Minsk agreements. "Specifically, at least one tank has been registered in the western outskirts of Kominternove and four other tanks to the north-west of the village of Zaichenko, which is under the Kominternove rural administration. Also, there are reports about the militants possessing BM-21 'Grad' multiple launch rocket systems behind the village of Sakhanka," the report said. Meanwhile, the leadership of the military campaign and commanders of military units serving in the Mariupol area have undertaken all measures necessary to prevent the escalation of the conflict, it said.

DONETSK. May 25 (Interfax) - A massive protest was staged on Sunday at the residence belonging to Ukrainian oligarch Rinat Akhmetov. Demonstrators gathered near Akhmetov's residence, chanting: "Russia!" "Donetsk republic!". Many held flags of the Donbass self-defense forces, as well as Russian tricolor flags and flags with the inscription "Rus." Although Akhmetov was not in the residence, it was guarded by armed men without identification insignia, presumably Akhmetov's security guards, according to the Donbass militia. The prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic Alexander Borodai told the crowd that, "Akhmetov's property will be nationalized." Sd (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

DONETSK. Oct 1 (Interfax) - The leader of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR), Alexander Zakharchenko, has accused the Ukrainian side of violating the agreement on the withdrawal of weapons in Donbas and has announced that the militia will suspend this process. "In accordance with the Minsk agreements, it [weapons withdrawal] was supposed to take place even earlier. Yesterday I signed a decree on the withdrawal of weapons, but I strongly doubt that it will be implemented because the rhetoric of the Ukrainian military differs sharply from the rhetoric of [Kyiv's] representatives in Minsk. [The weapons withdrawal agreement] was signed yesterday, but Donetsk was shelled this morning," Zakharchenko told reporters on Thursday. "The document makes it absolutely clear that [weapons will start to be withdrawn] the next day since the moment when fire is ceased. Fire was not ceased today and [weapons] withdrawal has been postponed," he said. If the Ukrainian side commits any violations, the DPR will be ready to bring hardware back, Zakharchenko said. "We have vast experience in pulling back hardware and returning it to its positions. That is why we are ready for it," the DPR leader said. tm ek (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

DONETSK/KYIV. Jan 4 (Interfax) - The militia of the self-proclaimed Donetsk people's republic (DPR) claim that the Ukrainian government forces have violated a ceasefire 16 times over the past 24 hours. "Our positions have been shelled 16 times, and 30% of all violations were committed in the area of the community of Nikishyne, where Ukrainian forces used tank and artillery guns. The other facts were near the Donetsk airport and the city's northern outskirts. In these cases, Ukrainian forces used firearms and grenade launchers," militia deputy chief of staff Eduard Basurin told journalists on Sunday. The militia headquarters also told Interfax that Ukrainian artillery shelled the neighborhood of Trudovske. "A resident of the neighborhood of Trudovske sustained a stomach injury in an artillery attack. Two private homes were also damaged," a headquarters spokesman said. Ukrainian artillery also damaged a gas pipeline and several electrical substations, he said. At the same time, the Ukrainian government forces claim that the Donbas militia have violated the ceasefire 10 times. The press center of the military operation being conducted in eastern Ukraine says that the militia "shot firearms and grenade launchers twice upon the government forces at the Donetsk airport and three times in the community of Nikishyne. The communities of Bohdanivka and Orlovske came under artillery fire, and the Grad multiple rocket launcher was used to shell the outskirts of Hnutove." The press center also reported on its Facebook account that the militiamen used guided antitank missiles near Novoaidar. va (Our editorial staff can be reached at eng.editors@interfax.ru)

DPR: Donbas children not getting payments from Kyiv, can't enter Ukraine MOSCOW. April 8 (Interfax) - Ukraine does not recognize birth and death certificates issued on the territory of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) on Ukrainian forms and does not pay child benefits, Yana Chepikova, DPR adviser on children's rights, said. "Ukraine currently does not want to recognize the birth and deaths of these children. Ukraine doesn't recognize these documents. The question is why?" Chepikova told a press conference on Wednesday. Chepikova said people who are born on the territory of the DPR are issued "standard birth certificates on Ukrainian forms with Ukrainian stamps," but their parents cannot get any child benefits. She also said Ukraine has not made any payments to families with children and children with disabilities since October 2014. "The payment of all social benefits, from newborn benefits to benefits to families with children and benefits to children with disabilities, stopped in October," Chepikova said. Chepikova said people who want to travel from Donbas to Ukraine with their children are also having problems. "Our children cannot enter territories controlled by Ukraine. How can you explain to a five-year-old or a ten-year-old why they can't meet with their grandmother or grandfather in Ukraine? The mother can't get a pass because they all have been declared terrorists and separatists," Chepikova said. She added that the DPR children need assistance and psychologists are working with them because the war has deeply affected their perception of the world and reality. "The children suffered massive psychological damage. Many psychologists are now working with us. Some people are still living in shelters and small children are still falling down and covering their heads when they hear loud metal sounds from passing cars," she said. Information on the establishment of the post of DPR children's rights adviser and Chepikova's appointment to the post was reported earlier in spring 2015. av cy

DPR-LPR statement on unilateral arms withdrawal aims to raise Contact Group efficiency - Pushilin (Part 2) MOSCOW. July 18 (Interfax) - The joint statement by authorities of the self-proclaimed Donbas republics on the unilateral withdrawal of armaments with caliber under 100mm is a step made on the eve of a Contact Group meeting scheduled for July 21, DPR representative Denis Pushilin has said. "That will probably be discussed on [July] 21 because preliminary debates not supported with concrete actions unfortunately do not lead to anything. Ukraine finds different variants, so to say, to pick on particular words, particular issues, in order not to fulfill, not to do anything," he said in a program aired by the television channel Rossiya 24. "We are taking a unilateral step, which is rather resolute and daring, and this is a concrete action. That is, Ukraine will have nowhere, so to say, to wander off, but will either have to accept and do the same or admit that they are, probably, supporting a military solution to this conflict," Pushilin said. He noted that the initiative put forward by the DPR and the LPR demonstrated their "adherence to the peaceful way of resolution of this conflict." "Once again and in a unilateral manner we are taking a number of steps in order to initiate or accelerate the fulfillment process regarding provisions of the Package of Measures which have been coordinated, have been guaranteed by the chiefs of state, and which must be urgently implemented," Pushilin said. He emphasized that the militia was expecting reciprocal peace-loving steps from Kyiv. "A step forward like that. If we live to see the same actions taken by Ukraine, if there are really people there who are ready to make concrete decisions rather than simply declare them from [TV] screens addressing the European and international public, then we will be really able to take some efficient steps in the field of full-fledged termination of the hostilities and securing of truce," the DPR negotiator said. He noted that the declared withdrawal of armaments will start after they receive a positive signal from the Ukrainian authorities. "It is now necessary to receive a response. And we will be ready to start concrete actions," Pushilin said. te

Drives during a stopover. A convoy of 280 Kamaz trucks carrying humanitarian aid to civilians in southeastern Ukraine moves on MOSCOW, August 21 (RIA Novosti) - The Russian Foreign Ministry on Thursday called on all parties concerned to prevent any disruptions in the delivery of Russian humanitarian cargo to eastern Ukraine. The most important task for now is to ensure that the convoy reaches its destination point without any disruptions, the ministry said in a statement. The Russian side reiterates its firm security guarantees. Similar guarantees have also been provided by the Ukrainian authorities and the militia. The ministry also warned of possible provocations aimed at disrupting the delivery of aid. Ukraines National Security Council spokesman Andriy Lysenko said earlier today that Kiev had no information on when the Russian humanitarian aid convoy can enter the country. On Thursday afternoon, Ukrainian customs officials confirmed that they had started inspecting the first trucks carrying Russian humanitarian aid to eastern Ukraine. Earlier in August, in light of the worsening humanitarian situation in Ukraine, Russia suggested sending an international humanitarian mission to eastern Ukraine under the auspices of the ICRC. The convoy comprises 280 trucks carrying about 2,000 tons of humanitarian aid, including baby food, medicine, grain, sugar, sleeping bags and other necessities. It set off from the Moscow Region on August 12 heading toward Ukraines conflict areas. However, the convoy has been stuck on Russias border with Ukraine and Kiev had been sending conflicting reports on whether the cargo would be allowed to proceed into eastern Ukraine. After lengthy negotiations Kiev finally recognized the cargo as humanitarian aid.

DUSHANBE, July 31 (Itar-Tass) - Russia’s Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will take part in a session of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) in Dushanbe, capital of Tajikistan, on Thursday, July 31. "The session will become a key event in preparing a session of the Council of SCO Heads of State," the Russian Foreign Ministry said. Lavrov said on Wednesday, July 20, that the SCO summit was scheduled for September. "Results of the ministers’ work will be presented at the summit, which is called upon to give a serious impulse to the SCO consolidation," Lavrov said. He said the promulgation of common interests of all the SCO member-states had significance for consolidation, too. The SCO foreign ministers will coordinate joint approaches towards further development of the organisation, the situation in the world and in the region. The ministers will take a decision on the celebrations marking World War II 70th Anniversary. In 2013 the SCO ministers were instructed to work out a joint strategy for developing the organisation till 2025. The basic document "has been prepared by Russia and is being studied by the partners", the ministry said. The ministers will discuss a wide range of regional and international issues, including the situation in Ukraine. "Special attention will be paid to the situation in Afghanistan due to the presidential elections and the withdrawal of NATO’s-led contingent from the country," the ministry said. The foreign ministers will also discuss the situation in the Middle East, the events in Syria and the Iran-P5+1 talks on Tehran’s nuclear programme.

East Ukraine truce yielding results - Lavrov MOSCOW. Feb 26 (Interfax) - The latest ceasefire in the south-east of Ukraine has already proven to be effective, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has said. "The OSCE (Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe) has reported a significant reduction in the number of shootouts. The ceasefire is yielding results," Lavrov told a press conference on Thursday. "Creating the opposite impression and saying that the truce is not working is in the interests of those who still want to disrupt the Minsk process," he said. tm cy

Economy, Ukraine and intl affairs to dominate Putin's Dec 18 press conference - Kremlin official MOSCOW. Dec 16 (Interfax) - International events, the current economic situation in Russia, the Ukrainian crisis and sanctions are expected to dominate the agenda for Russian President Vladimir Putin's annual press conference on December 18, presidential press secretary Dmitry Peskov believes. "It is easy to predict that certainly there will be a whole number of questions concerning the international situation and a whole range of questions linked with the events in Ukraine because it is the final press conference," Peskov told Interfax. "Obviously, much time will be dedicated to the economy one way or the other," the press secretary said. The conflict in eastern Ukraine will also be addressed, Peskov said. "As a result of those tragic events that occurred in Ukraine last winter, there will naturally be questions about the situation in the southeast, evidently questions about Crimea, and questions about the position assumed by Western countries. Surely, there will be some questions concerning the sanctions and Russia's response to them," the press secretary said. All ministries and agencies are providing the president with relevant information as part of preparations for the press conference. "Without doubt, the whole array of information and the figures determining the main economic and social indicators are being updated very vigorously. All this is being reported to the president," he said. Questions important for the regions will also feature high on the event's agenda because scores of regional media companies have been accredited for the president's press conference, Peskov said. Questions about the 2014 Winter Olympic Games in Sochi may also be asked at the press conference, he said. Peskov did not rule out that Putin could set a new record in the history of his press conferences. But the content of the press conference is by far more important than its duration, he added. "The president may or may not set a new record. It is all about the content, not duration. And we certainly hope that, as always, it will be interesting and content-rich," Peskov said. The Russian president's annual press conference is due to begin at Moscow' International Trade Center at noon on December 18. tm

ECONOMY: CRIMEA-POWER-SUPPLY Russia to relocate additional diesel generators to Crimea - Energy Minister Novak MOSCOW, November 24. /TASS/. Additional 300 diesel generators will be delivered to Crimea, Russia’s Energy Minister Alexander Novak said Tuesday in an interview with radio station Vesti FM. "We certainly take into account possibility or worse outcome. Now we relocating diesel generator sets to Crimea to meet the need to the possible maximum, especially in those villages where there is no energy system, which are not reaches by the power in the mode of temporarily power cuts," Novak said. "Today we made the decision - Ilyushin Il-76with 300 diesel generator sets flies to Crimea," the Minister added. Novak added that at the same time, construction of energy bridge to Crimea is going according to the schedule, first phase will be commissioned in December. "All the notions that construction works are taking too long are completely unfounded. On the contrary, [the projects is going - TASS] in accordance with the schedule that we have received as part of design documentation," the Minister said. He also noted that, according to the updated plan, the first phase of a 400 MW power bridge will be commissioned in December 2015. "Apparently knowing that in December we will be partially free from dependence on the Ukrainian energy system, extremists do these things that we deal with today," Novak said. On November 20, power lags were damaged in Ukraine, presumably because of the explosive device. "On November 20 220 kV "Kakhovskaya Titan" and 30 kV Melitopol-Dzhankoy power transmission lines were damaged, presumably by an explosive device. The lines are located on the territory of Ukraine. Until the circumstances are clarified the Russian Energy Ministry constantly monitors the situation with electricity supply to the Crimean consumers," he Russian Ministry of Energy press service said. Novak also said that proper power capacity of Crimea currently covers 35-40% of the peninsula’s needs. "Currently, thanks to transferring mobile gas turbine power plants, we have overcome the absolute zero energy supply to Crimea on Sunday; we have launched about 300 megawatts, thus ensuring energy supply of the crucial infrastructure first. Now we cover, including the maximum consumption, 35-40%," Novak said. Crimea currently needs about 1,000 megawatts per day, he added. Earlier Deputy Prime Minister Dmitry Kozak said that Crimea was provided with only 30% of the required power supply.

ECONOMY: IMF-UKRAINE-RUSSIA Russia does not find it necessary to withdraw from IMF due to situation with Ukraine - Finance Minister MOSCOW, December 10. /TASS/. Russia does not find it necessary to withdraw from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) due to situation with Ukraine, Finance Minister Anton Siluanov told reporters on Thursday. "I find it is not reasonable to withdraw from the fund," - he said. "We are one of the key participants of the fund. We don’t find it necessary to withdraw from the fund because of a disputable situation which has emerged. We think that the IMF is conducting the right policy aimed at supporting balance of payments and budget of the countries, which need financial assistance," - Siluanov said. Earlier, President Vladimir Putin said that Russia was ready to restructure Ukraine’s $3 bln debt, if the US, the EU or a major international financial institution provide guarantees to Russia. But the guarantees were not provided. On December 8, the IMF Executive Board lifted the ban on provision of loans to the countries with overdue sovereign debts. The decision, in particular, means that the IMF will continue to implement its anti-crisis program for Ukraine even if Kiev fails to pay in time on its debt to Russia. This decision will also be extended to other situations where countries with sovereign debts, still enjoy the support of the fund. Russia’s Finance Ministry believes that the IMF took the decision only for Kiev, which agreed on the restructuring of commercial debt with all creditors but did not agree on the official loan it had received from Russia. On December 20, Ukraine is expected to fully pay its debt to Russia. If it fails, within 10 days after that date, Russia will go to court.

ECONOMY: RUSSIA-UKRAINE-EU Ukraine’s moratorium on debt payment not to influence Russia’s position in talks on Ukraine-EU association - Economic Development Minister NAIROBI, December 18. /TASS/. Ukraine’s decision to impose moratorium on payment of its debt to Russia is virtually a default announcement though it will not influence Russia’s position in talks on Ukraine-EU association, Russia’s Economic Development Minister Aleksey Ulyukayev said on Friday. "Moratorium aka default… Of course not, those are different things," he said when answering the question whether the decision will change Russia’s negotiating position. Earlier on Friday Ukraine’s Cabinet imposed moratorium on payment of the Russian debt worth $3 bln. Ukrainian government also imposed moratorium on the payment of $507 mln by 2 Ukrainian companies to Russian banks. On December 21, the next ministerial meeting within trilateral consultations between Russia, Ukraine and the European Union is planned to be held in Brussels where practical solutions to Russia’s concerns over implementation of the trade and economic part of the Agreement of Ukraine-EU association in various spheres will be discussed.

Editor's Note: Global Times reporter Chang Meng interviewed Russian Ambassador to China Andrey Denisov to discuss the current situation in Ukraine as Crimea prepares to go to the polls on Sunday in a vote that may dramatically influence the future of the region. GT: How will Russia administrate Crimea if it decides to join Russia after the Sunday referendum? How will Russia deal with it if the referendum has the opposite result? Denisov: It is too early to predict the results of the Sunday referendum. It is even more premature to contemplate Russia's actions with regard to the outcome. We reckon that only the people of Crimea have the right to determine their future and the future of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea. Nevertheless, we are closely monitoring the development of the situation. If the referendum brings that result [joining Russia] Crimea can turn to the Russian Federation with the proposition to accept the Republic of Crimea into the Russian Federation as a new constituent entity. In this case a respective interstate treaty between the Republic of Crimea and the Russian Federation would be needed, and if signed it should be approved by Russia's relevant authorities. So as you can see, the procedure is multilayered and quite complicated.   Today we can only observe the situation and state that Russia will fully respect any results of the free will of the Crimean people at the referendum. GT: If Ukraine eventually starts to turn to the Western camp, how will Russia handle the bilateral relations? Denisov: As President Putin said, Russia's position on the situation in Ukraine is consistent. Russia is interested in a stable and powerful Ukraine, where the legal rights and interests of the Ukrainians, our compatriots and all nationals are enforced. Russia has always considered Ukraine to not just be a neighbor but a fraternal state. Thus Russia is eager to maintain close ties with Ukraine under any circumstances. We believe that current instability in different regions of Ukraine is a direct consequence of careless actions by the new Ukrainian regime, which, in our perspective, is not fully legitimate. We advocate normalization of the situation in Ukraine and call for the fulfillment of the 21 February agreement, which would mean the formation of a legitimate national unity government considering the interests of all political forces, all nationalities and regions of the country. GT: How does Russia view and plan to tackle the sanction measures that the US and the EU have threatened to impose? What are their reasons for doing so? Denisov: Indeed, the Russian Government has been hearing certain threats to "punish" Russia for sticking to its principled line with regard to the settlement of the crisis in Ukraine. This aggrieves us a lot. These threats are obviously being used to put extra pressure on our country and to influence the Russian stance on some critical issues of international affairs. We consider such methods to be unconstructive and exacerbating tensions in bilateral and multilateral contact. Moreover if such sanctions are imposed, the harm will inevitably affect both sides and, according to many experts, Russia would not be the one who suffers more. GT: China has a close strategic partnership with Russia and holds the principle of non-intervention. As the ambassador, how do you view China's role in solving the Ukraine crisis? Denisov: Indeed, our bilateral relations with China have been on the incline. Despite the fact that they have always been very good, recently we can see a new drive for significant development. Today we may speak of "new heights"in our cooperation in all fields. Leaders and foreign ministers of our countries have discussed the current crisis in Ukraine. We are very grateful to China for its balanced and principled position on this issue. Russia and China are making a significant contribution to international development and security. We hope that the closeness of our positions on Ukraine will become an important factor for stability in the region.  GT: Some observers see the crisis as a Cold War scar. How would different resolutions influence the international situation and also Russia's relations with the US and the EU? Denisov: The crisis in Ukraine has deep internal roots and is not about Russia-US or Russia-EU relationships. We regret that our Western partners are not always able to adequately perceive the changing reality and accept that it is not possible to impose their own will everywhere on the globe. Still we express our sincere hope that the situation in Ukraine will pacify soon, contacts with our American and European counterparts will become more productive, and contribute to the normalization of the crisis. GT: What is your comment regarding the recent postings on the official Sina Weibo account of your embassy, especially those refuting the moves of the US? Denisov: I know that some of the blog postings on the Russian Embassy official Sina Weibo have triggered a broad discussion among netizens and in media. All of those postings reflect the official position of the Russian Federation and are strictly in line with the statements recently made by Russian officials. I noticed that the online community was particularly interested in the statement by Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman A.Lukashevich commenting on the distortion of facts by the US Department of State. We are indeed concerned with some cases of applying "double standards" in international affairs and misinterpreting reality which only result in escalation of tensions around developments in Ukraine and Crimea. Thus we feel the need to provide the Chinese public with our insights and express our hope for more followers.

Eight MPs from Russia's Stavropol Kray will observe the 16 March referendum in Crimea, News.1777.ru website reported on 13 March. MPs, who travelled to Crimea to deliver humanitarian aid, met the management of Crimea's Berkut riot police battalion and other security agencies. They also discussed humanitarian assistance with local authorities, the News.1777.ru website said, referring to the press service of Stavropol parliament. "In general, the situation is calm: Crimea is preparing for a referendum. Of course, the majority supports unification with Russia. Of course, they are concerned that there will be a provocation," Stavropol Kray MP Gennadiy Yefimov, Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, said to GTRK Stavropolye TV by phone on 12 March. "We met veteran organizations. They asked a lot of questions, mainly about pensions, insurance, housing and utility services. We tried to answer their questions," Kirill Kuzmin, MP from Just Russia party, told the channel.

Espreso TV Online reported at 1552 GMT that police have discovered the body of "the head of Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko's campaign staff in one of Vinnytsya Oblast rayons." According to a police report, the man's body with a gunshot wound to the head was found in the man's car in Nemyriv, Vinnytsya Oblast, around 1230 local time (0930 GMT) 5 June. Further as warranted.

EU and Russia could work together if the Ukrainian conflict is frozen, Simeon Djankov, former deputy prime minister and minister of finance of Bulgaria said WASHINGTON, October 2 (RIA Novosti) - European Union and Russia could work together if the Ukrainian conflict is frozen and the European Commission is likely to respond to limiting of hostilities in Ukraine by lessening the sanctions regime against Russia, said Simeon Djankov, former deputy prime minister and minister of finance of Bulgaria. "If you notice, literally in the last two weeks the discussion evolved from incoming President [of the European Commission, Jean-Claude] Juncker and a number of his commissioners has been on if there is a limit to the hostilities, if we reach a position of frozen conflict, then we can discuss how we and the Russians can work together," said Djankov at a Thursday Peterson Institute of International Economics event on global economics prospects. Djankov noted that this position was in stark contrast to statements made by EU officials in the summer saying that without a long-term solution, Russia would face increased sanctions. European economic sanctions have had a disproportionate impact on the EU's 28 member states and European businesses, said Djankov. He added that the European business leaders have voiced opposition to the sanctions. "[They] have been saying the costs are disproportionately affecting our economies, so we are very unlikely in the future to go with other sanctions," he said. Further, he noted that those countries have been pressuring the incoming European Commissioners to explain under what conditions the current sanctions regime can start begin alleviated. Since Crimea vote to rejoin with Russia in March, the European Union, the United States and other western partners have levied sanctions against Russia on three separate occasions. The successful ceasefire negotiations that took place in Minsk, Belarus in early September have served as a confidence building measure, opening discussions of sanctions relief. In October, the European Commission is scheduled to discuss modifying Russian sanctions, an act that will require unanimous consent.

EU has given Ukraine, Georgia clear signal about prospects of visa-free regime - Poroshenko (Part 2) RIGA. May 22 (Interfax) - Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko says Ukraine and Georgia have received a signal from the European Union about the prospects of the introduction of a visa-free regime. "We have [received] a strong message that the EU welcomes the success of Ukraine and Georgia in the liberalization of the visa regime with the EU," Poroshenko told reporters after the Eastern Partnership summit in Riga on Friday. Poroshenko said there are no political obstacles in the issue of the provision of a visa-free regime with the EU. "We have now removed all political obstacles to a visa-free regime," the president said, responding to a question as to what Ukraine will do to ensure prompt introduction of visa-free regime with the EU. Poroshenko added that "solely technical issues remain to be resolved to achieve this goal." av gs

EU links resumption of visa-free travel dialogue with Russia to normalization in Ukraine MOSCOW. Jan 15 (Interfax) - The European Union is prepared to resume the dialogue with Russia in various fields, including visa-free travel, Ukraine situation permitting, a European diplomat told Interfax. There are spheres of cooperation beyond sanctions, such as humanitarian contacts, cooperation between partners in the protection of human rights and civil society, he said in view of the EU foreign ministerial conference due on January 19.
