Speaking of the possibility to resume the visa-free travel dialogue between Russia and the European Union, the diplomat said it would be good if the Ukraine situation allowed the unlocking of various dialogue dimensions. Most importantly, the EU is ready for a new stage of relationship if the Ukraine situation permits this to happen, he emphasized. The diplomat added that the issue of anti-Russian sanctions was unlikely to be discussed by the EU foreign ministers on January 19. In the procedural sense, the sanctions will be discussed in March and July upon the expiry of the twelve-month period, the source noted. He also said it was much too early to say which decisions the EU foreign ministers might make. Te ap

EU still ready to sign association agreement with Ukraine - Estonian foreign minister TALLINN. Feb 26 (Interfax) - The European Union is ready to support a democratic and peaceful Ukraine, Estonian Foreign Minister Urmas Paet said while visiting Kyiv on Tuesday. "The association agreement between the EU and Ukraine is still ready to be signed. We favor its soonest possible conclusion and believe this would be helpful in terms of Ukraine's future," the Estonian Foreign Ministry press service quoted Paet as saying. "Ukraine's unity, the sense of responsibility of its political forces and the overcoming of the political crisis are crucial for true political and economic stability," he said. "It is very important to set up a new and responsible government, so that the state could be provided with financial assistance, for instance, through the European Union, the IMF or other institutions," he said. He also supported the idea of holding presidential elections based on the people's free will in May. Paet praised the Ukrainian people's desire to build a state respecting democracy and human rights. What is important right now is to lessen tensions on the streets and in the provinces and improve confidence in society, he said. During his visit to Ukraine, Paet met with Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada Deputy Chairman Ruslan Koshulynsky and Party of Regions parliamentary faction leader Oleksandr Yefremov. He also met with U.S. Deputy Secretary of State William Burns in Kyiv. va cm

EU summit leaves Russia sanctions unchanged (Part 2) BRUSSELS. Oct 24 (Interfax) - The European Council has "recalled its previous decisions on restrictive measures" imposed on Russia over the Ukrainian crisis, according to a communique issued by the EU leaders after their meeting on Friday. The Council "will remain seized with Ukraine in order to provide direction as required," the document said. The Council also underlined the need for full compliance with the Minsk Protocol on ceasefire in eastern Ukraine. "The Russian Federation should assume its responsibilities for the full implementation of the Minsk agreements," the communique said. Kk ap

Excerpt from news report by Russian official state television channel Rossiya 1 on 5 June [Presenter, as part of report from Omsk on a "social innovations forum"] We are now joined live by Federation Council speaker Valentina Matviyenko. Thank you, Valentina Ivanovna, for finding the time to talk to us. [Passage omitted: outline of agenda as suggested by the forum's title] [Presenter] Now as to Ukraine: What in your view is the latest act of provocation by Kiev's military [as fighting escalates in Ukraine's southeast] to do with? [Matviyenko (captioned)] Well, you know, it seems to me there is an explanation. As soon as the situation calms down, as soon as it starts to improve and talk starts whether the issue of whether to soften the sanctions or lift the sanctions against Russia needs to be considered, as if at the direction of a conductor new acts of provocation start. The aim is to create a negative information background and for no reason at all, without any foundation to blame the Russian Federation for the escalation of the situation. The Kiev authorities do not want to negotiate with the DPR and LPR [self-proclaimed "Donetsk People's Republic" and "Luhansk People's Republic"]. We can see how they are in every way putting up new obstacles to the implementation of the political part of the Minsk accords. What is behind this is this: After all, they need to account to their own nation for what is happening in Ukraine, for the worsening of the economic situation, for the violation of human rights, for the persecution of dissidents, the violation of the rights of the mass media and simply for the total worsening of life for the citizens of Ukraine. They do not want to account for that, however. And, of course, another explanation is that there will be a G7 summit soon. There, of course, the issue of sanctions against Russia will be on the agenda. [Presenter] Thank you, Valentina Ivanovna. Federation Council speaker Valentina Matviyenko was answering our questions. [1432 gmt] Source: Rossiya 1 TV, Moscow, in Russian 1400 gmt 5 Jun 15

Excerpt from report by privately-owned Russian news agency Interfax Moscow, 13 October: The leadership of the Donetsk people's republic [DPR] is not against the flights of the OSCE drones over the territory of the self-proclaimed republic but warns of technical complications concerning their security. "Politically, we are certainly not against the OSCE using its drones to monitor the situation. However, there is a number of technical issues which have not been resolved yet," DPR vice-premier Andriy Purhin [Russian: Andrey Purgin] told Interfax. In particular, he said, it is not clear enough how to distinguish an OSCE drone from a similar Ukrainian aircraft in the air. "One should not rule out that mistakes can be made when identifying an aircraft and for the moment it is technically difficult to guarantee security of the flights of such planes," Purhin said. [Passage omitted]

Excerpt from report by privately-owned Russian news agency Interfax Moscow, 23 March: Head of the State Duma Committee for International Affairs Aleksey Pushkov has responded to Washington's support for demilitarizing Crimea with a counterproposal: to wind up the North Atlantic alliance [NATO]. "Demilitarizing Crimea is a stillborn idea. It is neither in Ukraine's nor in the USA's remit. Why don't we discuss voluntary dissolution of NATO instead?" the committee head wrote on his Twitter page on Friday evening [as received; the tweet is in fact dated Sunday 23 March]. US support for the idea of demilitarizing Crimea was expressed on 20 March by [US] Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs Wendy Sherman. [Passage omitted: Sherman quoted]

Excerpt from report by privately-owned Ukrainian news and analysis website Levyy Bereg on 24 April The self-proclaimed mayor of Slovyansk [Donetsk Region city], Vyacheslav Ponomaryov, has told his gunmen to occupy kindergartens. Journalist Roman Burko reported this on Facebook, quoting eyewitnesses. According to the eyewitnesses, groups of about five to six persons were in kindergartens and schools at about 1300 [1000 gmt]. Ponomaryov told his terrorists to use [Russian President Vladimir] Putin's tactic of shielding themselves with women and children. Parents who came to a kindergarten to take their children home were faced with the fact that their children were not given to them under various pretexts, saying that they should fight on the side of the "Donetsk republic". We recall that Ponomaryov promised to kill all hostages and shoot the city's residents for their help to Ukrainian servicemen. [Passage omitted: more about Ponomaryov's threats]

Excerpt from report by RIA Novosti (part of the state-owned International News Agency Rossiya Segodnya); subheads are as published: Krasnodar, 17 December: Krasnodar Kray governor Aleksandr Tkachev believes that the slump in the exchange rate of the ruble is to a large extent "manmade", and it is Russia's payment for its position on the international arena, including for the incorporation of Crimea. [Passage omitted: summary of ruble slump, related financial development] Price of victory In Tkachev's view, both Western sanctions and the oil price drop had a political impact on the ruble rate and the macroeconomic state of the Russian economy. He described the oil price drop as a "provoked and manmade strike". He said it was an illusion to suppose that the West would put up with the incorporation of Crimea into Russia, and that our country would still "remain steady and stable". "(The situation in the Russian economy) is the price, the challenge that we have to accept. Didn't we all applaud, didn't we all say it's great, well done, us, for making Crimea ours. This means we have to share not only the responsibility but also the burden, the losses," Tkachev said during the session of the territorial parliament on Wednesday [17 December]. Advantages and disadvantages In Tkachev's view, there are both advantages and disadvantages in the political challenge that Russia has made to the West. Thus for instance, he said, Krasnodar Kray, which he heads, now has the opportunity to improve its position in agriculture. Furthermore, he is convinced that in the current conditions the authorities have to develop medium and small business, the light and, as much as possible, the heavy industry. "It will, however, take years," he admitted. Moreover, with the new interest rate rise, "not a single enterprise will be able to develop and create a competitive product". At the same time Tkachev is convinced that the state will direct all the resources to the suppression of inflationary pressures, the strengthening of the ruble and the return to an acceptable interest rate. "This is quite a difficult time, which carries risks for our country, but the objective remains the same: we have to not only retain our potential but also think about growth, about creating new productions - no-one has scrapped this program," Tkachev said. He expects the situation on the currency market to start stabilizing before the New Year. "We'll overcome these difficulties. And our choice in favor of Crimea, in favor of successful Olympics, was a conscious choice... We have a strong army, we have economic potential," Tkachev said, adding that Russia in 2000 and in 2014 was two different things.
